<h2>Results from Fall 2022</h2><div class="info-updated"><p>This information was last updated at Wednesday, October 26, 2022 at 10:35 AM</p><div class="openCloseAll"> <img style="margin:0 auto; display:none;" src="https://timetable.dawsoncollege.qc.ca/wp-content/plugins/timetable//assets/images/ajax-loader.gif"/> <a class="openAll btn btn-sm btn-default" href="#">Open All</a> <a class="closeAll btn btn-sm btn-default" href="#">Close All</a></div></div><h2>3D Animation and Computer Generated Imagery</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-111-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Preproduction</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Meinert Hansen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will introduce students to the visual development of an animated film. Design foundations will be covered in terms of how they related to visual storytelling. Students will work from a short script.   Topics include: story beat visualizations, environments designs, layout and choreography, props and character designs, cinematography and film structure.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Meinert Hansen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will introduce students to the visual development of an animated film. Design foundations will be covered in terms of how they related to visual storytelling. Students will work from a short script.   Topics include: story beat visualizations, environments designs, layout and choreography, props and character designs, cinematography and film structure.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">9:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-121-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Principles of Animation I</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Geoff Carley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This will be a 2D digital animation course. It will use hand drawn animation to explore the fundamentals of movement and will introduce students to observing the characteristics of movement and how to achieve believable movement by following and exaggerating these characteristics.  Topics include: timing and rhythm, ease in/ease out, squash and stretch, drag and overlapping action, wave principle, key-frames and pose to pose animation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">9:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Geoff Carley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This will be a 2D digital animation course. It will use hand drawn animation to explore the fundamentals of movement and will introduce students to observing the characteristics of movement and how to achieve believable movement by following and exaggerating these characteristics.  Topics include: timing and rhythm, ease in/ease out, squash and stretch, drag and overlapping action, wave principle, key-frames and pose to pose animation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-131-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to 3D Animation</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alison Loader</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to provide students with an introduction to the 3D digital tools that will be utilized in the development of animation processes and products. Students will be introduced to the latest software tools used in a 3D animation production. Through interactive lecture, discussion, demonstration and application, students prepare for further classes in 3D animation. Topics include: 3D application tools and functions, modeling, animation, materials and mapping, and rendering.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alison Loader</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to provide students with an introduction to the 3D digital tools that will be utilized in the development of animation processes and products. Students explore basic tools and apply them to various anatomical problems to find modelling and rigging solutions for character motion. Major emphasis is placed on proper identification and placement of controls. Topics include: polygon character modeling, forward and inverse kinematics, efficient use and planning of polygons, character rigging, skeletal structures, bone weighting, behavioural expressions, morph targets, and constraints and expressions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Josef Sy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores the basic principles of modelling and rigging as applied to a series of very different characters. Students explore basic tools and apply them to various anatomical problems to find modelling and rigging solutions for character motion. Major emphasis is placed on proper identification and placement of controls. Topics include: polygon character modeling, forward and inverse kinematics, efficient use and planning of polygons, character rigging, skeletal structures, bone weighting, behavioural expressions, morph targets, and constraints and expressions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-352-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Character Design</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Geoff Carley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will expand upon students' previously acquired figure drawing techniques with a focus on character traits and expression. Quick sketch techniques to capture weight, balance, mood and emotion will be explored, as well as refinement and presentation. Topics include: attitude and exaggeration, visual character design elements and their role in typecasting, and model sheets and their production.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Geoff Carley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will expand upon students' previously acquired figure drawing techniques with a focus on character traits and expression. Quick sketch techniques to capture weight, balance, mood and emotion will be explored, as well as refinement and presentation. Topics include: attitude and exaggeration, visual character design elements and their role in typecasting, and model sheets and their production.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-362-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Matte Painting</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Raymon Fong</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course follows Digital Colors and Textures.  Using Photoshop, students learn to apply 3D textures and create digital matte paintings. The course will explore several texture mapping techniques and apply painted surface details onto 3D geometry. Students will be asked to apply their knowledge of 2D and 3D applications to create texture maps and backgrounds for future production. Topics include: building a color palette, paint sketching techniques, blocking in of shapes, colors on a perspective grid, believable atmospheres, atmospheric perspective, composition, lighting and cinematography.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Raymon Fong</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course follows Digital Colors and Textures.  Using Photoshop, students learn to apply 3D textures and create digital matte paintings. The course will explore several texture mapping techniques and apply painted surface details onto 3D geometry. Students will be asked to apply their knowledge of 2D and 3D applications to create texture maps and backgrounds for future production. Topics include: building a color palette, paint sketching techniques, blocking in of shapes, colors on a perspective grid, believable atmospheres, atmospheric perspective, composition, lighting and cinematography.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-363-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Virtual Worlds</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matthew McIver</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will study the simulated environment of virtual worlds and 3D genre, including tutorials in 3D modelling. This course in scene design addresses all the traditional cinematic concepts using digital tools. The 3D software will be used to design and build all the aspects of set components, including: scenery, lighting, and props, and landscape. The dynamics of moving sets are also studied. Topics include: building environments, animating moving sets, choreographing lighting, creating visual effects, fog, snow, smoke, mood lighting, lightning, and rain.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matthew McIver</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will study the simulated environment of virtual worlds and 3D genre, including tutorials in 3D modelling. This course in scene design addresses all the traditional cinematic concepts using digital tools. The 3D software will be used to design and build all the aspects of set components, including: scenery, lighting, and props, and landscape. The dynamics of moving sets are also studied. Topics include: building environments, animating moving sets, choreographing lighting, creating visual effects, fog, snow, smoke, mood lighting, lightning, and rain.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-371-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Modelling Props</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matthew McIver</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Modelling clean animate-able meshes is an essential skill in the 3D industry. Modelling props will focus on instilling proper modelling workflow including concept development and reference gathering. Through lectures, in class demonstrations and assignments, students will learn tools and techniques to model non organic objects, seamless texturing of props and rendering. Topics include: polygon modeling techniques, deformations, hierarchy and linking, utilizing system scaling and units, and lighting and rendering of props.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matthew McIver</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Modelling clean animate-able meshes is an essential skill in the 3D industry. Modelling props will focus on instilling proper modelling workflow including concept development and reference gathering. Through lectures, in class demonstrations and assignments, students will learn tools and techniques to model non organic objects, seamless texturing of props and rendering. Topics include: polygon modeling techniques, deformations, hierarchy and linking, utilizing system scaling and units, and lighting and rendering of props.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-381-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Lights, Camera and Rendering I</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nabil E. Kachaami</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will study rendered images achieved by using advanced software making real, all natural visual phenomena. Illumination, color, shadows, darkness and light will be studied. This course introduces the student to the concepts of light, shadow and surface properties as they apply to creating environments and visual effects within 3D graphics applications. The study of the natural properties of light and human perception will be the focus. Topics include: three point lighting, global illumination, camera lens properties, depth of field, caustics and radiosity, shaders and rendering.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">James Giberson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will study rendered images achieved by using advanced software making real, all natural visual phenomena. Illumination, color, shadows, darkness and light will be studied. This course introduces the student to the concepts of light, shadow and surface properties as they apply to creating environments and visual effects within 3D graphics applications. The study of the natural properties of light and human perception will be the focus. Topics include: three point lighting, global illumination, camera lens properties, depth of field, caustics and radiosity, shaders and rendering.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-501-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Visual Effects</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Raymon Fong</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will be an introduction to digital compositing principles and visual effects skills using compositing software. Students will explore and understand main compositing and visual effect tools. Concepts such as creating a composite branch, layering images and animation will be introduced and practiced.  Topics include: composting, particle systems, tracking, and image stabilization</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">James Giberson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will be an introduction to digital compositing principles and visual effects skills using compositing software. The course will consist of training in digital video and audio standards, as well as compression techniques including the authoring of appropriate output formats for a student reel or web. Topics include: tools and techniques for digital video editing, coherent sequencing and continuity, camera angles, shots, and framing, mixing a soundtrack, basic titles, and output.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Raymon Fong</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students will learn the practical processes and the software skills required to combine digital animation and audio into a final production which the graduates will then use to enter the workforce. Students will design their characters, environments, and camera action. In this advanced course students will continue to build upon their skills. Time will be spent refining scenes, objects and characters in preparation for their final production project. Students explore methods for cultivating original ideas suitable for production as a short animated reel. Preliminary exercises lead to the development of a production-ready concept package that they will present for critique. Modelling approaches will be discussed and chosen. Each project will be fully scripted, critiqued, and rewritten before going into production. Topics include: storyboard, script, modeling  design of props environments and character, and animatic  production with sound.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Charles Le Guen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students learn how to effectively plan, coordinate, and execute a feature film idea. Students organize and develop production technique similar to that experienced in industry. Emphasis is placed on the development of a production schedule and adherence to the schedule, problem solving and working effectively as a production team. In addition, students demonstrate the ability to develop work that demonstrates teamwork, organization, effective sequencing, continuity, consistency in terms of style, production. Topics include: teamwork, organization, effective sequencing, continuity, consistency in terms of style, and production.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Alison Loader, Khadija Boulazhar, Matthew McIver</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to provide students with the opportunity to generate an animated group project. Students study the elements of complex motion, performance structure, and their relationship to digital inverse kinematics. Digital characters with natural movement, emotion, and density are created. The primary focus of this course is creating digital characters that act, and improve realistic movement by developing animation techniques that extend the realism of 3D animation. Topics include: IK systems, timing ease in out, line of action and arcs, anticipation and emotion, exaggeration and realistic movement, and acting for animators.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:30 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Omar Morsy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course focuses on the task of creating a believable animated performance using advanced character tools. Students study the elements of complex motion, performance structure, and their relationship to digital inverse kinematics. Digital characters with natural movement, emotion, and density are created. The primary focus of this course is creating digital characters that act, and improve realistic movement by developing animation techniques that extend the realism of 3D animation. Topics include: IK systems, timing ease in out, line of action and arcs, anticipation and emotion, exaggeration and realistic movement, and acting for animators.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:00 AM - 1:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Anthropology</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">381-101-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Anthropology</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">10 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Katarzyna Wolfson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course provides an overview of what anthropology encompasses from the history of anthropological thought to the major subfields of study including linguistics, biology, social and archaeology. The unique vision and  social scientific perspective that anthropology brings to the social sciences will be discussed. This course will present an approach designed to introduce students to main areas of the discipline that may be explored more profoundly in the higher level courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Verity Whalen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course provides an overview of what anthropology encompasses from the history of anthropological thought to the major subfields of study including linguistics, biology, social and archaeology. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">381-204-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Development of Civilization</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maciej Domanski</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will trace the development of civilizations from the prehistoric beginnings of human and social organization, warfare, religion, sexual domination and domestication, to the rise of large, complex urban civilizations.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">381-210-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Anthropology of Parenthood</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Cornelia Howell</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course deals with the concept of parenthood by investigating how different cultures define motherhood, fatherhood and parenthood in practical terms. With this cross-cultural perspective, parenthood in the Western context will be explored by re-examining ideas about biological and social parenthood.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">381-302-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Race and Racism</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carolina Pineda</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines race and ethnic relations from an anthropological perspective with emphasis on the contemporary Canadian scene. Of particular concern is the impact of race as a cultural concept not a biological fact, as well as the influence of institutional racism on residential patterns, immigration, stratification, marriage and the family, identity formation, politics, law and social control, religion, rituals, language and communication.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">381-BWS-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Anthropology</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Culture on the Move</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carolina Pineda</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to introduce students to the social science of anthropology. An introduction to the major subfields of study including linguistics, biology, social and archaeology will allow students to understand how anthropologists study the origins and development of humans in the context of their physical and cultural environments. Students will learn about different cultures as well as the workings of their own culture. The concept of culture will be used to explore the movement of people, ideas and things. Motivations and impacts (socio-cultural, environmental, economic and political) will be examined to reveal complexities and nuances of mobility (or lack thereof) of people, ideas and things in todays world.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Biology</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">101-801-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Biological Systems in Radiation Oncology</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Virginia Hock</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The purpose of this course is to give the student the essentials of anatomy and physiology of all human body systems as they pertain to Radiation Oncology. The structure and function of cells are discussed with an emphasis on the cell cycle and cell division (mitosis and meiosis). All human anatomical systems are described concerning location, surface landmarks, and surrounding structures. The physiology of all systems is described with particular attention given to the skeletal, nervous, lymphatic, respiratory, digestive, and reproductive systems.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Radiation Oncology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Virginia Hock</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The purpose of this course is to give the student the essentials of anatomy and physiology of all human body systems as they pertain to Radiation Oncology. The structure and function of cells are discussed with an emphasis on the cell cycle and cell division (mitosis and meiosis). All human anatomical systems are described concerning location, surface landmarks, and surrounding structures. The physiology of all systems is described with particular attention given to the skeletal, nervous, lymphatic, respiratory, digestive, and reproductive systems.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Radiation Oncology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">3:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">101-910-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Anatomy and Physiology 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Brid Nic Niocaill</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is the first of two that are designed to introduce the student to the fundamentals of anatomy and physiology of all human body systems. Physiological and anatomical terminology are introduced as well as important biological concepts such as homeostasis. The basics of cell structure and function are discussed with emphasis on the cellular organelles, cell cycle, and meiotic cell division. The main focus of this course is both the physiology and three-dimensional anatomy (with respect to locations, surface landmarks, vasculature, and surrounding structures) of the nervous, endocrine, digestive, urinary and reproductive systems.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Medical Ultrasound Tech</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.29</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">101-915-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Human Anatomy and Physiology</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Francesca M. Thriault</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course focuses on analyzing the roles of anatomical structures and physiological interactions in the maintenance of equilibrium in the human body, a principle termed homeostasis. Emphasis is placed on accurate interpretation of concepts and phenomena related to homeostasis, both through the study of the normal functioning of cells, tissues, organs and organ systems and through analysis of disease states.  Importance is placed on linking normal and abnormal anatomy and physiological functions with appropriate biomedical samples.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Biomed Lab Tech</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.29</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.29</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Tutorial</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.37</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Francesca M. Thriault</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course focuses on analyzing the roles of anatomical structures and physiological interactions in the maintenance of equilibrium in the human body, a principle termed homeostasis. Emphasis is placed on accurate interpretation of concepts and phenomena related to homeostasis, both through the study of the normal functioning of cells, tissues, organs and organ systems and through analysis of disease states.  Importance is placed on linking normal and abnormal anatomy and physiological functions with appropriate biomedical samples.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Biomed Lab Tech</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Tutorial</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">3:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">3:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.29</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.29</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.37</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">101-917-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Applied Molecular Biology</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Andrew Wieczorek</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to introduce students to the field of molecular biology by describing its fundamental principles, techniques, and applications. Students are guided through the central dogma of molecular biology where they will explore the structure and function of nucleic acids in cells. Several techniques in molecular biology will be discussed in lectures and some key PCR based techniques will be carried out in laboratories. Applications of these techniques in molecular diagnostics will be highlighted.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Biomed Lab Tech</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.29</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.29</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.4</td><td data-label="Type">Tutorial</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">101-921-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Human Biology</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">10 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Angela Rose Lapierre</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course begins with an introduction to anatomical terminology, a discussion of the various levels of structural organization thatmake up the human body, and a brief overviewof each system's contribution to homeostasis.  The course emphasizes control systems(nervous and endocrine), reproduction, and classical genetics. The material covered in this course provides a useful background for nonscience students planning to study psychology in university. This course can be used as a concentration course in Social Science, but cannot  be used in the revised Science programs.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.29</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gina Gentile</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course begins with an introduction to anatomical terminology, a discussion of the various levels of structural organization thatmake up the human body, and a brief overviewof each system's contribution to homeostasis. Blood circulatory system is covered in detail. Laboratory exercises complement class work.  Throughout the four courses students are encouraged to appreciate that life processes have a molecular basis. The program specific competencies, which are to develop an integrated perception of the human body and functions, and to link immunity/infections to physiological and metabolic mechanisms, are developed in all four of the biology courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Nursing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.29</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Suzanne Kunicki</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is the first in a series of four courses in human anatomy & physiology and immunology & microbiology for Nursing students in which all the main topics are introduced. Blood circulatory system is covered in detail. Laboratory exercises complement class work.  Throughout the four courses students are encouraged to appreciate that life processes have a molecular basis. Blood circulatory system is covered in detail. Laboratory exercises complement class work.  Throughout the four courses students are encouraged to appreciate that life processes have a molecular basis. The program specific competencies, which are to develop an integrated perception of the human body and functions, and to link immunity/infections to physiological and metabolic mechanisms, are developed in all four of the biology courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Nursing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.29</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Caroline Robert</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is the first in a series of four courses in human anatomy & physiology and immunology & microbiology for Nursing students in which all the main topics are introduced. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">101-987-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Human Body for Nurses III</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">4 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Brid Nic Niocaill</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is the third in a series of four courses in human anatomy and physiology, immunology and microbiology for Nursing Students. Throughout these courses students are encouraged to appreciate that life processes have a molecular basis and that despite obvious differences, all living things have much in common. The program specific competencies: to develop an integrated perception of the human body and functions, and to link immunity/infections to physiological and metabolic mechanisms, are developed in all four of the biology courses. In this third course, the main topics are metabolism, reproduction and defense mechanisms, both general defense and immunology. Laboratory exercises, consisting mostly of computer simulations, complement class work.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Nursing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Brid Nic Niocaill</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is the third in a series of four courses in human anatomy and physiology, immunology and microbiology for Nursing Students. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">101-BWT-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Science and Technology: Introduction to the Science of Biology</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Biology of Sustainability</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Brian Mader</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The aim of this course is to introduce non-science students to the biological mechanisms involved with sustainable practices. This course introduces ecological principles and conservation biology as they relate to human impacts on biodiversity and sustainability. Students will gain an understanding of current environmental issues and sustainable practices, with a specific focus on sustainability projects/Living Campus at Dawson College.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Biology of Sustainability</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Brian Mader</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The aim of this course is to introduce non-science students to the biological mechanisms involved with sustainable practices. This course introduces ecological principles and conservation biology as they relate to human impacts on biodiversity and sustainability. Students will gain an understanding of current environmental issues and sustainable practices, with a specific focus on sustainability projects/Living Campus at Dawson College.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Fundamentals of Biology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Suzanne Kunicki</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The aim of this course is to introduce non-science students to some fundamental principles in the field of Biology. To do so, the topics of anatomy and physiology, genetics, biodiversity, ecology, and evolution will be studied.  In addition, students will learn about the scientific method and how it can be used to distinguish between science and the science fiction that is often found in the media.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">101-BZE-05</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">General Biology II</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">9 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joel Rubin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is required for students entering biology or the health sciences at university. Topics in cell chemistry, cell structure and function, major metabolic processes, and introductory molecular genetics will be covered. Examples of regulation by nervous and hormonal control mechanisms will be examined to highlight the relationship between structure and function. Laboratory exercises make use of computerized data collection techniques, and are used to complement appropriate lecture material.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.23</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.22</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.22</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joel Rubin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is required for students entering biology or the health sciences at university.
