Various documentary and narrative approaches will be explored. Students have access to DSLR cameras, sound recording and lighting equipment, for both in class and home use.  The department's labs have up-to-date computers and software for in-class and evening work sessions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">530-921-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Animation Atelier</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Dipti Gupta</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Animators breathe life into inanimate characters and make them come alive on screen. This course introduces several traditional/2D animation and experimental techniques to the students. Students learn key terminology and practice production techniques to create fluid action. Through interactive exercises, students explore squash, stretch and other actions with characters. The students are introduced to a series of short animation techniques and exercises that finally culminate to a short animated film production by the end of the term.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">530-923-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Communications Design and Practice</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">George Alexander Milton</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">How effectively does communication reach its intended recipient? How are effective strategies devised and put into practice? This course provides students with the opportunity to apply various modalities and tools of communication, enabling them to understand and make use of both traditional analogue and digital media and online tools for enhancing communication with a globally and socially distributed audience. Among other possibilities, students will engage in the production and evaluation of a social network, a piece of digital art, a performance piece, or a media campaign.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">530-924-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Media Development and Production</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Terryll Loffler</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">A well-made video is the tip of a submerged organizational iceberg.  This course permits students to produce elaborate projects with an emphasis on organization and management. Course activities include: pitch sessions, workshops, technical exercises, group-project development, auditions, tests and on-going analysis of student work. Students have extended access to the department's up-to-date production facilities for use both in and outside of class.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Terryll Loffler</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">A well-made video is the tip of a submerged organizational iceberg. Students have extended access to the department's up-to-date production facilities for use both in and outside of class.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">530-925-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Cinema and Communications: Selected Topics</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jesse Klein</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will closely examine an issue or practice of social and cultural significance in the realm of cinema and/or communications. In the first semester, students will become familiar with linear measurements and measuring units and with the concept of leveling and elevation. They will learn the theory and do the practical exercises related to these topics. Furthermore, they will be working in teams, using the surveying instruments, establishing their work area, planning the work, and using the appropriate methods to obtain results that must be presented in a specific notebook according to professional standards.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 9:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:30 AM - 1:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Caroline Harvey</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is an introduction to Field Surveying. In the first semester, students will become familiar with linear measurements and measuring units and with the concept of leveling and elevation. They will learn the theory and do the practical exercises related to these topics. Furthermore, they will be working in teams, using the surveying instruments, establishing their work area, planning the work, and using the appropriate methods to obtain results that must be presented in a specific notebook according to professional standards.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 9:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:30 PM - 4:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Caroline Harvey</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is an introduction to Field Surveying. Students will identify and asses the environmental impacts that arise from various engineering projects, and will plan and carry out environmental impact studies. This course deals with environmental regulations; atmospheric emissions; global warming and greenhouse effects: acid rain; global climate change; effects of pollution on ecological systems.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sofia Babarutsi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The objective of this course is to introduce and demonstrate to the students the major environmental concerns and to propose environmental measures for pollution protection. Students will identify and asses the environmental impacts that arise from various engineering projects, and will plan and carry out environmental impact studies. This course deals with environmental regulations; atmospheric emissions; global warming and greenhouse effects: acid rain; global climate change; effects of pollution on ecological systems.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">221-375-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Municipal Engineering I</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sofia Babarutsi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to introduce and demonstrate to the students the technical design of infrastructure projects such as drinking water purification plants and water distribution systems. It introduces to the students the basic principles of hydraulics as applied to the design, analysis, and operation of water distribution systems. It shall familiarize the students with the environmental laws, regulations and directives for water to protect public health. As well, the students will examine strategies that increase the water efficiency in cities to minimize the environmental impact on natural water resources.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">-2H.27</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sofia Babarutsi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to introduce and demonstrate to the students the technical design of infrastructure projects such as drinking water purification plants and water distribution systems. It introduces to the students the basic principles of hydraulics as applied to the design, analysis, and operation of water distribution systems. It shall familiarize the students with the environmental laws, regulations and directives for water to protect public health. 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Montreal Area</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">332-115-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Greco-Roman Tradition</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jiri Tucker</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course aims to give the student an overview of the major periods and achievements of the Greco-Roman civilization, with special emphasis on the reading of literature in translation. The student is made aware of the originality of the Greco-Roman achievement and the debt owed to it by subsequent Western civilization. A criterion in the choice of texts for study is the influence they have exercised on the later Western tradition. For the purpose of this survey, Greco-Roman antiquity will be divided into six periods. From each period are drawn writings that are representative of the major forms of literature of the ancient world.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Liberal Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Community Recreation Leadership Training</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">391-101-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Recreation Leadership 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Lara Falquero, Simeon Pompey</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This introductory course deals with the planning, developing and leading of recreation activities. Students participate in a wide range of sports, socio-cultural and outdoor activities. The concepts of inheritance, polymorphism, data abstraction and programming to interfaces are used to design software. Students are introduced to software version control and effective team collaboration.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.24</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Daniel Pomerantz</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course will enhance the students knowledge of object-oriented programming and Java to produce stand-alone applications employing reusable objects, data structures and the Java collections framework. The concepts of inheritance, polymorphism, data abstraction and programming to interfaces are used to design software. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">420-540-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Data Communications and Networking</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Victor Manuel Ponce Diaz</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to familiarize the student with modern data communications theory, concepts, and terminology, including the various communications media and protocols used to transmit and share information over various types of networks. Students will acquire sufficient knowledge of networks to be able to operate comfortably as programmers in a network environment. Students will define and implement applications that make use of data exchange services. The services will use TCP/IP sockets programs that the students will implement to demonstrate an understanding of the underlying protocols of the Internet.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carlton Davis</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to familiarize the student with modern data communications theory, concepts, and terminology, including the various communications media and protocols used to transmit and share information over various types of networks. Students will acquire sufficient knowledge of networks to be able to operate comfortably as programmers in a network environment. Students will define and implement applications that make use of data exchange services. The services will use TCP/IP sockets programs that the students will implement to demonstrate an understanding of the underlying protocols of the Internet.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">420-902-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Web Design</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">4 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Chaviva Lifson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will provide the student with the skills to design and develop an effective Web site. Issues of page layout, navigation, aesthetics, colour, typography, readability, graphics, multimedia, interactivity, and animation will be addressed. The student will also learn to perform critiques of existing Web sites based on design principles, functionality, and audience needs. Upon completion of this course, the student will be able to: Understand the major steps involved in planning and creating a Web site; State the objectives of a proposed Web site and the requirements of its target audience; Identify the main design elements of a Web page; Understand how copyright applies to content published on the Internet; Use text, graphics, audio and video effectively in a Web page; Devise multiple strategies for laying out Web pages; Create consistent and easy-to-use site navigation; Test the web site on the local development system and deploy to the cloud.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Business Management Marketing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.18</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.16</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Chaviva Lifson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will provide the student with the skills to design and develop an effective Web site. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">420-BWC-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Computer Science</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">4 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Computers</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Chaviva Lifson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">You will gain a historical appreciation of the evolution and development of computers and will acquire and demonstrate a basic knowledge of computer concepts. You will be able to illustrate the diversity of systems and will learn to recognize the impact of computers through the direct investigation of software. The MS Word processor and Excel spreadsheet will be described and examined. The relationship between computers and networks will be explored with regard to their impact on society. Security, privacy and computer ethics will be examined in the course readings and discussed in class. You will produce a 750-word paper, based on individual research, exploring one of the topics covered in the course.   **Any Science student (First Choice, Health, Pure and Applied, Environmental, ESP, DSP, etc) planning to take Introduction to Computer Programming in Engineering Science (360-420-DW) as a Science option must not take any Computer Science complementary course such as 420-BWC or 420-BXC.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.18</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Computers</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jean-Claude Desrosiers</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">You will gain a historical appreciation of the evolution and development of computers and will acquire and demonstrate a basic knowledge of computer concepts. The student will also learn to perform critiques of existing Web sites based on design principles, functionality, and audience needs.     **Any Science student (First Choice, Health, Pure and Applied, Environmental, ESP, DSP, etc) planning to take Introduction to Computer Programming in Engineering Science (360-420-DW) as a Science option must not take any Computer Science complementary course such as 420-BWC or 420-BXC.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.16</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Web Site Creation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Lei Lopez</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will provide the student with the skills to design and develop an effective Web site. Issues of page layout, navigation, aesthetics, color, typography, readability, graphics, multimedia, interactivity, and animation will be addressed. The student will also learn to perform critiques of existing Web sites based on design principles, functionality, and audience needs.     **Any Science student (First Choice, Health, Pure and Applied, Environmental, ESP, DSP, etc) planning to take Introduction to Computer Programming in Engineering Science (360-420-DW) as a Science option must not take any Computer Science complementary course such as 420-BWC or 420-BXC.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Contemporary Issues</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">365-BWP-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Contemporary Issues Set 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">4 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Gender Matters</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kim Simard</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is an interdisciplinary course that will bring together womens/gender studies students and faculty, as well as students from the larger college community, into a learning space that will explore how gender shapes our individual lives, societal institutions, and the systems of privilege and exploitation that mark our world. Following an interdisciplinary approach with guest speakers from both inside and outside the college most weeks, students will be introduced to ideas, images, challenges, research, and voices that engage with how gender permeates and intersects with other hierarchies and structures in our society. Themes covered in the course can include intersectionality; gender and the justice system; gender, health, and climate change; kinship; queer representation in cinema; gender and psychology; gender, art, and representation; and women on war and peace.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 7:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Peace 365</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ivan Freud</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Peace 365 is an innovative complementary course that seeks to contribute to peace in the world by exploring peace-building from a cross-disciplinary perspective. Locally and globally, conflicts divide people and communities, and undermine well-being and happiness. Students in this course will learn to identify and understand the fundamental conflicts of humanity. The specific roles of several disciplines in understanding peace will be recognized and explored in panels, lectures, and coursework. Students will acquire and practice strategies for creating peace in their relationships with self, community, and nature. Individually and collectively, we will develop the confidence to apply these strategies in the real world, with the aim of creating a more peaceful world for all.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.45</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Designing Solutions For A Better World (INTENSIVE)</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Timothy Miller</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will allow students to explore a contemporary issue of their choice and examine the beginning phases of solving the issue. Through this weeklong intensive course, students will follow various methodologies, mainly, Design Thinking, to help them problem solve. Students will work in groups to research the contemporary issue by understanding the target market and the macro environment. Students will narrow their research to clearly define the contemporary issue and come to a concrete problem statement. Students will then ideate a multitude of possible solutions and prototype these solutions. Students will end the week with testing which solution is most viable and appropriate to solve their contemporary issue.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Tuesday, January 10, 2023</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Aug 24, 2022</td><td data-label="End Date">Aug 24, 2022</td><td data-label="Time">6:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Learning Perspectives</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jennifer Savard</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course will explore Western approaches to education with a respect for Indigenous approaches, informed by the Mikmaq concept, Two Eyed Seeing. Mikmaq Elder Albert Marshall refers to Two-Eyed Seeing as learning to see from one eye with the strengths of, or the best in, the Indigenous knowledges and ways of knowing, and from the other eye learning to see with the strengths of, or the best in, the Western (mainstream) knowledges and ways of knowing, but, most importantly, learning to use both these eyes together, for the benefit of all. This course will explore Two-Eyed Seeing through cross-disciplinary and cross systems learning activities in media, arts, and social sciences activities in the classroom and on the land. In the process students will gain a greater understanding of their unique learning styles and perspectives, and explore multiple strategies for becoming self-determined learners and advocates to achieve their goals at college and beyond.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Journeys</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.18</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.18</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">365-BXP-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Contemporary Issues Set 2</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Personal Finances and Money Management (INTENSIVE)</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rosario Lo Raso</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will examine contemporary issues within the context of personal finance and money management. This course will examine the process of managing ones finances in order to achieve personal financial goals. Within this framework students will be exposed to topics including: rent vs own for a primary residence, automobile lease vs purchase, RRSPs, TFSAs, and planning for ones financial objectives. The course is geared towards the general student population.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Thursday, September 15, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Aug 24, 2022</td><td data-label="End Date">Aug 24, 2022</td><td data-label="Time">6:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Personal Finances and Money Management</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Fabienne Cyrius</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Creative Arts</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-113-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Arts and Culture</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Natalie Kepka</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This required course will introduce students to the Arts and Culture profile from a multi-disciplinary perspective so as to situate the study of artistic expression within the evolution of art and society.  Focusing on at least three key periods or movements, and through a series of case studies, students will consider such questions as: who produces and has produced art and why; the value and purpose different societies and different artists have attached to artistic creation; the impact of social and technological development on art and of art on society; the distinction between high and popular culture; the impact of mass culture; and the multiple perspectives from which an artistic creation can be studied and appreciated.  Students will go on at least two outings so as to encourage their exploration of different modes of artistic expression. They will also have an assignment built around a visit to the library and library research.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Natalie Kepka</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This required course will introduce students to the Arts and Culture profile from a multi-disciplinary perspective so as to situate the study of artistic expression within the evolution of art and society.  Focusing on at least three key periods or movements, and through a series of case studies, students will consider such questions as: who produces and has produced art and why; the value and purpose different societies and different artists have attached to artistic creation; the impact of social and technological development on art and of art on society; the distinction between high and popular culture; the impact of mass culture; and the multiple perspectives from which an artistic creation can be studied and appreciated.  Students will go on at least two outings so as to encourage their exploration of different modes of artistic expression. They will also have an assignment built around a visit to the library and library research.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-120-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Culture Through the Ages</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nathalie Lachance</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course Culture Through the Ages will explore one or more selected theme(s) related to spoken and/or written language and its relationship to culture. The close relationship between language and human cultural achievement will be examined from its emergence to the present, with particular emphasis on significant periods in the story of human civilization (e.g. the Classical era, the Middle Ages, the Renaissance, etc.). The goal of the course is to provide students with a broad understanding of these significant periods, such that will allow them to identify key characteristics, people and events, and understand how they shaped our linguistic and cultural heritage. The thematic approach will help students evaluate and compare rather than simply memorize.  Possible learning activities may include class discussions on selected readings, individual and group work, interactive activities, field trips, guest speakers etc.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Languages</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Christina Chough</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course Culture Through the Ages will explore one or more selected theme(s) related to spoken and/or written language and its relationship to culture. The close relationship between language and human cultural achievement will be examined from its emergence to the present, with particular emphasis on significant periods in the story of human civilization (e.g. the Classical era, the Middle Ages, the Renaissance, etc.). The goal of the course is to provide students with a broad understanding of these significant periods, such that will allow them to identify key characteristics, people and events, and understand how they shaped our linguistic and cultural heritage.
