The close relationship between language and human cultural achievement will be examined from its emergence to the present, with particular emphasis on significant periods in the story of human civilization (e.g. the Classical era, the Middle Ages, the Renaissance, etc.). The goal of the course is to provide students with a broad understanding of these significant periods, such that will allow them to identify key characteristics, people and events, and understand how they shaped our linguistic and cultural heritage. The thematic approach will help students evaluate and compare rather than simply memorize.  Possible learning activities may include class discussions on selected readings, individual and group work, interactive activities, field trips, guest speakers etc.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Languages</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-302-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Lost in Translation</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Leila Roiter</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Lost in Translation is a third semester required course in the Languages Profile, whose goal is to help students adopt a critical and analytical approach to language and culture. The course will explore the social and cultural meaning of a variety of signs (words, images, cultural practices) and the processes by which individuals and /or social groups interpret them. Students will be encouraged to review many of their own assumptions in relation to language and culture and to analyze the role their own experience plays in understanding the experience of others. Class activities may include selected readings, response papers, class discussions and debates, audio-visual presentations, individual and group work, guest speakers, field trips, etc.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Languages</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Leila Roiter</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Lost in Translation is a third semester required course in the Languages Profile, whose goal is to help students adopt a critical and analytical approach to language and culture. The course will explore the social and cultural meaning of a variety of signs (words, images, cultural practices) and the processes by which individuals and /or social groups interpret them. Students will be encouraged to review many of their own assumptions in relation to language and culture and to analyze the role their own experience plays in understanding the experience of others. Class activities may include selected readings, response papers, class discussions and debates, audio-visual presentations, individual and group work, guest speakers, field trips, etc.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Languages</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-303-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Linguistics</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Helen Karanika</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will introduce Languages Profile students to the fascinating field of Linguistics by focusing on key elements of the structure and use of human language. Students will learn how speech sounds are produced and why individual languages sound distinct (i.e. Phonetics and Phonology), how words are constructed from smaller meaningful parts (i.e. Morphology), how sentences are organized out of their constituents (i.e. Syntax), and how humans use all of the above effortlessly all the time to interpret and convey meaning (i.e. Semantics)! Students will have the opportunity to apply linguistic concepts to a research topic of their choice, expanding and deepening their understanding of the field. Possible class activities include selected readings, class discussions, individual and group work, audio-visual presentations, guest speakers, etc.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Languages</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Helen Karanika</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will introduce Languages Profile students to the fascinating field of Linguistics by focusing on key elements of the structure and use of human language. Students will learn how speech sounds are produced and why individual languages sound distinct (i.e. Phonetics and Phonology), how words are constructed from smaller meaningful parts (i.e. Morphology), how sentences are organized out of their constituents (i.e. Syntax), and how humans use all of the above effortlessly all the time to interpret and convey meaning (i.e. Semantics)! Students will have the opportunity to apply linguistic concepts to a research topic of their choice, expanding and deepening their understanding of the field. Possible class activities include selected readings, class discussions, individual and group work, audio-visual presentations, guest speakers, etc.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Languages</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-498-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Integrating Activity (IA)</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Ramona Ramlochand, Stephane Calce</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Integrating Activity is the required fourth-term course in the Arts and Culture Profile. Students in this course will have the opportunity to evaluate and build upon their learning experiences in the ALC Program.  The Integrating Activity course will be approached as a project-driven workshop requiring students to consolidate the knowledge they've acquired studying in the various disciplines associated with the Arts and Culture profile at Dawson College. The project may be executed in the medium/media of the students' choice, including (but not limited to) creative writing, (such as poems, plays, short stories, etc.) and visual art forms (drawing, painting, collage, sculpture, film, photography, dance, etc.). The course will culminate in a gala or related event presented by the graduating class that serves as the Arts and Culture Profiles major contribution to the Arts, Literature and Communications spring festival.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-913-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Culture Without Borders</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joy Cheng Yu Lin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">As its name indicates, the course Culture Without Borders will explore and celebrate cultural and linguistic diversity in todays world.  Through selected topics related to language and culture, students will be able to recognize and appreciate trends, characteristics, and forms of expression that distinguish different societies and shed light on how they view the world. Describing, contextualizing and comparing such diverse cultural expressions will allow us to appreciate each others differences, but, most importantly, highlight what we all have in common.  Possible class activities include selected readings, class discussions, individual and group work, audio-visual presentations, guest speakers, etc.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Giorgia Sottanelli</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">As its name indicates, the course Culture Without Borders will explore and celebrate cultural and linguistic diversity in todays world.  Through selected topics related to language and culture, students will be able to recognize and appreciate trends, characteristics, and forms of expression that distinguish different societies and shed light on how they view the world. Describing, contextualizing and comparing such diverse cultural expressions will allow us to appreciate each others differences, but, most importantly, highlight what we all have in common.  Possible class activities include selected readings, class discussions, individual and group work, audio-visual presentations, guest speakers, etc.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-941-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Journalism: Writing News Stories</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Andrea Strudensky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Writing News Stories, offered in the first term and open to all students in the ALC program, can be taken as a stand-alone course, or as part of the Journalism minor along with Writing Feature Stories, Journalism and the Web, and Ethics of Journalism. In the Writing News Stories course, students will learn how to write leads and headlines, how to organize and develop stories, and how to quote and attribute. They will also practice interview techniques, and class activities may simulate those one would encounter in a newsroom. Assignments can include critiquing news articles from various newspapers and the writing of news stories focused on the Dawson community, as well as local, provincial, federal, and world news, depending on the focus of the instructor. Students will be encouraged to submit assignments to the school newspaper, The Plant.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Adam Bright</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Writing News Stories, offered in the first term and open to all students in the ALC program, can be taken as a stand-alone course, or as part of the Journalism minor along with Writing Feature Stories, Journalism and the Web, and Ethics of Journalism. In the Writing News Stories course, students will learn how to write leads and headlines, how to organize and develop stories, and how to quote and attribute. They will also practice interview techniques, and class activities may simulate those one would encounter in a newsroom. Assignments can include critiquing news articles from various newspapers and the writing of news stories focused on the Dawson community, as well as local, provincial, federal, and world news, depending on the focus of the instructor. Students will be encouraged to submit assignments to the school newspaper, The Plant.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-942-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Journalism: Writing Feature Articles</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Gilbert</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Writing Feature Articles, offered in the second term and open to all students in the ALC program, can be taken as a stand-alone course or as part of the Journalism minor, along with Writing News Stories, Journalism and the Web, and The Ethics of Journalism. This course will introduce students to feature writing as a genre of journalism. Students will learn the step-by-step process for writing features, including generating ideas, crafting the pitch, researching, interviewing, structuring, and polishing the final draft. Students will analyze published feature articles for structure and style, acquire specific writing skills through in-class exercises, and develop their own feature articles. Class time will consist of journalistic writing exercises, peer-editing, story meetings, discussion, and other activities. Students will be encouraged to submit their feature articles to the school newspaper, The Plant, and to other publications.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">502-944-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Journalism and the Web</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Filtz</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students will learn how to conceive, produce and publish creative forms of news stories using a variety of electronic media such as blogs, social media platforms, discussion forums, newsgroups, citizen journalism, podcasts, email chains, messaging apps, and newsletters.  The course may include a collective thematic as well as an individual orientation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Diagnostic Imaging</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">142-B11-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Medical Imaging - Fundamentals of the Profession</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Arnulfo Montiel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces the student to the organizational structure of the College, the program and the health care system as a whole. It will explore the responsibility of the Medical Imaging Department and the function of the members of the health care team found in each of the disciplines in the hospital settings. The function and professional responsibilities of the technologist are explained in the context of all the regulatory bodies that govern the profession. The student is introduced to some essential information on the nature of radiation, radiation protection and basic principles in the management of medical imaging information.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Arnulfo Montiel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces the student to the organizational structure of the College, the program and the health care system as a whole. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">142-B12-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Radiographic Anatomy</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mary Ann Hoskin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course aims to provide the students with the essential anatomical references, surface landmarks, skeletal anatomy, and anatomical and radiological terminology used in medical imaging. The skeletal anatomy of the human body is described in detail from a three-dimensional perspective. Differentiation between radiographic projection, position, and view is demonstrated. The students evaluate the displacement and spatial relationships of anatomical structures in relation to movements of the body and the X-ray source. Radiographic image analysis is also introduced as the students identify key anatomical structures of the various regions of the skeletal system on basic images.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mary Ann Hoskin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course aims to provide the students with the essential anatomical references, surface landmarks, skeletal anatomy, and anatomical and radiological terminology used in medical imaging. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">142-B14-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Image Formation and Management Systems</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Arnulfo Montiel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The purpose of this course is to give the student a basic comprehension of the applied principles of the radiological image formation process, computer systems used in the medical field, mainly radiology computer systems used for image display data storage, and transmission. In addition, the course will address quality assurance procedures, federal and provincial laws, and regulations in preserving the integrity and confidentiality of patient information.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 11:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Arnulfo Montiel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The purpose of this course is to give the student a basic comprehension of the applied principles of the radiological image formation process, computer systems used in the medical field, mainly radiology computer systems used for image display data storage, and transmission. In addition, the course will address quality assurance procedures, federal and provincial laws, and regulations in preserving the integrity and confidentiality of patient information.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 11:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Arnulfo Montiel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The purpose of this course is to give the student a basic comprehension of the applied principles of the radiological image formation process, computer systems used in the medical field, mainly radiology computer systems used for image display data storage, and transmission. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">142-B31-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Computed Tomography 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Lavoie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, the student will develop an understanding of CT scan hardware components and basic software applications in order to create cross-sectional images of the human body. The student will learn how to identify cross sectional anatomy of the brain, spine, and extremities and identify which pathologies of these anatomical areas require CT scan imaging. The student will be able to analyze the images for diagnostic quality and adapt imaging parameters to the patient and the pathology. This course will prepare the student to administer patient care throughout the examination and work in a multidisciplinary team. Radiation protection methods and quality control will be emphasized throughout the course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.6</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Lavoie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, the student will develop an understanding of CT scan hardware components and basic software applications in order to create cross-sectional images of the human body. Magnetic Resonance (MR) systems, physical principles, instrumentation, and coil technology will be analyzed in terms of bio-effects and exam optimization. Operator-controlled parameters, pulse sequences, and examination protocols in the clinical environment will be examined. Brain and spine cross-sectional anatomy images, pathology, and applications will be emphasized. Properties of the gadolinium-based contrast agent will be described. The importance of patient screening and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) safety will also be introduced. The student will successfully demonstrate by simulation routine MRI brain and vertebral column applications and procedures.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.19</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Christina Papathanasopoulos</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Magnetic Resonance Imaging 1 will introduce the students to the fundamental technical principles and methodology of MRI. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">142-B33-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Radiographic Procedures 3</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Heidi Gumbley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course focuses on the theory required to perform basic imaging procedures of the spine, bony thorax, and chest radiography. This course provides the students with an opportunity to practice skills required to perform basic imaging procedures of the spine, bony thorax, and chest. The course also familiarizes students with related aspects of patient care and imaging criteria. Emphasis is placed on routine positioning as well as an introduction to problem-solving for atypical patients and their specific physical, emotional, and psychological needs. The student will also become familiar with the pathological process and identify pathologies of the spine, bony thorax, and chest on images.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Heidi Gumbley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course focuses on the theory required to perform basic imaging procedures of the spine, bony thorax, and chest radiography. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">142-B34-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Radiobiology and Protection</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Lavoie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this 45-hour course, students integrate previously acquired concepts of radiation physics and human biology with their study of the biological effects and methods of measurement of ionizing radiation to gain an in-depth understanding of the fundamental principles of radiation protection in diagnostic radiology. The international, federal, provincial, institutional, and professional responsibilities toward diligent radiation safety practices and their impact on the patient, general public, co-workers, and themselves as future technologists are emphasized throughout the course. The knowledge and abilities acquired from this course, as well as those acquired from other courses in the program, allow students to advocate for and apply effective radiation safety measures in the laboratory and clinical environments.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Lavoie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this 45-hour course, students integrate previously acquired concepts of radiation physics and human biology with their study of the biological effects and methods of measurement of ionizing radiation to gain an in-depth understanding of the fundamental principles of radiation protection in diagnostic radiology. The international, federal, provincial, institutional, and professional responsibilities toward diligent radiation safety practices and their impact on the patient, general public, co-workers, and themselves as future technologists are emphasized throughout the course. The knowledge and abilities acquired from this course, as well as those acquired from other courses in the program, allow students to advocate for and apply effective radiation safety measures in the laboratory and clinical environments.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">142-B35-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Imaging and Interventional Procedures 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mary Ann Hoskin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students explore Radioscopy, Mammography, Mobile Radiography, as well as Bone Mineral Density.  Mammography: Students will gain an understanding of the equipment, positioning, and procedures needed to perform mammograms. The students will learn to provide care for the patients, look for signs of diseases such as lesions, lumps, calcifications, cysts, and more.  The role of quality assurance in this modality will be explored.  Mobile: Students will learn how to perform radiographic/radioscopic procedures in the operating room, emergency room, and other areas of the hospital on adult and pediatric patients.  BMD: Students will learn positioning, clinical applications, interpretation of results, clinical procedures, safety, quality assurance, and operation of bone densitometry equipment on adult and pediatric patients.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:30 PM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">3:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">3:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.6</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mary Ann Hoskin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students explore Radioscopy, Mammography, Mobile Radiography, as well as Bone Mineral Density.  Mammography: Students will gain an understanding of the equipment, positioning, and procedures needed to perform mammograms. The students will learn to provide care for the patients, look for signs of diseases such as lesions, lumps, calcifications, cysts, and more.  The role of quality assurance in this modality will be explored.  Mobile: Students will learn how to perform radiographic/radioscopic procedures in the operating room, emergency room, and other areas of the hospital on adult and pediatric patients.  BMD: Students will learn positioning, clinical applications, interpretation of results, clinical procedures, safety, quality assurance, and operation of bone densitometry equipment on adult and pediatric patients.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.6</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:30 PM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mary Ann Hoskin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students explore Radioscopy, Mammography, Mobile Radiography, as well as Bone Mineral Density. Clinical Practice 2 is a 225-hour intensive clinical course that takes place in the affiliated hospitals and clinics. Students are prepared to perform, as entry level technologists, all the tasks associated with radiological examinations of all the anatomical systems of the human body, for all age groups. Students are also prepared to participate, at an entry level, in the specialized imaging modalities of angiography, computed tomography, bone mineral densitometry, and magnetic resonance imaging.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">COMPRESSED: August 19 to October 21, 2022  9:00-12:00, 13:00-16:00  HOSPITAL</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Thursday, September 1, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Aug 18, 2022</td><td data-label="End Date">Oct 21, 2022</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Hospital</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Drama</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">560-591-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Acting for Animation</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Edward Hughes</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course provides an introduction to the craft of acting including improvisation, script analysis, building a character and scene study, through a series of practical exercises and discussion. Students learn the fundamentals of acting essential to the enhancement of the animators' skills, developing the relationship between the idiosyncrasies of a character and their behaviour in movement and speech.  Examples will also be drawn from live-action and animated films. Topics include: distinctive gestures and expressions, inner life of a character, development of character thought, how to plan the performance and arc of a character's journey.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">3D Animation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Edward Hughes</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course provides an introduction to the craft of acting including improvisation, script analysis, building a character and scene study, through a series of practical exercises and discussion. Students learn the fundamentals of acting essential to the enhancement of the animators' skills, developing the relationship between the idiosyncrasies of a character and their behaviour in movement and speech.  Examples will also be drawn from live-action and animated films. Topics include: distinctive gestures and expressions, inner life of a character, development of character thought, how to plan the performance and arc of a character's journey.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">3D Animation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">560-913-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Concept and Craft in Theatre</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Stephane Zarov</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will be exposed to major movements and innovators of modern and contemporary theatre, the impact of their theories on the culture and their influence on theatre craft areas such as acting, playwriting, design, and directing. The actors tools will be developed through a variety of approaches to scene work with exercises to extend the vocal, physical and creative potential. Students will also attend a theatrical performance with the focus of relating this field assignment to the themes in the course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">560-916-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Performance Workshop</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Edward Hughes</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students will continue to develop fundamental acting skills while collaborating in mounting a theatre piece. The process will begin with auditions and casting, and proceed through script analysis and rehearsals to presentation. In addition, according to the identified needs and special requirements of the script, as well as areas of interest and aptitudes demonstrated by individual class members, students will take on technical and other production-related tasks and responsibilities in key areas such as design, handling of props/costumes, dramaturgy, assistant direction, videography, stage management and publicity. This course will culminate in a studio performance.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Economics</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">383-101-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Economics</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">25 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ahmad Banki</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to economic systems, the great economic thinkers, the different schools of thought, and the basic concepts and theories of economics. Students will become familiar with introductory tools, methods, and models of economic analysis, as well as recognize their limitations. Applying different perspectives and relying on current and historical data, the course exposes students to Canada's and Quebec's major macroeconomic problems such as unemployment, recessions, inflation, and the public debt. Students will learn how governments can use fiscal, monetary, and trade policies to reduce domestic economic problems. The course prepares students to critically assess government economic policies and economic information in the news media.  For students in the Social Science program, this course is a pre-requisite to all other Economics courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michel Mayer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to economic systems, the great economic thinkers, the different schools of thought, and the basic concepts and theories of economics. Students will become familiar with introductory tools, methods, and models of economic analysis, as well as recognize their limitations. Applying different perspectives and relying on current and historical data, the course exposes students to Canada's and Quebec's major macroeconomic problems such as unemployment, recessions, inflation, and the public debt. Students will learn how governments can use fiscal, monetary, and trade policies to reduce domestic economic problems. The course prepares students to critically assess government economic policies and economic information in the news media.  For students in the Social Science program, this course is a pre-requisite to all other Economics courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Environmental Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carlo Catino</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to economic systems, the great economic thinkers, the different schools of thought, and the basic concepts and theories of economics. Students will become familiar with introductory tools, methods, and models of economic analysis, as well as recognize their limitations. Applying different perspectives and relying on current and historical data, the course exposes students to Canada's and Quebec's major macroeconomic problems such as unemployment, recessions, inflation, and the public debt. Students will learn how governments can use fiscal, monetary, and trade policies to reduce domestic economic problems. The course prepares students to critically assess government economic policies and economic information in the news media.  For students in the Social Science program, this course is a pre-requisite to all other Economics courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Commerce</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00017</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Menouar Boulahfa</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to economic systems, the great economic thinkers, the different schools of thought, and the basic concepts and theories of economics. The assumptions of each theory will be clearly stated and the weaknesses of the theory pointed out. Topics covered in the course include market structures, supply and demand, consumer behaviour, behaviour of the firm, production and costs, and the determination of equilibrium price and output in different markets. Using concepts and theories, students will analyze how individuals and companies react to government interventions in the market such as subsidies, minimum wages, and price controls.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line.
