The assumptions of each theory will be clearly stated and the weaknesses of the theory pointed out. Topics covered in the course include market structures, supply and demand, consumer behaviour, behaviour of the firm, production and costs, and the determination of equilibrium price and output in different markets. Using concepts and theories, students will analyze how individuals and companies react to government interventions in the market such as subsidies, minimum wages, and price controls.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">383-213-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Economics and Environment</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Jean Duclos Alegue Feugo, Lisa Di Marzo</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The environment provides a number of resources that are essential for production, distribution, and consumption, and is in turn affected by these economic activities. The course focuses on the interaction between the environment and economic activities, and assesses the causes of the various types of air, land, and water pollution. It presents the economic concepts, theories, and models that explain environmental pollution. The course examines the effectiveness of the various approaches to pollution abatement adopted by governments. It also discusses the causes of global warning and the various multilateral attempts to control the emission of green houses gases.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Environmental Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">383-218-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Economic Analysis</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Economics of Happiness</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Worku Aberra</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to one of the newest fields of economics: The Economics of Happiness. Economics is concerned about the well-being of individuals. An individuals well-being depends on his or her income, consumption, employment status, health status, social relationships, and the environment in which the individual lives. The course analyzes the economic variables that affect subjective well-being. It assesses the weaknesses of the GDP figures in measuring economic well-being and presents alternative measures for assessing economic well-being. Students will become familiar with the problems of measuring, comparing, and aggregating subjective well-being across individuals. Students will become familiar with the economic concepts, theories, tools, and approaches that are used in evaluating economic well-being. Students will critically examine the consumerism of happiness promoted by certain approaches to happiness.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">383-302-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Macroeconomics</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michel Mayer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to theories that explain the determination and evolution of macroeconomic aggregates such as GDP, the rate of unemployment, the rate of inflation, and the rate of interest. It discusses macroeconomic theories and models, specifies their assumptions, presents their applications, and identifies their limitations. Relying on historical and current data, the course examines the changes that have taken place in the Canadian economy over the last few decades. Topics discussed in the course include economic cycles, sources of economic growth, fiscal and monetary policies. Students will learn how different schools of thought, namely the Classical and Keynesian schools, approach these topics. The course enables students to apply macroeconomic concepts to specific cases and to critically assess economic policies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ahmad Banki</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to theories that explain the determination and evolution of macroeconomic aggregates such as GDP, the rate of unemployment, the rate of inflation, and the rate of interest. It discusses macroeconomic theories and models, specifies their assumptions, presents their applications, and identifies their limitations. Relying on historical and current data, the course examines the changes that have taken place in the Canadian economy over the last few decades. Topics discussed in the course include economic cycles, sources of economic growth, fiscal and monetary policies. Students will learn how different schools of thought, namely the Classical and Keynesian schools, approach these topics. The course enables students to apply macroeconomic concepts to specific cases and to critically assess economic policies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section is compatible and available for International Business Studies.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">383-324-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">The Stock Market</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Economics of Investment</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carlo Catino</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to how to assess investment management and the stock market. It applies various investment theories to assesses asset allocation and to examines the relationship between risk and rates of return. Students learn concepts and theories that explain how investors allocate their wealth among financial assets, real estate, and commodities. Students will understand how macroeconomic variables such as the rate of economic growth, the rate of unemployment, the rate of inflation, and the rate of interest, as well how macroeconomic variables such as profits, productivity, and sales growth can be applied to understand the stock market. Students will understand the construction of stock market indices such the Dow Jones Industrial Average, the NASDAQ, the TSX, the Standard and Poor 500. The course enables students to apply various concepts, theories, and models to understand stock listings and to critically assess financial information.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">383-401-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Advanced Studies in Economics</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Charles-Albert Ramsay</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course examines current economic issues, selected by the instructor teaching the course. The issues can be provincial, national, or international in scope.  The course presents students with the theoretical discussions, the empirical evidence, and the policy options pertaining to these issues. While discussing these issues, students will understand how economics explains economic problems as well as how it influences policy decisions.  Students are required to submit a project at the end of the term. The project provides students with the opportunity to apply the appropriate economic model, theory, and concepts in analyzing a clearly defined problem. In undertaking the project, students will learn how to write an economics paper, including how to summarize, present, and analyze quantitative data, a skill that is important for university-level studies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.24</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.24</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">383-901-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Basics of Macroeconomics</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Jean Duclos Alegue Feugo, Lisa Di Marzo</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to economic systems, the great economic thinkers, the different schools of thought, and the basic concepts and theories of economics. Students will become familiar with the introductory tools, methods, and models of economic analysis, as well as recognize their limitations. Applying different perspectives and relying on current and historical data, the course exposes students to major macroeconomic problems of Canada and Quebec, such as, unemployment, recessions, inflation, and the public debt. Students will learn how governments can use fiscal, monetary, and trade policies to reduce domestic economic problems. The course prepares students to critically assess government economic policies and economic information in the news media. The course teaches students how the macroeconomic environment affects the firm and how to use macroeconomic data for management purposes.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Business Administration</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Jean Duclos Alegue Feugo, John Sagar</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course introduces students to economic systems, the great economic thinkers, the different schools of thought, and the basic concepts and theories of economics. The principles and structure of IP addressing and the fundamentals of Ethernet concepts, media, and operations are introduced to provide a foundation for the curriculum. By the end of the course, students will be able to build simple Local Area Networks (LANs), perform basic configurations for routers and switches, and implement IP addressing schemes.  Designing, calculating, and applying subnet masks and addresses to fulfill given requirements in both IPv4 and IPv6 networks will be covered.  Practical laboratory experiments will be performed with a variety of networking components and software.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:30 PM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.22</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.22</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Boris Lorkovic</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces the architecture, structure, functions, components, and models of the Internet and other computer networks. Students are eligible to write the English Exit test once they have completed at least 2 of English 101, 102, 103 and are in the process of taking the third.</p>
<p>Therefore, we recommend that students take 101, 102 and 103 before BXE.</p>
<p>If the last English course you passed was 603-001, your next course is 603-101-MQ Writing English.</p></div></div><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-101-MQ</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">I.C.E.</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">85 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Writing English</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mary Gossage</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Designed for students whose first language is not English and who have been educated in English for less than five years, this course introduces students to the study of literature at the college-level, with special emphasis on vocabulary-building, correct sentence structure, grammar, idiom and critical thinking. There will be a strong emphasis on basic textual interpretation and the construction of the literary essay through written and spoken critical responses to specific texts.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to College English: Monsters, Madness, and Mourning: A Critical Introduction to Horror Cinema</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>18001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Jay Shea, Julian Nemeth</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Along our journey into taboo territory, well test the genres limits (are psychological thrillers horror?). Well discuss the range of emotions horror films evoke and the human experiences they speak toincluding loss, mourning, and trauma. With the guidance of philosophy, literature, and our own experience, well navigate the nightmares and make sense of films including Night of the Living Dead (1968), Mulholland Drive(2001), and The Atlantics (2019). Join usif you dare!</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Reflections</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to College English: The Story of Us: The Oral Tradition and Digital Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>18002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Gray Miles, Rebecca Million</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Long before we had books we had stories, and through legends, myths, plays, songs and nursery rhymes  even jokes and gossip  culture was passed from one generation to another and travelled over long distances and joined distant peoples in symbol and imagination  all by voice, memory, and performance. This is the Oral Tradition, ancient and powerful. The Oral Tradition didnt die out when writing or the digital age came along. It transformed, yes, but it still lives and works on us and has power in our world today. Think of urban legends and conspiracy theories, memes, trends and slang. Now culture passes around in story form on digital platforms; online games, social media, chat groups and forums. What are the connections between ancient Oral Traditions and contemporary Digital Culture? Can we trace a through-line back through the ages to today? If stories are how we learn about ourselves, what are we to think of our own culture based on the stories we tell about us right now?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Reflections</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 6:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-102-MQ</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Literary Genres</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">21 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kayla Fanning</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Three 20th Century Novels</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Roy Cartlidge</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students will read three novels that launched the careers of their respective authors: Ernest Hemingway (1899-1961), Jack Kerouac (1922-1969) and Alan Sillitoe (1928-2010). These novels have little in common ? thematically, stylistically or otherwise. They are the stories of three very different, but equally memorable characters in very different places at very specific points in the twentieth century: Paris in the 20s, various locales across the USA in the 40s and 50s, and an English industrial town in the early 60s. Students and the instructor will explore their reactions to these works through readings, classroom discussion, recordings and video, and attempt to give clear expression to these reactions in our in-class and homework assignments.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Short Story: From Poe to Postcards</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">George Slobodzian</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course we will be focusing on the short story, from 19th century examples of the form to contemporary experiments, thus plotting the evolution and permutations of the genre. Students will learn to apply a familiarity with the genre's formal characteristics and conventions to their own readings, literary analyses, and creative efforts.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Poetry</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Susan Elmslie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course, an introduction to poetry, will develop students understanding and appreciation of poetic genres, forms, movements, devices, and strategies. The study of prosody, rhyme, and figurative language will be featured. We will practice close reading, learning to recognize devices and structures, with the aim of writing clearly and thoughtfully about poetry in a critical essay. Learning activities may include reading or reciting poetry aloud, completing poetry-writing exercises, listening and responding to lectures and class discussions, participating in group discussions, and writing informal or formal (analytical) responses to poems. Numerous literary terms will be introduced or reviewed to help students gain some of the vocabulary of critical writing and improve their comprehension and analysis of poetry. Students will produce and present a Favourite Poem Video, commenting on their favourite poem and may be asked to attend an online poetry reading during the semester."</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Short Story</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Trevor Rouse</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">What exactly is essential about short stories? Taking the above quote as a starting point, this course will approach the short story as a generic form distinct  not merely in lengthfrom other forms of prose narrative: the novel, the tale, the fable, and the parable. We will briefly consider some of these other genres, but most readings for the course will be short stories, from Edgar Allan Poe's seminal works of genre fiction to more recent works by Etgar Keret and Amy Hempel. Several critical methods and perspectives will be employed, but the major emphasis will be on the formal characteristics of literature and close textual analysis. Class meetings will include brief lectures but will emphasize group and class discussions. Participation is essential. Students will also refine critical thinking skills and essay-writing techniques through regular group writing assignments.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00006</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Hannah Rahimi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Shakespeare's Comedies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00007</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matt Bergbusch</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course will explore the genre of dramatic comedy through William Shakespeares plays As You Like It, Twelfth Night and The Tempest. We will use Shakespeares plays to come to a broad understanding of the key aspects of dramatic comedy. We will explore the plays in the historical context of their production/staging and with a view to understanding their enduring appeal. Historical background texts and other useful sources will be made available online and in class. In this course we will read and discuss literature critically, closely, and sensitively and learn to develop effective spoken and written arguments. The course will include instruction in the revision and editing of texts.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Shakespeare's Comedies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00008</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matt Bergbusch</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course will explore the genre of dramatic comedy through William Shakespeares plays As You Like It, Twelfth Night and The Tempest. We will use Shakespeares plays to come to a broad understanding of the key aspects of dramatic comedy. We will explore the plays in the historical context of their production/staging and with a view to understanding their enduring appeal. Historical background texts and other useful sources will be made available online and in class. In this course we will read and discuss literature critically, closely, and sensitively and learn to develop effective spoken and written arguments. The course will include instruction in the revision and editing of texts.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Graphic Memoir by Women</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00009</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Merrianne Couture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In the last several decades, the comics genre has emerged as an important mode of storytelling. Increasingly, it is becoming known as an effective tool for both social commentary and self-representation, political and otherwise. In this course, students will explore one very particular subset: autobiographical narratives produced by women which combine visuals and text. Analyzing both of these literary components, students will develop a critical approach to studies in graphic memoir. This course is cross-listed with the Women's Gender Studies Profile.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Detective Fiction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00010</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rita Much</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">After a brief consideration of the origins of detective fiction in Godwin, Poe and Collins, students will evaluate the contribution of the short story form of this sub-genre by a close reading of A.C. Doyles The Adventure of the Speckled Band and short stories by G.K. Chesterton and D.L. Sayers. The main focus is the period between the two World Wars, the Golden Age of the classic English detective novel. The class will pay particularly close attention to the influence of the Detection Club, founded in England in 1928, on the conventions of detective fiction in the work of Agatha Christie. Theoretical work will consist primarily of lectures and class discussion based on the primary texts as well as relevant secondary sources. Practical work will include film analysis and written analyses of the material, including revisions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">American Prose and Drama</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00011</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anna-Maria Kibaris</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course we study American literature from the end of the nineteenth century until the present. While the main focus of the course is on prose fiction and drama by authors such as Jewett, Crane, Hemingway, Fitzgerald, Parker, Faulkner, and Williams, we distinguish the main characteristics of the shifts in sensibility from realism through modernism to contemporary literature. We also discuss the historical, philosophical, and literary background out of which the texts arise, examining, where relevant, gender-related issues. The course includes a close look at the idea of the American dream. There will be lectures, class and group discussions, quizzes, and, occasionally, the presentation of audio-visual material.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Poetry</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00012</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Susan Elmslie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course, an introduction to poetry, will develop students understanding and appreciation of poetic genres, forms, movements, devices, and strategies. The study of prosody, rhyme, and figurative language will be featured. We will practice close reading, learning to recognize devices and structures, with the aim of writing clearly and thoughtfully about poetry in a critical essay. Learning activities may include reading or reciting poetry aloud, completing poetry-writing exercises, listening and responding to lectures and class discussions, participating in group discussions, and writing informal or formal (analytical) responses to poems. Numerous literary terms will be introduced or reviewed to help students gain some of the vocabulary of critical writing and improve their comprehension and analysis of poetry. Students will produce and present a Favourite Poem Video, commenting on their favourite poem and may be asked to attend an online poetry reading during the semester."</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Modern and Contemporary Drama</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00013</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Louise Arsenault</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to introduce the student of drama to various plays from the modern and contemporary periods. The five plays that are studied vary each term and are chosen for their challenging topics, innovative structures and compelling language. This course is meant to encourage the reading of plays out loud in the classroom as well as a group presentation of a scene in lieu of an oral. The student will develop a deeper understanding and respect for the genre and hopefully develop a continued interest in theatregoing. The attendance at a play and its written review are mandatory.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00014</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Justin Pfefferle</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Poetry</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00015</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kathryn Hall</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is an introduction to poetry and so, in this course, we will read a variety of poems (mainly contemporary poems). By reading closely and asking questions about the poems and how they work, we will learn about word choice, figurative language and various poetic structures. Through class discussions and different types of written assignments (both creative and analytic), we will look at how the poems function: how language is at work in the poems and the effects it creates. We will read poems by: Emily Dickinson, Elizabeth Bishop, Ezra Pound, Adrienne Rich, Seamus Heaney and T.S. Eliot (just to name a few). We will also read a few short essays by poets writing about poetry and take an in-depth look at Canadian poetry by examining the work of 10 contemporary Canadian poets. No advance knowledge of poetry is required  just your curiosity and willingness to pose questions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Domestic Gothic</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00016</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Luke Reid</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Recent cultural production has looked to the Gothic genre as a means of representing the haunting traumas of oppression and marginalization. More often than not, these depictions concentrate their horror within the space of the family home. This course contextualizes this resurgence, examining the genre of Domestic Gothic. It interprets the notion of domesticity broadly  from the familial to the architectural, from homemaking to house building. Using the figure of the haunted house, this course tracks the Gothic genres evolving treatment of evil from an abstraction that, in the words of Henry James, cannot be explained away to a psychological effect deeply situated within history, culture, and systems of power. Texts include Jamess The Turn of the Screw (1898), Shirley Jacksons We Have Always Lived in the Castle (1962), Alison Bechdels tragicomic Fun Home (2006), Carmen Maria Machados memoir In the Dream House (2019), and Jordan Peeles film Us (2019).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Drama</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00017</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Gelineau</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students will explore the language of drama, analyzing the complex of theatrical signs--language, movement, gesture, setting, music, etc.--that dramatists use to create and tell stories. Students will learn to identify, compare and contrast the dramatic conventions of different periods and societies with particular reference to the origins of ritual drama in ancient Greece and to the theatre of Shakespeare. And we will survey Western drama up until the twentieth century.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Medieval Literature in Translation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00018</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Andrew Williams</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores the poetics of important Anglo Saxon and Middle English texts (in Modern English translations) using the philosophical writing of Boethius as a central underpinning.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">What is a Classic?</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00019</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michelle Syba</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">A survey of the classic short story, from Anton Chekhov to Yiyun Li, and including Flannery OConnor, Franz Kafka, Gabriel Garcia Marquez, and Alice Munro. We will read with an eye to understanding these stories more deeply (their characterization, narrative point of view, plot, imagery, tone, etc.) and why they have endured. Class time will include short lectures, discussions, individual writing exercises, and group exercises.     We will also ask a set of philosophical questions about classic art, inspired by Italo Calvinos book Why Read the Classics? How can a work written over a hundred years ago still speak to us today? In what ways is it strange to us, and in what ways familiar? Moreover, why read challenging, complex texts  with characters who are not always relatable, endings that are neither happy nor offer closure, and meanings that are ambiguous? What is the difference between classic art and contemporary entertainment? Can a classic be entertaining?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">What is a Classic?</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00020</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michelle Syba</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">A survey of the classic short story, from Anton Chekhov to Yiyun Li, and including Flannery OConnor, Franz Kafka, Gabriel Garcia Marquez, and Alice Munro. We will read with an eye to understanding these stories more deeply (their characterization, narrative point of view, plot, imagery, tone, etc.) and why they have endured. Class time will include short lectures, discussions, individual writing exercises, and group exercises.     We will also ask a set of philosophical questions about classic art, inspired by Italo Calvinos book Why Read the Classics? How can a work written over a hundred years ago still speak to us today? In what ways is it strange to us, and in what ways familiar? Moreover, why read challenging, complex texts  with characters who are not always relatable, endings that are neither happy nor offer closure, and meanings that are ambiguous? What is the difference between classic art and contemporary entertainment? Can a classic be entertaining?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Medieval Literature in Translation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00022</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Andrew Williams</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores the poetics of important Anglo Saxon and Middle English texts (in Modern English translations) using the philosophical writing of Boethius as a central underpinning.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-103-MQ</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Literary Themes</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">47 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Dangerous Desire: Love and Loss</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Francis Lardy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the nature of desire, particularly its influence on interpersonal relationships. Through analysis of short fiction, a full-length play, and a novella, we investigate motivations for (self-) destructive behaviors and choices. Course texts address matters of the heart and the body while exploring issues of obsession, jealousy, heartache, and fulfillment (or lack thereof). We start by asking general questions, such as: Do we control our desires or do our desires control us? We progress to more precise interrogations, such as: What compels people to maintain damaging relationships despite the consequences? Major evaluations include two essays, a test, and a creative presentation. Short writing assignments are regularly part of homework.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Heroism and Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Seyed-Gholamreza Shafieesabet</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course emphasizes the study and consideration of the literary, cultural and human significance of selected works of the Western and non-Western literary traditions from Antiquity to Modern period. An important goal of the class is to promote an understanding of the works in their cultural, historical and political contexts and of the enduring human values which unite the different literary traditions. As we move through the texts, we will pay particular attention to the question of the kinds of values that these foundational works were meant to instill in their audiences. We will consider what, for each culture, constitutes the exemplary person, often known as the hero or heroine, and what each work has to say about human nature and ethics, gender issues, and the Other. The format of the course will include class discussions, short lectures, group work, writing assignments and essays, reading quizzes, and film screening.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Twentieth Century Themes</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Simon Fanning</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course we will discuss a number of North American short stories and short novels that deal with ordinary people trying to adapt to the radically changing twentieth-century world. We will give particular attention to the ways in which wars and other large-scale historical events affect the lives of individuals. In addition to close thematic analysis of the texts, we will examine some of the characteristics of literary modernism and post-modernism. Throughout the course, our primary goals will be to improve critical reading, thinking and writing skills, and to develop the appreciation and understanding of serious literature. Students will continue to learn to write a formal essay of literary criticism.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Nurturing Nature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Wendy Thatcher</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we will be examining literature that focuses on the environment and the complicated relationship between humans and the natural world. While nature has sustained humanity, we have not given back, leading to the current environmental crises we are experiencing. Most of the works we read will be from the twentieth century onwards, but we will take the occasional look back in time. We will be reading some poems, short stories and a novel, but most of  the readings will be selections from memoirs and essays. The writers  people like Alice Munro, T.C. Boyle, Richard Powers, Hope Jahren, Roger Deakin, Bill McGibben, J. B. MacKinnon, Elizabeth Kolbert, Jonathan Franzen  will take us through gardens, dirt, trees, forests, waterways and wild places. We will be introduced to travellers, conservationists, ecoterrorists, loggers and people like ourselves. Through these landscapes, literary and real, we will come to understand some of the major challenges facing the earth today.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Book Club</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00006</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mary Gossage</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course looks at selected works of contemporary literature from a student-directed perspective. Although students will examine texts with reference to their cultural contexts and thematic developments, the goal of the course is to have open discussions of the books based on the students initial responses and thoughts about the readings, and then have them work toward an understanding of the books as literature. Major assessments will be based on critical analyses of the texts.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Gender Issues in Drama</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00007</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Louise Arsenault</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the various gender issues that are addressed in four or five highly acclaimed plays that challenge gender role constructs and stereotyping. Plays will be selected from the modern and contemporary periods and students will be encouraged to explore their historical and social contexts. The class will read aloud from the plays and act out a scene in a group. Attendance at a relevant play is mandatory as well as a written review of it. Personal opinions and insights are welcome.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Gender Issues in Drama</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00008</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Louise Arsenault</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the various gender issues that are addressed in four or five highly acclaimed plays that challenge gender role constructs and stereotyping. Plays will be selected from the modern and contemporary periods and students will be encouraged to explore their historical and social contexts. The class will read aloud from the plays and act out a scene in a group. Attendance at a relevant play is mandatory as well as a written review of it. Personal opinions and insights are welcome.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Themes in Family Drama</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00009</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alyson Grant</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Family Dramas will explore contemporary plays written in or translated into English that have as their primary focus family in all its various forms. Dark themes such as the corrosive effect of secrets, the potentially suffocating burden of parental expectations and the soul-destroying effect of emotional and physical violence will mingle alongside the more hopeful, though often quite complicated, themes of loving parental sacrifice and familial affection. Playwrights are from different countries and are of varying races, ethnicities and genders so we can appreciate differences and overlapping concerns. All of these plays are critically acclaimed and have enjoyed long runs and, in some cases, adaptation into film.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Immigrant Experience</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00010</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matthew Taylor</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines short fiction, essays, and novels depicting the experiences of immigrants. We will focus on contemporary fiction exploring the lives of newcomers from places such as Latin America, South-East Asia, and the former Soviet Union. The course pursues questions of cultural adaptation, generational conflict, marginalization, racism, and the abiding dreams of political freedom and economic success in a new society.
