It necessarily involves some consideration of the history of immigration patterns  the forces that have induced or obliged people to migrate, the nature of the societies they leave behind, the policies and attitudes that greet them in their new countries.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">21st Century Novels and Contexts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00012</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Louise Slater</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores literature that speaks to our current moment in one or more ways. Possible themes include Indigenous experience in Canada; imagined futures, as explored through speculative fiction; Black American experience; and contemporary women's experience. Novels (long-form fiction) have the gift of allowing us a deep experience of situations and identities we might not otherwise access. To develop our understanding of these themes, we will read three 21st-century novels alongside a range of non-fiction material that will contextualize the subjects we'll explore.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Time Travel in Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00013</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Todd Starke-Meyerring</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Although predominantly considered a theme of science fiction, the concept of time travel has popularity beyond the issues surrounding the scientific possibility of travelling in time itself, made theoretically possible by Einstein. Since time affects everyone, a wide spectrum of authors has explored what it might mean to travel in time, be it to the past or the future. But time travel is far more than simply about poking into the past to change something undesirable or popping into the future to have a peek at where things might be going. The device of travelling in time is more about the present and how we feel about it, usually that something could  and sometimes should  be changed to make life better. This course will explore how time travel  and time itself  is explored in a variety of texts.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Quest Pattern</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00014</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marie-Thrse Blanc</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The quest pattern, also known as the heros journey, details the passage or crossing of a storys protagonist from the moment he/she leaves a certain comfort zone to a return to victory and normalcy after facing a number of harrowing obstacles. In this class, as we ponder the universality of this pattern, we will look closely at thematic passages from childhood to young adulthood, from single to married life, and from innocence to knowledge and transgression.The class format will consist of brief lectures, followed by work done in class.The goal of the course will be to develop student analytical autonomy. Films will occasionally be shown. Throughout the semester, a great deal of emphasis will be placed on the writing of sound and intelligent essays and on proper citation rules. Strong note-taking skills are vital to this class.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Indigenous Women's Literature from Turtle Island</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00015</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Stunden</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00016</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jennifer Savard</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Canada and the First World War</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00017</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Zachary Abram</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Cultural memory of the First World War is predicated as much on the literature it inspired as anything else. In fact, most young people are introduced to the First World War in English class rather than history class. These literary works are then interwoven into state-sanctioned efforts to memorialize the war dead. Nowhere is this phenomenon more evident than in Canada. Few Canadians cannot recite at least some of John McCraes In Flanders Fields. Canadian war literature tackles issues related to war that are often elided by the official narrative. Canadian writers reimagine the Canadian soldier as a site of skepticism and resistance, affording Canadians the opportunity to claim counter-histories, reject master narratives and find new originary myths. Through reading emblematic texts, students will examine how Canadian identity has been formed in close identification with war. Students will examine the historical contexts of these works, their themes, and their formal features.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Glimpses, Insights, Epiphanies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00018</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Tijana Stojkovic</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">All literature and even art in general can be seen as the result of a moment of revelation, a glimpse into a truth, or an insight into a reality that goes beyond our default comprehension. Art can equally be understood as an effort to recreate and explore these moments in different fictional scenarios. In this course, well be identifying, analyzing, and interpreting such epiphanies  explicit or implicit  as phenomena often arising from inconspicuous ordinary situations in a number of short stories, poems, and films. What are the contexts in which these epiphanies occur, and what do they bring to the text as a whole? Are they positive, negative or even absent moments? Whose epiphany is it: the authors/narrators/speakers, the characters, or the readers? These are some of the questions well discuss in this course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Writing the Great War</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00019</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Noah Weisberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will examine how the First World War (1914-1918) transformed Western society and played a significant role in shaping the culture, values, and geography of the modern world.  After a brief introduction to the concept of warfare, students will move to an examination of the Great Wars literatureprimarily poetry and excerpts from memoirs. The class will focus on how soldiers responded to the physical and psychological trauma of the War but will also examine writing by non-combatants to see how the effects of the War were felt well beyond its battlefields.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Gender and Utopia</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00020</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Neil Hartlen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we will read various science fiction texts (novels and short stories) that share the goal of analyzing and re-imagining the role of gender in society. We will take as a starting point the feminist assumption that gender is socially constructed and that the meaning of sexual differences is never natural, essential, or self-evident, but is always a matter of (social) interpretation.  We will be particularly interested in later writers of science fiction who, beginning in the 1960s, interrogate and challenge the male dominance of earlier examples of the genre and their (mis)representations of women and other sexual nonconformists including gay or bisexual men and women and transgender individuals. Key authors include Ursula K. LeGuin, James Tiptree Jr., Joanna Russ, Samuel R. Delany, Octavia Butler, and John Varley, among others.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Words of Love</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00021</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Brent Devine</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Love is among the most malleable words in the English language. Love is at once universal and transcendent, and deeply personal and historical. This course, through the investigation of a range of texts from different genres and historical periods, asks you to contemplate diverse literary depictions of love and its consequences. We will consider the medieval romance and courtly love, the fairy tale and true love, and queer literature and forbidden love. Students will be encouraged to understand, appreciate, and analyze works of literature, and to write critically about these works by developing their own ideas in the form of a literary essay. Class time will be divided between lectures, class discussion, group work, and in-class assignments. Assignments include reading quizzes, in-class brainstorming and writing exercises, homework (esp. reading), and major essays.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Reading, Writing, Eating</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00022</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Tracie Gemmel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students will explore food in relation to literature, politics, and culture. Through reading both fiction and non-fiction, students will engage in discussion, produce several written texts and participate in small group and independent projects. Although most of the emphasis in this course is on studying texts that explore the vast and universal theme of food, students will enjoy films, guest lecturers, a restaurant visit and the sampling of various foods in class. Classes will consist of short lectures, discussions, graded group work, e-journals, reading quizzes, short writing exercises, oral presentations with peer feedback and process essay writing (multiple drafts, peer-editing).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Postcolonial Literature: Caribbean</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00023</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Frank Runcie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The arrival of European colonists in 1492 changed the course of history in the Caribbean. This fascinating region was divided among the great powers and populated by people from Africa and Asia. All of them have contributed to the culture of the region. This course looks at the ideas and the art of diverse islands and peoples responding in essays, poems, novels and plays to foreign domination, enslavement, formation of national identity, and articulating new visions of personhood. Among the authors whose work, both theoretical and creative, will be studied are Aim Csaire, Frantz Fanon, Jamaica Kincaid, Derek Walcott, Louise Bennett, Linton Kwesi Johnson, Kerry Young, and Austin Clarke. This course is cross-listed in Dawsons Women and Gender Studies Certificate.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Postcolonial Literature: Caribbean</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00024</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Frank Runcie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The arrival of European colonists in 1492 changed the course of history in the Caribbean. This fascinating region was divided among the great powers and populated by people from Africa and Asia. All of them have contributed to the culture of the region. This course looks at the ideas and the art of diverse islands and peoples responding in essays, poems, novels and plays to foreign domination, enslavement, formation of national identity, and articulating new visions of personhood. Among the authors whose work, both theoretical and creative, will be studied are Aim Csaire, Frantz Fanon, Jamaica Kincaid, Derek Walcott, Louise Bennett, Linton Kwesi Johnson, Kerry Young, and Austin Clarke. This course is cross-listed in Dawsons Women and Gender Studies Certificate.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Woman with Agency</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00025</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gina Granter</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">To have agency is to be able to exert some control over ones life: to be an active subject rather than a passive object. Women in patriarchal societies have historically been denied equal agency to that of men, and still face barriers to fully realizing their goals for themselves, particularly if other factors such as racial prejudice, ableism, ageism, class discrimination, homophobia and/or transphobia are involved. In this course students will explore a number of themes related to women asserting their agency, often against norms of their times and places. Novels, essays, and short stories by a diversity of women and nonbinary authors (included because they were assigned female at birth and discuss that experience) are among the course's required works. The relevance of historical and cultural context will be  considered  in  our  discussion  of  works  in  the  course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Migrations</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00026</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Gilbert</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores migration and its repercussions as a recurring theme in contemporary literature. Course readings revolve around ideas of displacement, refuge, alienation, re-invention and belonging, as well as home, family, tradition and language. The course involves brief lectures and discussion in the online forum. Students will write about the class texts and do a final assignment inspired by their own life experience.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Being Blitzed: British Literature of World War II</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00028</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Robin E. Feenstra</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores the various representations of the Second World War in British literature. While the focus falls on the literature of the blitz, many other thematic preoccupations (borders, propaganda, patriotism, love, the domestic and the foreign, the public and the private, reconstruction and damage) emerge that speak to the wide variety of writings and perspectives on the war. The Second World War was the most momentous set of events in the twentieth century, and inspired a wealth of writing: factual and fictional texts that explore an immense range of experiences. In addition to conveying different aspects of the wars actuality, these works also raise important questions about the relation of art to life, the relationship between individual and the nation or state, the role of women in otherwise male-dominated narratives of war, and about politics and culture. Course readings include poems, stories, essays, radio broadcasts, documentary and feature films, and a short novel.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Climate Narratives</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00029</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Catherine Payne</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The overall goal of this course is to examine human relations and climate. We will start by examining climate change in relation to the fossil fuel industry with a focus on their climate ramifications (in the present and in future imaginaries). We will continue by exploring the link between evolving societies, and fossil fuel consumption. In essence, the course is concerned with mapping the links between ecosystems and (several possible) future(s) of humanity. Texts will include a combination of literature, poetry, film, nonfiction, speculative fiction and science fiction.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Climate Narratives</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00030</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Catherine Payne</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The overall goal of this course is to examine human relations and climate. We will start by examining climate change in relation to the fossil fuel industry with a focus on their climate ramifications (in the present and in future imaginaries). We will continue by exploring the link between evolving societies, and fossil fuel consumption. In essence, the course is concerned with mapping the links between ecosystems and (several possible) future(s) of humanity. Texts will include a combination of literature, poetry, film, nonfiction, speculative fiction and science fiction.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Abandoned Children in Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00031</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Louisa Anne Hadley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we will consider a range of texts that feature abandoned children, including traditional fairy stories, excerpts from Victorian novels, various short stories and a contemporary novel. Through close analysis of these literary works, students will recognize the recurring motifs and conventions in the depiction of abandoned children. We will consider how different types of abandonment - such as physical, emotional, temporary, permanent - impact the position and purpose of the abandoned child in these texts. In particular, we will explore how authors use the abandoned child to critique social issues such as racism, poverty, and parenting. Students will also develop skills in literary analysis by examining techniques and devices used by authors, such as plot, setting, conflict, characterization, symbolism, metaphor, and various other common elements in literature.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">A Meaningful Life</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00032</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Chad Lowe</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we will read works that ask the question: what constitutes a meaningful life?  The answers to this question found in literary history are, of course, varied, and given the diversity of human experience, even asking the question itself can be problematic.  The texts we focus on will be discussed and analyzed using concepts from philosophy and psychology.  Possible authors covered in the course include George Eliot (Mary Ann Evans), Ivan Turgenev, Leo Tolstoy, Anton Chekhov, E. M. Forster, Graham Greene, Richard Yates, Richard Wright, Kazuo Ishiguro and Joan Didion.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Themes in Shakespeare</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00033</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Matt Bergbusch</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course will explore aspects of theme in Shakespeares As You Like It (comedy),Othello (tragedy) and The Tempest (romance). We will study the plays in the historical context of their production/staging and with a view to understanding their enduring appeal. Historical background texts and other useful sources will be made available online. In this course we will read and discuss literature critically, closely, and sensitively and learn to develop effective spoken and written arguments. The course will include instruction in the revision and editing of texts. All major assignments will adhere to MLA guidelines re. format, references, and presentation</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Liberal Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Lord of the Rings</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00034</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rebecca Million</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">J.R.R. Tolkiens masterpiece, The Lord of the Rings, has undeniably been an important influence on the imagination of readers worldwide. Its imagined world and its characters and story have been reproduced and embellished in visual art, music, poetry and on film.Tolkiens influence on the genre of Fantasy Literature is just as important. But far from being an escape from reality, we can see that these works, set in an imaginary realm and peopled by fantastic creatures, in fact deal with very real problems and ideas confronted by the 20th and 21st centuries: war, lust for power and its corrupting influence, abuse of the natural world, and the demand upon the individual to fight injustice and evil. By examining the genre of Fantasy Literature through this fundamental example, we will try to understand how fantasy reveals truths about the real world, and how it works as storytelling, connecting with readers at a deep level through the use of archetype and folklore.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.45</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Lord of the Rings</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00035</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rebecca Million</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">J.R.R. Tolkiens masterpiece, The Lord of the Rings, has undeniably been an important influence on the imagination of readers worldwide. Its imagined world and its characters and story have been reproduced and embellished in visual art, music, poetry and on film.Tolkiens influence on the genre of Fantasy Literature is just as important. But far from being an escape from reality, we can see that these works, set in an imaginary realm and peopled by fantastic creatures, in fact deal with very real problems and ideas confronted by the 20th and 21st centuries: war, lust for power and its corrupting influence, abuse of the natural world, and the demand upon the individual to fight injustice and evil. By examining the genre of Fantasy Literature through this fundamental example, we will try to understand how fantasy reveals truths about the real world, and how it works as storytelling, connecting with readers at a deep level through the use of archetype and folklore.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00036</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Charlotte Boatner-Doane</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00037</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Charlotte Boatner-Doane</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">A Meaningful Life</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00038</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Bohdan  Ladashevska, Chad Lowe, Laura Mimeault</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we will read works that ask the question: what constitutes a meaningful life?  The answers to this question found in literary history are, of course, varied, and given the diversity of human experience, even asking the question itself can be problematic.  The texts we focus on will be discussed and analyzed using concepts from philosophy and psychology.  Possible authors covered in the course include George Eliot (Mary Ann Evans), Ivan Turgenev, Leo Tolstoy, Anton Chekhov, E. M. Forster, Graham Greene, Richard Yates, Richard Wright, Kazuo Ishiguro and Joan Didion.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Confessional Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00039</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Shalon Nicole Noble</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the concept of confessional literature. The texts we will study are diverse, ranging from letters to poetry, canonical to experimental. They are all linked, however, by the core thematic content that runs through each of them: in a word, confession. We will discuss the nature of confession, but for a basic definition from which to start, confession means an outpouring of intimate expression, testifying to both personal trial and social unrest. Our course texts range in time from the early-19th century to the present. Each one is autobiographical in nature (sometimes obviously, sometimes less so) and documents personal struggles against the backdrop of a tumultuous social context. Throughout the course, well discuss the texts both as unique works of art in themselves as well as in the context of their creation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">More Human than Human</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00040</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alexander Flamenco</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Whether it is our search for purpose as a species, our search for meaning in existence, our search for intellectual supremacy, or our search for idealized bodies, we will examine how the authors in our syllabus unpack these overwhelming pursuits and critique what it means to create, what it means to be human, and in their most speculative moments, what it means to be more human than human. Classes will consist of lectures which will be our primary guide through our course material. Our lecture periods will significantly focus on unpacking the literature and films in our syllabus. We will also use open discussions, group exercises, and informal writing assignments to help move through our material.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">African Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00041</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Robert J Rose</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will examine a selection of African literature with the aim of learning about an often-neglected part of the world. We will read works of fiction, drama, poetry, and autobiography, from a range of authors, regions, and time periods, striving in our efforts to gain a clearer understanding of the history, geography, people, and politics of this vast continent. In our necessarily limited survey, we will read literature in translation (from Arabic, French, and Kiswahili), as well as works composed in English, paying due attention to the impact of European colonialism and to its lingering influence. In addition to reading the works of major and lesser-known writers, we will look at maps, watch documentaries, and generally embrace an open and interdisciplinary approach in our efforts to improve our knowledge of Africa and its literature.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Augustan Satire</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00042</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Gelineau</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will examine themes of the satirists of the Augustan period. Through an examination of the work of Swift, Wycherley, and Pope, we will see how and why these satirists reacted with moral outrage to the encroaching of what has become the modern world, with its love of individualism, democracy, business, and science. The course will limit itself to the genre of satire in the period; so the study of that genre and its history, as well as the study of the broader historical period and the cultural context these authors were writing in, will be our concern.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Metamorphoses in Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00043</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Liana Bellon</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Websters Dictionary defines metamorphosis as a transformation, as by magic or sorcery or as a marked change in appearance, character, condition, or function.  As we will see, writers and artists throughout the centuries have been fascinated by the theme of physical and psychological change. Beginning with the ancient Roman poet Ovids collection of poems, written in 1 C.E. and entitled the Metamorphoses, we will analyze how this recurring theme is explored in Shakespeares Othello, Shaws Pygmalion, Wildes The Picture of Dorian Gray, and Kafkas The Metamorphosis. Towards the end of term, we will read Neil LaButes play The Shape of Things, which is the culmination of our courses theme since it includes many references and allusions to the transformations explored in the works above.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Metamorphoses in Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00044</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Liana Bellon</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Websters Dictionary defines metamorphosis as a transformation, as by magic or sorcery or as a marked change in appearance, character, condition, or function.  As we will see, writers and artists throughout the centuries have been fascinated by the theme of physical and psychological change. Beginning with the ancient Roman poet Ovids collection of poems, written in 1 C.E. and entitled the Metamorphoses, we will analyze how this recurring theme is explored in Shakespeares Othello, Shaws Pygmalion, Wildes The Picture of Dorian Gray, and Kafkas The Metamorphosis. Towards the end of term, we will read Neil LaButes play The Shape of Things, which is the culmination of our courses theme since it includes many references and allusions to the transformations explored in the works above.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Themes in Family Drama</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00045</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alyson Grant</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Family Dramas will explore contemporary plays written in or translated into English that have as their primary focus family in all its various forms. Dark themes such as the corrosive effect of secrets, the potentially suffocating burden of parental expectations and the soul-destroying effect of emotional and physical violence will mingle alongside the more hopeful, though often quite complicated, themes of loving parental sacrifice and familial affection. Playwrights are from different countries and are of varying races, ethnicities and genders so we can appreciate differences and overlapping concerns. All of these plays are critically acclaimed and have enjoyed long runs and, in some cases, adaptation into film.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00046</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Adam Bright</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Love Story</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00048</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Bassel Atallah</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines how different methods of storytelling represent romantic love and how such a representation is relevant to a larger society. In our treatment of the question of how love is represented in literature, we will focus on poems, plays, and stories written in different literary periods and take into consideration their cultural and historical contexts. Literary representations of issues such as idealness in love, false illusions of romance, obsessive desire, and anti-love will be explored.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">More Human than Human</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00049</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alexander Flamenco</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Whether it is our search for purpose as a species, our search for meaning in existence, our search for intellectual supremacy, or our search for idealized bodies, we will examine how the authors in our syllabus unpack these overwhelming pursuits and critique what it means to create, what it means to be human, and in their most speculative moments, what it means to be more human than human. Classes will consist of lectures which will be our primary guide through our course material. Our lecture periods will significantly focus on unpacking the literature and films in our syllabus. We will also use open discussions, group exercises, and informal writing assignments to help move through our material.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">African Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00050</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Robert J Rose</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will examine a selection of African literature with the aim of learning about an often-neglected part of the world. We will read works of fiction, drama, poetry, and autobiography, from a range of authors, regions, and time periods, striving in our efforts to gain a clearer understanding of the history, geography, people, and politics of this vast continent. In our necessarily limited survey, we will read literature in translation (from Arabic, French, and Kiswahili), as well as works composed in English, paying due attention to the impact of European colonialism and to its lingering influence. In addition to reading the works of major and lesser-known writers, we will look at maps, watch documentaries, and generally embrace an open and interdisciplinary approach in our efforts to improve our knowledge of Africa and its literature.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Heroism and Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00051</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Seyed-Gholamreza Shafieesabet</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course emphasizes the study and consideration of the literary, cultural and human significance of selected works of the Western and non-Western literary traditions from Antiquity to Modern period. An important goal of the class is to promote an understanding of the works in their cultural, historical and political contexts and of the enduring human values which unite the different literary traditions. As we move through the texts, we will pay particular attention to the question of the kinds of values that these foundational works were meant to instill in their audiences. We will consider what, for each culture, constitutes the exemplary person, often known as the hero or heroine, and what each work has to say about human nature and ethics, gender issues, and the Other. The format of the course will include class discussions, short lectures, group work, writing assignments and essays, reading quizzes, and film screening.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-113-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Literary Movements</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Literary Movements</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Amanda Cockburn</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Literary Movements is the required first-term course in the Literature Profile. It introduces students to the discipline of literary studies, and may focus on at least three key periods or movements in literature, such as medieval literature, Renaissance literature, Neoclassicism, Romanticism, Victorian literature, Modernism, and Postmodernism. The texts, presented chronologically, are situated in their historical and cultural context, with an emphasis on how the periods or movements emerged and developed. Teachers may also focus on how the texts intersect with other arts of the period, such as painting, music, photography, film, and architecture, in order to offer a full understanding of each historical moment. Students will write literary essays, including one comparative essay, with attention to, among other elements, identifying themes and literary techniques, formulating a thesis, incorporating reputable secondary sources, following MLA format, and editing carefully.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Literary Movements</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Amanda Cockburn</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Literary Movements is the required first-term course in the Literature Profile. It introduces students to the discipline of literary studies, and may focus on at least three key periods or movements in literature, such as medieval literature, Renaissance literature, Neoclassicism, Romanticism, Victorian literature, Modernism, and Postmodernism. The texts, presented chronologically, are situated in their historical and cultural context, with an emphasis on how the periods or movements emerged and developed. Teachers may also focus on how the texts intersect with other arts of the period, such as painting, music, photography, film, and architecture, in order to offer a full understanding of each historical moment. Students will write literary essays, including one comparative essay, with attention to, among other elements, identifying themes and literary techniques, formulating a thesis, incorporating reputable secondary sources, following MLA format, and editing carefully.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-312-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Literary Theory and Criticism</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Literary Theory and Criticism</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Luke Reid</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Literary Theory and Criticism is a required third-term course in the Literature Profile taught in tandem with The Novel as a co-requisite. This course reviews and questions many of the fundamental assumptions involved in the traditional study of literature, particularly formalist and historical approaches. The course will also consider more recent alternative approaches, such as deconstruction, psychoanalysis, Marxist criticism, and feminist, queer, and postcolonial studies. Students will write critical essays incorporating secondary sources related to either a particular approach or the critical history of a particular text. They may also read examples of professional criticism to trace the critical history of a novel, one that may also be studied in depth in the Novel course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-313-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">The Novel</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Novel</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Lorne Roberts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The Novel is a required third-term course in the Literature Profile taught in tandem with Literary Theory and Criticism as a co-requisite. The course may be presented as an overview of the novel's development, from the eighteenth-century to the present day, and may focus on representative novels from various literary periods. Students will analyze the novels' formal and literary elements as well as relationships to their social, cultural, political, and economic contexts. In coordination with Literary Theory and Criticism, the course also considers the novels connection to contemporary critical approaches.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, and Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-913-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">World Literature</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">World Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Gelineau</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">World Literature, offered in the first term of the Literature Profile and open to all students in the ALC program, is a study of works from different periods and cultures in history, offering the experience of reading across a broad base of literature and culture. In this course, students will be introduced to literary texts from various regions of the world, such as the Middle East (Southwest Asia), Europe, Africa, Asia, and the Americas. Texts will be studied chronologically, thematically, or by region.
