By studying a historical range of texts from various cultures and traditions, students will gain greater appreciation of the cultural diversity found in their own contemporary world and begin to recognize themes that unite our collective human experience. The course often includes an assignment that invites students to attend a cultural event or visit an exhibit. As well, students may be encouraged to write at least one essay that incorporates secondary research and literary analysis.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-916-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Creative Writing</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Creative Writing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jeffrey Gandell</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Creative Writing, offered in the third term and open to all students in the ALC program, gives students the opportunity to practice writing techniques used in a variety of genres. Students' sense of craft is developed through study, writing exercises, and critique. Other learning activities may include lectures, readings, discussions, presentations, editing practice, and evaluation or self-evaluation exercises. Through reading, listening, discussion, and practice, students gain awareness of the tools of creative writers and the skills to use them in their own work. To this end, the study of poetics constitutes part of the course. Carefully reading and responding to others work are also components of the course, so active participation in the class is required. Revising and editing are also emphasized. At the end of the course, students submit a portfolio of work developed during the term. Students will be encouraged to submit to Creations, the Literature Profile journal.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">603-BXE-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Applied Themes in English</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">18 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Food for Thought: Farm to Table</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Wendy Thatcher</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we are going to look at many aspects of food ? the good, the bad, and the ugly ? and to read some important contemporary texts about the implications of diet for humans and the planet. Readings will vary from short stories, essays, articles and to longer works; they will include selections from Lolis Eric Elie, Anthony Bourdain, Michael Pollan, T.C. Boyle, various chefs, Anna Lappe, Adam Gopnik, Sonia Faruqi and Sarah Elton, the latter three being Canadian. Some of the issues covered will be food choices, fast food vs. slow food, factory farms vs. the organic alternative, animal welfare, the local food movement, and food waste, amongst others. We will be looking at rhetorical strategies used by these writers and at ways to improve reading, writing and presentation skills. Student responses will include a personal essay, restaurant and film reviews, letters, an analytical essay, a presentation, culminating in a research essay of 1000 words related to your program.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Food for Thought: Farm to Table</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Wendy Thatcher</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we are going to look at many aspects of food ? the good, the bad, and the ugly ? and to read some important contemporary texts about the implications of diet for humans and the planet. Readings will vary from short stories, essays, articles and to longer works; they will include selections from Lolis Eric Elie, Anthony Bourdain, Michael Pollan, T.C. Boyle, various chefs, Anna Lappe, Adam Gopnik, Sonia Faruqi and Sarah Elton, the latter three being Canadian. Some of the issues covered will be food choices, fast food vs. slow food, factory farms vs. the organic alternative, animal welfare, the local food movement, and food waste, amongst others. We will be looking at rhetorical strategies used by these writers and at ways to improve reading, writing and presentation skills. Student responses will include a personal essay, restaurant and film reviews, letters, an analytical essay, a presentation, culminating in a research essay of 1000 words related to your program.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Critical Reading of Digital Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Lee Scott Young</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students will examine a number of the forces shaping society in the post-millennial cultural landscape, particularly the Internet and how it is affecting our notions of literacy, identity, knowledge, and our common cultural experience. The approach will be to examine how new forms of digital media are changing the way that we deliver, receive, create and experience text. Emphasis will be on social networking, blogging, and other forms of user-generated content, as well as journalism, advertising, privacy and copyright issues. Each student will do a research project that will ultimately be developed into an oral presentation and final paper and which will allow the student to explore how her or his specific discipline intersects with some of the main themes of the course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Women and Anger</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Louise Slater</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">While women's anger is not a new phenomenon, fiction and non-fiction books chronicling and channeling women's anger have been coming fast and furious in recent years. In Rage Becomes Her (2018), Soraya Chemaly notes that It is easier to criticize angry women than to ask the questions What is making you so angry? and What can we do about it? This course will explore these questions through selected recent fiction and non-fiction. The non-fiction texts provide data and report many women's lived experiences; the fictional texts offer sometimes satiric social commentary and/or revenge fantasy, but also serious consideration of Chemaly's second question: what to do in the face of these conditions? Heads up: some course material includes violence against women and girls, including rape, and violence against men, including dismemberment.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Non-Fiction Workshop</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00006</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Noah Weisberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Using Zinssers text as our guide, we will explore several areas of non-fiction: letters, writing about the arts, and travel writing. We will read some preeminent examples from each category, after which you will create your own. We will also use Zinssers book to improve your writing and reading skills to the point where you develop a fluency with the specialized vocabulary and conventions of non-fiction writing. Towards the end of the course, you will complete an oral presentation, and on the last day of classes, you will submit a major research paper that relates to your program of study.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.27</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Dystopian Fictions</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00007</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Robin E. Feenstra</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">A dystopia is an imaginary place or state in which things are unpleasant or bad, as from some form of deprivation, oppression, or terror. Keith Booker defines dystopian fiction as any imaginative view of a society that is oriented toward highlighting in a critical way negative or problematic features of that societys vision of the ideal. Our focus will be on the critical element of Bookers definitionin novels like 1984 and The Hunger Games, short stories like Harrison Bergeron and Caught in the Organ Draft, films like V for Vendetta and Gattacaand thus on extracting and analyzing the principal themes and sub-themes of these dystopian fictions: justice, freedom, individuality, morality, ethical behaviour, cognitive estrangement, power, surveillance, time, betrayal, the integrity of mind and body, children, the public and private, sexuality, religion, language, and history."</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Creativity</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00008</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Charlotte Hussey</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This cross-disciplinary course will provide the opportunity to explore what creativity means to you, as well as in your chosen field of practice. You will begin waking up your imagination via exercises designed by the visionary artist Alex Grey. You will record your explorations in a journal along with drawings, doodles, etc., as your creative process unfolds. At the heart of this hands-on, experiential course lies your own project; it can range from making a piece of art, to writing an academic essay, to drafting a work-place, problem-solving report. You will take your project through these stageswishing, choosing, starting, working, completing, and showing.You will learn strategies from psychotherapist Eric Maisel for overcoming such blocks as hungry mind, confused mind, chaotic mind, or shy mind anxiety. By semesters end, you will do an oral presentation and a written report on your work-in-progress, describing what you have learned about sustaining your own creative practice.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Non-Fiction Workshop</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00009</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Noah Weisberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Using Zinssers text as our guide, we will explore several areas of non-fiction: letters, writing about the arts, and travel writing. We will read some preeminent examples from each category, after which you will create your own. We will also use Zinssers book to improve your writing and reading skills to the point where you develop a fluency with the specialized vocabulary and conventions of non-fiction writing. Towards the end of the course, you will complete an oral presentation, and on the last day of classes, you will submit a major research paper that relates to your program of study.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Stranger than Fiction: Memoir and Autobiography</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00010</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Leanne D'Antoni</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will read the memoirs of David Sedaris, Haven Kimmel, Amber Ruffin, and Catherine Gildiner, to name a few. The class will consist of lectures, class discussions, oral presentations, and the revision and editing of students work. Students will analyze and respond to recurring themes found within memoir and autobiography. They will investigate what these authors lives reveal about love, loss, relationships, childhood, identity, and why their stories need to be told. Students will engage in close readings and will respond in class discussions and in their written work.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Stranger than Fiction: Memoir and Autobiography</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00011</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Leanne D'Antoni</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will read the memoirs of David Sedaris, Haven Kimmel, Amber Ruffin, and Catherine Gildiner, to name a few. The class will consist of lectures, class discussions, oral presentations, and the revision and editing of students work. Students will analyze and respond to recurring themes found within memoir and autobiography. They will investigate what these authors lives reveal about love, loss, relationships, childhood, identity, and why their stories need to be told. Students will engage in close readings and will respond in class discussions and in their written work.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Culture and Rhetoric</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00012</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Tavish McDonell</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines rhetorical strategies in contemporary culture over three units:      1.	Reading images and consumer culture. What rhetorical strategies can we identify in ads and public service announcements? How should we conceptualize the position of the individual within consumer culture? Students will write a rhetorical analysis of an ad/brand or PSA.   2.	Conspiracy theories and moral panics. What are conspiracy theories and moral panics and how do they spread? How can we promote media literacy and limit their impact? Students will write an essay refuting a text/news story/podcast/viral video promoting a false idea.   3.	Personality and the individual. What insights can be gained from personality testing and psychoanalysis? How can we read films as rhetoric about the development of the individual? Students will write an essay about their personality, their experience in their program, a goal and a film.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Applied Themes</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00013</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Andrea Strudensky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Reading the Classic Horror Film</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00014</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jay Shea</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will pursue the idea of classic horror as a way to designate films that articulate an important set of historical, psychological, philosophical, and political concerns. Divided up into a range of subgenres and special issues, this course will introduce students to the special versatility of horror as we explore the genres ongoing relevance and adaptability.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Reading the Classic Horror Film</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00015</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jay Shea</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will pursue the idea of classic horror as a way to designate films that articulate an important set of historical, psychological, philosophical, and political concerns. Feenstra</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">A dystopia is an imaginary place or state in which things are unpleasant or bad, as from some form of deprivation, oppression, or terror. Keith Booker defines dystopian fiction as any imaginative view of a society that is oriented toward highlighting in a critical way negative or problematic features of that societys vision of the ideal. Our focus will be on the critical element of Bookers definitionin novels like 1984 and The Hunger Games, short stories like Harrison Bergeron and Caught in the Organ Draft, films like V for Vendetta and Gattacaand thus on extracting and analyzing the principal themes and sub-themes of these dystopian fictions: justice, freedom, individuality, morality, ethical behaviour, cognitive estrangement, power, surveillance, time, betrayal, the integrity of mind and body, children, the public and private, sexuality, religion, language, and history."</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Women and Anger</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00019</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Louise Slater</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">While women's anger is not a new phenomenon, fiction and non-fiction books chronicling and channeling women's anger have been coming fast and furious in recent years. In Rage Becomes Her (2018), Soraya Chemaly notes that It is easier to criticize angry women than to ask the questions What is making you so angry? and What can we do about it? This course will explore these questions through selected recent fiction and non-fiction. The non-fiction texts provide data and report many women's lived experiences; the fictional texts offer sometimes satiric social commentary and/or revenge fantasy, but also serious consideration of Chemaly's second question: what to do in the face of these conditions? Heads up: some course material includes violence against women and girls, including rape, and violence against men, including dismemberment.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00020</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Felix Fuchs</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to help students to develop further their skills in reading, writing, speaking, and researching. Students will study and produce various forms of communication while strengthening their skills in argumentation. They will learn to recognize and use various rhetorical strategies in order to produce a program-specific major assignment.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>French</h2><div class="new dc_accordion open disciplineText  "><h2 class="dc_accordion-title highlighta"><a class="" style="" href="#important-information">Important Information</a></h2><div class="dc_accordion-body " style=""><p>Please refer to the Dawson College website for details on <a href="http://www.dawsoncollege.qc.ca/registrar/english-french-placement-tests" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">French placement testing requirements</a>.</p>
<p>Pratique du franais oral et crit pour les tudiants non francophones (602-03B-DW or 602-04B-DW): These courses are designed for students from OUTSIDE Quebec only and they are not available during the day (except for students registered in Journeys). If this is your placement, and you need more information or to register, please call the Registration Help Line (514-931-5701).</p>
<p><strong>French block B </strong>courses have been designed to meet students' needs in relation to their field of study. These courses will help develop vocabulary and communication skills related to their programs. Programs have been divided into three "families".</p>
<p>You must take the block B course designed for your program and at your French level. If you take a block B course this term, find which "family" you belong to, then look at the chart below to find the course number which corresponds to your level and to your "family".</p>
<p><strong><u>Arts et lettres</u></strong>: Arts, Literature and Communication (Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, Studio Arts), Graphic Design, Illustration, Industrial Design, Interior Design, Photography, Professional Theatre, Visual Arts, 3D Animation and Computer Generated Imagery.</p>
<p><strong><u>Sciences humaines</u></strong>: Accounting and Management Technology, Business Management (Marketing), Commerce, Community Recreation Leadership Training, Computer Science, Liberal Arts, Social Science, Social Science Profiles, Social Service.</p>
<p><strong><u>Sciences et techniques</u></strong>: Biomedical Laboratory Technology, Civil Engineering Technology, Diagnostic Imaging, Electronics Technology, Laboratory Technology/Analytical Chemistry, Mechanical Engineering Technology, Nursing, Physiotherapy Technology, Radiation Oncology, Science.</p>

Une ode  la libert d'tre ce qu'on est, ce qu'on nait. Nous y aborderons les thmes de la fatalit, de la marginalit, de la conscience mais aussi du mal tre qui happe parfois nos vies avec ou sans rsilience. Une aventure littraire mais profondment ancre dans une ralit trop souvent inexplore. Nous suivrons les traces de l'auteur David Goudreaut et tenterons de comprendre son message.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction  la littrature contemporaine</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00006</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Leila Ephrem El Boustani-Safi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Dans le cadre de ce cours, nous tudierons diffrentes productions littraires franaises et qubcoises du XXe et du XXIe sicle qui mettent l'accent sur des thmes aussi bien universels qu'actuels. LOrientalisme tmoigne dune fascination de lOccident pour lOrient (Empire ottoman, Maghreb, Moyen-Orient et Al-Andalus). Ds lors, une question se pose : lOrientalisme propose-t-il une reprsentation fidle de lOrient? Ou nen trahit-il pas plutt une vision occidentale purement fantasme? Afin de rpondre  cette  nigme  et dalimenter notre rflexion, nous analyserons des tableaux orientalistes (Delacroix, Benjamin-Constant, etc.), nous tudierons des extraits de rcits de voyage  Constantinople (Gautier, de Nerval), des pomes choisis des Orientales de V. Hugo et Les Aventures du dernier Abencrage de F.  R de Chateaubriand. Ce cours se conclura par une cration littraire labore en quipe: vous rdigerez vous-mme, de manire collaborative, une nouvelle orientaliste illustre.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Esthtiques du scandale</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00010</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Lyane Henrichon</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Dans le cours Esthtiques du scandale, nous tudierons diffrentes productions littraires franaises et qubcoises (depuis 1850 jusqu nos jours) en mettant laccent sur leur caractre transgressif. Notre parcours se fera essentiellement par la lecture de textes littraires, mais nous nous servirons galement de chansons, de films, duvres dart, etc. En somme, notre rflexion portera sur des uvres littraires et artistiques qui auront bouscul les normes et scandalis les diffrentes socits dans lesquelles elles ont t cres.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. LOrientalisme tmoigne dune fascination de lOccident pour lOrient (Empire ottoman, Maghreb, Moyen-Orient et Al-Andalus). Ds lors, une question se pose : lOrientalisme propose-t-il une reprsentation fidle de lOrient? Ou nen trahit-il pas plutt une vision occidentale purement fantasme? Afin de rpondre  cette  nigme  et dalimenter notre rflexion, nous analyserons des tableaux orientalistes (Delacroix, Benjamin-Constant, etc.), nous tudierons des extraits de rcits de voyage  Constantinople (Gautier, de Nerval), des pomes choisis des Orientales de V. Hugo et Les Aventures du dernier Abencrage de F.  R de Chateaubriand. Ce cours se conclura par une cration littraire labore en quipe: vous rdigerez vous-mme, de manire collaborative, une nouvelle orientaliste illustre.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction  la littrature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00014</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carmen-Silvia Cristea</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Ce cours se propose dengager une rflexion sur la manire dont la littrature raconte le monde et lhistoire, et sur sa lgitimit et sa pertinence. Nous tudierons dans ce but trois uvres littraires qui puisent leur inspiration dans lhistoire contemporaine. Aprs avoir analys, dans un premier temps, le contexte socio-historique qui reprsente la toile de fond de chaque uvre, les thmes abords, ainsi que les stratgies narratives, nous pencherons plus particulirement sur le mode dnonciation de chaque texte (la scne nonciative) en nous posant les questions suivantes: Qui est le narrateur? Quel thos, adopte-il pour raconter des vnements qui dpassent la sphre de lintime pour se greffer dans lhistoire contemporaine? Comment la forme dnonciation du roman faonne le rcit ainsi que le mode de rception de luvre?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction  la littrature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00015</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Laetitia Desanti</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Ce niveau de cours s'adresse aux tudiants qui maitrisent suffisamment le franais crit pour traiter de sujets d'ordre culturel et littraire.  ce niveau, les divers cours offerts portent sur des thmes culturels varis ainsi que sur les diffrents genres littraires. Llve amliore et parfait ses habilets linguistiques et approfondit sa matrise de la grammaire et de lcriture. Llve se sensibilise  lapprentissage du franais comme langue seconde pour tre en mesure de russir une relation daide tout en intgrant des notions de pdagogie, de didactique et de psychologie. Le rapport d'une recherche relie au programme spcifique de l'tudiant forme la composante de franais de l'preuve synthse (Comprehensive Assessment).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Ce cours s'adresse aux tudiants et tudiantes qui ont russi le cours 602-103 avec une note dau moins 75 % ou qui ont une trs bonne matrise du franais oral et crit, et qui dsirent aider des lves en difficult  se perfectionner en franais oral et crit. Pour pouvoir sinscrire  ce cours, les tudiants doivent communiquer avec V. Toutefois, la russite de ce cours ne garantit pas laccs au mme niveau pour tous les tudiants. Ltudiant sera valu tout au long de la session et  la fin du cours.  Il ou elle poursuivra son cheminement, selon ses comptences langagires, soit dans un autre cours prparatoire non-crdit ou soit en Franais de base. This course is for Indigenous students who are preparing to enter CEGEP level credited French (Basic French 602-100-MQ). However, passing this course does not guarantee access to the same level for all. The student will be evaluated throughout the semester and at the end. Depending on the students language skills, he or she will continue either in another preparatory course or in Basic French (602-100-MQ).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Journeys</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.18</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.18</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Geography</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">320-102-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Geography and the Environment</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">8 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jeffrey Barnes</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The environment encompasses the natural world, of which we are a part, and the built world, which we have created. Geography studies both the changes taking place within the natural world and the changes in the way people organize their activities spatially in the social world. This course introduces students to the dynamic character of society and its interaction with the natural environment. The course will introduce basic geography skills such as map reading, mapmaking and the usefulness of geographic information systems (GIS). It will then explore key concepts relating to the geographic study of climate, environment, and of society, culture, demography and development.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jeffrey Barnes</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The environment encompasses the natural world, of which we are a part, and the built world, which we have created. Geography studies both the changes taking place within the natural world and the changes in the way people organize their activities spatially in the social world. This course introduces students to the dynamic character of society and its interaction with the natural environment. The course will introduce basic geography skills such as map reading, mapmaking and the usefulness of geographic information systems (GIS). It will then explore key concepts relating to the geographic study of climate, environment, and of society, culture, demography and development.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Environmental Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Richard Soare</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The environment encompasses the natural world, of which we are a part, and the built world, which we have created. Geography studies both the changes taking place within the natural world and the changes in the way people organize their activities spatially in the social world. This course introduces students to the dynamic character of society and its interaction with the natural environment. The course will introduce basic geography skills such as map reading, mapmaking and the usefulness of geographic information systems (GIS). It will then explore key concepts relating to the geographic study of climate, environment, and of society, culture, demography and development.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">International Business Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Geoffrey Pearce</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The environment encompasses the natural world, of which we are a part, and the built world, which we have created. Geography studies both the changes taking place within the natural world and the changes in the way people organize their activities spatially in the social world. This course introduces students to the dynamic character of society and its interaction with the natural environment. The course will introduce basic geography skills such as map reading, mapmaking and the usefulness of geographic information systems (GIS). It will then explore key concepts relating to the geographic study of climate, environment, and of society, culture, demography and development.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gisela Frias</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The environment encompasses the natural world, of which we are a part, and the built world, which we have created. Geography studies both the changes taking place within the natural world and the changes in the way people organize their activities spatially in the social world. This course introduces students to the dynamic character of society and its interaction with the natural environment. This course explores the process of globalization and the restructuring of the global economy.  Globalization is analysed within the historical context of capitalism, its birth, intensification and geographical expansion. The changing dynamics of production and consumption, emerging patterns of global inequality, the changing role of the State, Multinational Corporations and International Organizations such as the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organization are explored. Contemporary debates on globalization and economic development are addressed.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">North South Studies<br>International Business Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">320-302-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Applied Geography</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sara Louise Kendall</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students will be introduced to fieldwork methods and data analysis techniques used in the field of Geography. Through a problem solving approach, students will address current issues related to public space, public art, urban renewal, and commercial development in Montreal. During fieldworks students will develop their ability to read maps, gather primary data through questionnaires, interviews and/or direct observation.  Emphasis will be placed on applying theories to urban space and developing original solutions to urban issues.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Travel and Tourism</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">320-303-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Environmental Issues</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sara Louise Kendall</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this class, students will develop tools for understanding, analyzing, and addressing key environmental issues. Students will examine changing relationships between humans and our environments, and the ways that natural, social, political, and economic systems interact. An emphasis will be placed on movements for environmental justice, including Indigenous-led and youth-led movements both in Canada and around the world. Key environmental issues that may be covered include climate change, mineral and resource extraction, availability of drinking water, waste disposal, and air and water pollution.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Environmental Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00008</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Geoffrey Pearce</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Geology</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">205-BWT-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Science and technology: intro to the science of geology</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Environmental Geology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Catherine Pappas-Maenz</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course begins with an examination of the formation of the Earth, composition of the Earth, and the processes of plate tectonics. Students will be introduced to the causes and characteristics of different kinds of natural hazards such as earthquakes, volcanoes and landslides.   The interconnection between different disaster phenomenon and options for the possibility of predicting and controlling their occurrence  will also be examined. An important focus of this class will be the study of natural disasters throughout history and their effect on human populations. The issue of global climate change in Earth's past and present will also be discussed.  This course is designed for non-science students.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Environmental Geology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Catherine Pappas-Maenz</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course begins with an examination of the formation of the Earth, composition of the Earth, and the processes of plate tectonics. Students will be introduced to the causes and characteristics of different kinds of natural hazards such as earthquakes, volcanoes and landslides.   The interconnection between different disaster phenomenon and options for the possibility of predicting and controlling their occurrence  will also be examined. An important focus of this class will be the study of natural disasters throughout history and their effect on human populations. The issue of global climate change in Earth's past and present will also be discussed.  This course is designed for non-science students.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">205-BZG-05</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Physical Geology</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Catherine Pappas-Maenz</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Geology is the study of the earth. To understand how our planet works, at depth and at the surface, the ideas and principles of biology, chemistry, physics, mathematics and geography are integrated in the exciting and stimulating studies which make up Earth Sciences. This course provides a basic understanding of geology and the methods used by geologists for studying Earth; the materials that constitute its makeup, the structure of those materials, and the processes acting on them. Students learn critical thinking and empirical reasoning skills that can be applied to any career or pursuit. The goal is to understand geological principles and how humans affect geological processes. Topics include the rocks and minerals composing Earth, the movement within Earth, and its surface features and the agents that form them and our environment.  This course may be taken by students in both Health Science and Pure and Applied Science as a Science option.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>German</h2><div class="new dc_accordion open disciplineText  "><h2 class="dc_accordion-title highlighta"><a class="" style="" href="#important-information">Important Information</a></h2><div class="dc_accordion-body " style=""><p>Please note the prerequisites for each course. Students in doubt of their level must contact the department chairperson at local 4633 or e-mail hkaranika@dawsoncollege.qc.ca before registration.</p></div></div><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">609-111-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">German 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">4 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marie-France Lemay</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of German, formal or informal. The course will develop four basic language skills: speaking, writing, listening comprehension, and reading comprehension. It will focus on basic grammatical structures and vocabulary, controlled and spontaneous expression, oral/written assignments, and an introduction to culture. Language learning will be enhanced through the use of various audiovisual media, as well as additional learning activities in the language lab.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">All Arts, Literature and Communication Profiles</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marie-France Lemay</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of German, formal or informal. Language learning will be enhanced through the use of various audiovisual media, as well as additional learning activities in the language lab.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Graphic Design</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-161-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Typography I</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gyula Zoltan Gefin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Typography 1 introduces typography and its essential role in graphic design, giving an appreciation of the history of letterforms as a means of visual communication, the distinguishing features of typefaces, and the use of letter, word and line spacing in typography. Typographic terminology is acquired. Students work with fewer given limitations but at the same time they learn to use approaches and styles appropriate for a target audience. Some exercises deal with typographic forms as graphic elements while others combine text, and graphic and photographic images. Colour is incorporated into designs.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Luc Parent</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Typographic Explorations develops a creative and experimental approach to typographic design.
