Selection and control of various artificial light sources as well as how to photograph in different lighting situations is covered. Each student produces a workbook of photographic lighting techniques that demonstrates through diagrams and illustrations how to apply specific lighting strategies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Daniel Cianfarra</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Photographic Lighting for Graphic Design introduces students to basic art direction in photography. Selection and control of various artificial light sources as well as how to photograph in different lighting situations is covered. Each student produces a workbook of photographic lighting techniques that demonstrates through diagrams and illustrations how to apply specific lighting strategies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.14</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-363-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Pictogram and Icon Design</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Franois Martin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Pictogram and Icon Design introduces flat graphic illustration in its simplest form  symbol design. Formal and informal approaches are explored. Freehand drawing skills are used at the beginning stages; later, a series of organic and a series of geometric symbols are created both by hand and on the computer. A book of developmental drawings is produced.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.10</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Franois Martin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Pictogram and Icon Design introduces flat graphic illustration in its simplest form  symbol design. Formal and informal approaches are explored. Freehand drawing skills are used at the beginning stages; later, a series of organic and a series of geometric symbols are created both by hand and on the computer. A book of developmental drawings is produced.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-365-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Illustration Techniques</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Suzanne Ct</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Illustration Techniques builds on the drawing courses given in the first year. Students produce preliminary and finished editorial illustrations on a given theme using different techniques such as pencil-crayon and pen-and-ink drawings, scratchboard, block printing, pastels, collage, mixed media, etc. Pictorial research and concept development are stressed. Students produce illustrations using any of a variety of techniques (e.g.: drawing, collage, block printing, collage, photo-montage, type as image, etc.). Then, using the computer and their skills in typography, illustrations are combined with type and integrated into an e-book design project.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.17</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gyula Zoltan Gefin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">E-Book Design brings together manual and digital techniques in the creation of a cover and typical pages for an e-book publication. Students produce illustrations using any of a variety of techniques (e.g.: drawing, collage, block printing, collage, photo-montage, type as image, etc.). Then, using the computer and their skills in typography, illustrations are combined with type and integrated into an e-book design project.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.17</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-565-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Explorations in Video Production</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nelly Dahan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Explorations in Video Production introduces students to the many aspects of basic video production including written materials for video productions, storyboards, studio practice, photographing for video, choosing a soundtrack and voice-over, cost estimates and production evaluations. Among the major themes covered are the emergence and influence of key intellectual currents, social and political revolution, the development of industrial society, the birth of the nation state, imperialism, totalitarianism, and the two world wars. Students are introduced to basic concepts such as historical cause and social change, race, class and gender, as well as to the major political ideologies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Diane Shea</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course traces the growth of Western civilization from its roots in the Judeo-Christian and Greco-Roman traditions to the 20th century. Among the major themes covered are the emergence and influence of key intellectual currents, social and political revolution, the development of industrial society, the birth of the nation state, imperialism, totalitarianism, and the two world wars. Students are introduced to basic concepts such as historical cause and social change, race, class and gender, as well as to the major political ideologies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Duckett</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course traces the growth of Western civilization from its roots in the Judeo-Christian and Greco-Roman traditions to the 20th century. Among the major themes covered are the emergence and influence of key intellectual currents, social and political revolution, the development of industrial society, the birth of the nation state, imperialism, totalitarianism, and the two world wars. Among the major themes covered are the emergence and influence of key intellectual currents, social and political revolution, the development of industrial society, the birth of the nation state, imperialism, totalitarianism, and the two world wars. Students are introduced to basic concepts such as historical cause and social change, race, class and gender, as well as to the major political ideologies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.22</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.22</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00020</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jrmy Ttrault-Farber</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course traces the growth of Western civilization from its roots in the Judeo-Christian and Greco-Roman traditions to the 20th century. Students registering for this section CAN TAKE IT SEPARATELY OR AS A PAIR WITH 350-101-DW 12002.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">330-201-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Canadian History</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">5 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Resistance to Canadian Colonialism</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Benjamin Lander</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will look at the long and ongoing history of colonialism in Canada but will focus specifically on the centuries long resistance to theft of land, imposition of European religious, cultural and social norms, and the numerous forms of discrimination that were/are part of the fabric of Canada. As such we will look at Indigenous, Black and other communities of colour who continue to resist inequity on these lands including most recently with the Wetsuweten pipeline, Loi 21 and Bill 96. Students will meet the competencies through analyses of specific themes, cases and problems linked to the basic concepts and theories presented in the course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Resistance to Canadian Colonialism</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Benjamin Lander</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will look at the long and ongoing history of colonialism in Canada but will focus specifically on the centuries long resistance to theft of land, imposition of European religious, cultural and social norms, and the numerous forms of discrimination that were/are part of the fabric of Canada. As such we will look at Indigenous, Black and other communities of colour who continue to resist inequity on these lands including most recently with the Wetsuweten pipeline, Loi 21 and Bill 96. Students will meet the competencies through analyses of specific themes, cases and problems linked to the basic concepts and theories presented in the course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Crime and Society</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rachle Caux</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will survey the history of crime and criminal justice in Canadian society, from the English and French origins to the present day. The topics to be covered include the French and English systems of justice as they emerged from the Middle Ages (ordeals, inquisitorial procedure, witch craze); the criminal judicial system of New France; the transformation after the British conquest; the judicial reforms of the Enlightenment and the introduction of the penitentiary; the Canadian justice system and its relation to women, juveniles and ethnic minorities; policing and the RCMP; capital punishment; and the present-day Canadian justice system. These topics will be examined using concepts such as gender, crime, law, race, class, and human rights, while using a variety of historical sources and methodologies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice<br>This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.45</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.45</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Crime and Society</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rachle Caux</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will survey the history of crime and criminal justice in Canadian society, from the English and French origins to the present day. The topics to be covered include the French and English systems of justice as they emerged from the Middle Ages (ordeals, inquisitorial procedure, witch craze); the criminal judicial system of New France; the transformation after the British conquest; the judicial reforms of the Enlightenment and the introduction of the penitentiary; the Canadian justice system and its relation to women, juveniles and ethnic minorities; policing and the RCMP; capital punishment; and the present-day Canadian justice system. These topics will be examined using concepts such as gender, crime, law, race, class, and human rights, while using a variety of historical sources and methodologies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice<br>This is a Learning Communities section. Students registering for this section MUST ALSO TAKE 385-306-DW 12001.<br>This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">330-206-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">U.S. History</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Divided We Stand: USA from Colonial Times to the Vietnam War</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Pierre L'Heureux</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students will survey the history of the United States from the colonial period to the present. They will study such topics as the establishment of slavery, the American Revolution, the Civil War, industrialization and its political and social consequences, imperial expansion into Latin America and Asia, the two World Wars, the long struggle for equal rights in America, the Cold War and the emergence of the United States as a global superpower.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">330-210-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Quebec History</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Outcasts and Minorities in Quebec History</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rachle Caux</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores Qubecs past through the lives and experiences of those who lived on the fringe. It surveys the history of Qubec from the colonial era to the present time through the analysis of individuals or groups whose defiance of accepted law and order challenged authority and dominant values. This course also reflects on the exclusion process in Quebecs past by focusing on people who are too often ignored from our official history books such as slaves, criminals, single mothers, the mentally challenged or simply rebels. Key events or phenomena such as the fight for the decriminalization of contraception or the October Crisis are also examined. This course seeks to provide a better understanding of Quebecs past and present by reflecting on how these individuals who did not fit into society's mainstream impacted and transformed our society, economy and culture.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">330-221-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Third World History</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Imperialism and Resistance</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maryann Farkas</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a survey of the Third World from the late 1800s to the present. Areas studied include Africa, the Middle East, India and China. The course will examine the forces, trends and events of European colonialism, its impact on the Third World, nationalist struggles and revolutions accompanying decolonization, and problems of the post-colonial world. Concepts such as colonialism, imperialism, decolonization, neo-colonialism, nationalism, revolution, racism, ethnicity, gender, and under-development will be used with a variety of historical sources.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">330-314-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Applied 20th Century History</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Great Revolutions of the 20th Century</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jrmy Ttrault-Farber</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The twentieth century was one of the most turbulent in human history, with world wars, political, social, and cultural revolutions that affected the lives of many people throughout the world. This course proposes to examine in detail, various revolutionary and tumultuous events that have marked different regions of the world. For each revolution (in some cases rapid social changes), we will analyze its causes and consequences as well as looking at the perspectives of the actors directly involved. Emphasis will be placed on reading and discussing primary sources, but contextual and explanatory lectures will also be provided. The competency associated with this course includes the following elements: to identify concrete situations which lend themselves to study; to use concepts applicable to these situations; to use a strategy appropriate to the study of these situations.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Fascism and the Second World War</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mark Theriault</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will help students to better understand historical fascism  its original form in Italy (Fascism), its German counterpart (National Socialism), and its compatibility with the culture of Imperial Japan, the third member of the Axis alliance that sought to dominate the world in the 1940s. International Communism will be discussed early in the course. It is crucial that students learn about Communist ideology and the Soviet Union in order to understand why fascism existed at all. The second half of the course will deal with the Second World War and some of its long-term effects. In order to achieve Competency 0225, to apply concepts related to Social Science disciplines to the understanding of the human phenomenon [sic] in concrete situations, each student will be required to write an analytical essay of 1500 to 2000 words on a topic chosen from a prepared list, or possibly a topic they propose on their own.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">330-325-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Applied Social and Economic History</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Family</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nancy Rebelo</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will explore different historical approaches to the most essential of all social organizations: the family. Some aspects of the history of the family to be covered will include the analysis of the continuous interaction between economic forms of production and the social conditions which accompany them; analysis of the kind of societies which have favoured various family strategies at particular times; the role of the emancipation of women; the changing position of children in the family; the impact of new technologies and the increasing mechanization of work on the family. This theme will be approached through the examination of various debates and methodological approaches related to family history and the analysis of a variety of primary and secondary sources (including cinematographic material, legal documents and personal narrative accounts).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Counting the Cost: Social Justice in Canada</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>12001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Elizabeth Kirkland</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course, which is paired with Quantitative Methods (300-360-DW) begins by looking at the current state of our society and then digs back into the past to explore the roots of social justice issues through hands-on research. We will be going out into the community, watching documentaries, hearing from experts, and getting our hands dirty in the archives in order to build research projects that bridge classroom learning and social activism.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This is a Learning Communities section. Students registering for this section CAN TAKE IT SEPARATELY OR AS A PAIR WITH 360-300-DW 12001.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">330-370-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Modern History-19th and 20th Centuries</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gemma Albanese</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a general survey of European and Western history from the French Revolution until the aftermath of World War II. Its main emphasis is on the understanding of first, the important broad socio-economic and political changes, and second, the relationship between these changes and the history of ideas. We examine the connection between the French Revolution and the ideas of such influential conservative thinkers as Edmund Burke and Joseph de Maistre. Similarly, the link between the Industrial Revolution and the various socialist ideologies is traced. The steady growth of liberalism and nationalism in the 19th century and of totalitarian and revolutionary ideologies in the 20th century are naturally important course themes.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Liberal Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">330-401-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Advanced Studies in History</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Art, Culture, and Social Change,1880-1945</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Julie Johnson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores some of the important events that shaped the years from 1880 to 1945, including industrialization, urban growth, revolutions, empire, and the two world wars, and emphasizes the significant role of art and other forms of cultural expression in both shaping and reflecting these histories. Particular focus is given to cultural and intellectual movements that challenged the existing order and pushed for meaningful social change across issues of race, class, gender, and sexualities. Through the reading of primary and secondary sources, students will produce a significant term project using historical knowledge, methodology, and concepts learned both in this class and in their 100, 200, and/or 300 level History courses</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.26</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.26</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Ideas and Inventions: A Modern World</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gesche Peters</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the importance of innovation and technology related to the history of science with a concentration on the Western World in the modern period. This will be explored through several historical topics, including the examination of common beliefs and realities known about the natural world, the role of scientific communities and their make-up and dynamics, differences between the applied and theoretical forms of invention, government interest in these principles, and others. All of these issues will be examined through the example of particular inventions, technologies and scientific principles from roughly the 17th century onward. Through the readings of several primary and secondary sources, students will produce a term project using historical knowledge, methodology and concepts learned both in this class and their 100, 200 and/or 300 level History courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">330-BXS-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Applications in History</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Snapshots of the 20th Century</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ray Claudio Pino</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Snapshots always capture a moment in time. However, they might also reveal far more. The 20th century was a remarkable period of exhilarating and tumultuous change and challenge. We will consider moments in time as an entre to exploring various aspects of this period in order to understand its continuities and discontinuities. The Model T Ford (Michigan, Manchester, 1908-27) and Tiananmen Squares Tank Man (Beijing, 1989) are examples of those moments in time that represented something far more. In this course, we will traverse and consider key topics in 20th century history, and students will analyze issues using social scientific approaches.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Humanities</h2><div class="new dc_accordion open disciplineText  "><h2 class="dc_accordion-title highlighta"><a class="" style="" href="#important-information">Important Information</a></h2><div class="dc_accordion-body " style=""><p>Students must follow the sequence 345-101-MQ, 345-102-MQ then 345-BXH-DW.</p></div></div><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">345-101-MQ</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Knowledge</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">64 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Reading The Past</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Wood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The aim of this course is to foster critical thinking about a specific field of knowledge: archaeology, the study of past material culture. The methods by which the discipline collects data, assesses evidence and builds arguments will be examined. The course will demonstrate how archaeology can be used to reconstruct ancient beliefs, answer larger questions about past societies, test the veracity of written accounts and challenge traditional reconstructions based on literary sources. It will also show how archaeological evidence can be used to construct and test theories meant to explain past trends, namely why societies collapse. Relevant case studies will be drawn from a variety of times and places, such as Rome, the ancient Near East, pre-Columbian America, the world of the Vikings and early Islamic Jordan. A section on pseudo-archaeology will allow for the critical examination of mistakes in reasoned argumentation, while studying popular conceptions about the past.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Examined Life</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Derrick Farnham</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">For Socrates The unexamined life is not worth living (Apology, 38a). In this Knowledge course, students will apply a logical analytical process to how knowledge is organized and used (345-101 competency). We will attempt to examine our own lives by studying his. The course will consider arguments, how to evaluate and produce them. The students logical skills will be honed, allowing a better understanding of the world and an enhanced ability to communicate and succeed. This will be done by gaining an appreciation of the reasoning abilities of Socrates. We will begin with a look at the world that Socrates was born into, Athens, the Greek myths he grew up with and the war with Sparta. We will then read some of the works of Plato, in which Socrates is the main player, and consider the debate over what we can know and what is worthwhile. The perspective taken will be the thoroughness of understanding and argumentation in establishing and refuting positions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Media Knowledge</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mari Heywood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The media mediates our lives and as such influences our beliefs, values, choices, and fundamentally structures our vision of ourselves and the world. It describes our most personal expectations and provides us with ways of seeing and interpreting events, influencing what we consider to constitute helpful, valid, and even true knowledge. In this course we use sources of mass and alternative media to question objectivity of information. We consider visual communication (linking image and imagination) and examine strategies of data and information collection and persuasion. Examples from investigative journalism, advertising, popular magazines, and other sources help us develop an understanding of what we know, how we know it, and the limits of our knowledge. To evaluate what restricts and shapes knowledge and our understandings of our own and others lives, it is essential to know how knowledge is constructed and conveyed through media.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.45</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.45</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Self: Theories and Construction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">John Hunting</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the problem of knowledge (epistemology) and its relevance for theories of the self. In thinking about the "self" various related notions are apparent: soul, mind, consciousness, self-consciousness, subjectivity, body-image, self-image, self-concept, psyche and personality. We will ask what these notions mean and how they relate to what having or being a self involves. For example, is the self (or soul) best described as an immaterial thing that "thinks"? Is our individuality only really guaranteed by our corporeality, suffering or happiness? Is the self better described as a self-reflexive process, the origin of which is rooted in experience? Is the self a construction, mere habit or illusion? Is the self a radical freedom or a "no-thing" as Sartre proclaimed? Is the self a unified and singular thing, or is it an essentially divided, layered and conflicted process? Is the self a culturally learned "manner of being" we are asked to perform?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Evolution</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rui De Sousa</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will look at how the theory of evolution has revolutionized our understanding of our place in the universe. Charles Darwin's The Origin of Species undermined many of the premises of Western thought about the elevated status of human beings in the cosmos. We will look at how the dominant views on the origins of human life prior to the modern era were undermined by developments in the Scientific Revolution and during the Enlightenment. We will then examine the notions of variation and natural selection in The Origin of Species and how they seek to explain the development of all life forms. We will also study Darwin's contributions to our understanding of human evolution in his other famous work The Descent of Man and look at the intellectual debate which its publication inspired. The course will conclude with an overview of what we know today about the origins of life on Earth, the particular phases of human evolution and recent developments in the science of genetics.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Media Knowledge</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00006</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mari Heywood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The media mediates our lives and as such influences our beliefs, values, choices, and fundamentally structures our vision of ourselves and the world. It describes our most personal expectations and provides us with ways of seeing and interpreting events, influencing what we consider to constitute helpful, valid, and even true knowledge. In this course we use sources of mass and alternative media to question objectivity of information. We consider visual communication (linking image and imagination) and examine strategies of data and information collection and persuasion. Examples from investigative journalism, advertising, popular magazines, and other sources help us develop an understanding of what we know, how we know it, and the limits of our knowledge. To evaluate what restricts and shapes knowledge and our understandings of our own and others lives, it is essential to know how knowledge is constructed and conveyed through media.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Critical Thinking and Communication</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00007</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Abid Bahar, Bohdan  Ladashevska, Laura Mimeault</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students will learn about knowledge related to communication. They will critically examine what constitutes competent communication, how these norms develop and become accepted, and how we can know what these norms are. They will also discover whether the norms of effective communications are the same everywhere.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Greek Mythology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00008</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anne Thorpe</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Studying the past is never a straightforward task and the difficulties are compounded when examining cultures like ancient Greece, from which surviving evidence is limited and produced for the most part by a narrow subset of that society. What knowledge of ancient Greece is possible then? In this course, well examine some of the material thats survived, exploring the relative usefulness of these sources in shedding light on ancient Greek culture. In particular, well consider what insights ancient Greek myth might offer us, especially when it claims to present historical events, such as the origins of the universe, the creation of men, women and the gods, and the Trojan War. These stories are fictional and often preposterous, and yet one of the central functions of myth is to reinforce and explore key cultural values. Thus, we can use these myths to glean truths about the ancient Greek value system, and through close analysis even discern which long-held beliefs were in dispute.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Critical Thinking, Creative Thinking, Design Thinking</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00009</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jessica Lim</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The focus of this class is on the creative process and the knowledge we gain through creativity. Throughout the semester, students will be asked to practice different creative thinking tools, develop their own creative processes, and explore the relationship between the philosophical skill of critical thinking and the artistic skill of creative thinking. Students will study, practice, and apply creative tools to unlock their critical thinking, and, ultimately, will design ideas that make the world better.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Darwin's Tea Party</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00010</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gabriel Tordjman</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Biological knowledge, or knowledge of the living world, has been essential to human survival since the dawn of humanity and has transformed nature, society, and our ideas about who and what we are. Darwin's theory of evolution is one key example of just how powerful biological knowledge has been and continues to be, though it is just one chapter in this story. Today, biological science and technology are on the verge of triggering even more radical transformations of our environment, society, and perhaps of human nature itself. This course examines the growth and impact, use and misuse of biological knowledge, from the earliest periods to the rise of Darwin's evolutionary theory, right up to the present.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Darwin's Tea Party</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00011</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gabriel Tordjman</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Biological knowledge, or knowledge of the living world, has been essential to human survival since the dawn of humanity and has transformed nature, society, and our ideas about who and what we are. Darwin's theory of evolution is one key example of just how powerful biological knowledge has been and continues to be, though it is just one chapter in this story. Today, biological science and technology are on the verge of triggering even more radical transformations of our environment, society, and perhaps of human nature itself. This course examines the growth and impact, use and misuse of biological knowledge, from the earliest periods to the rise of Darwin's evolutionary theory, right up to the present.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Critical Pedagogy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00012</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mariam Sambe</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Native Ways of Knowing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00013</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Aditya Kumar Dewan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Over the past last 500 years, indigenous peoples of the world have lost much of their traditional knowledge due to invasion and colonization by non-natives. There have been attacks on their language and culture, commercialization of their art, and use of their plant knowledge in the development of medicine without their consent. However, there is still much to be learned from contemporary hunters-gatherers, since this knowledge is still used in their daily lives. This course deals with contemporary native peoples' knowledge of land and nature, resource management, environmental adaptation, herbal medicine, social and economic organization. It will examine the importance of preserving, promoting and protecting indigenous language, culture and knowledge. By examining this other system of knowledge in a multidisciplinary framework, students may better understand their own system of knowledge and its use.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">What Does It Mean To Be Human?</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00014</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Eric Van Der Wee</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">With science steadily progressing in areas such as eugenics; the increasing attention surrounding bioethical issues; and the struggle for religion and philosophy to describe the human condition in this current landscape, a definition of being human is a matter of renewed importance. This course will consider the question of what it means to be human from distinct disciplines, in an effort to build up a knowledge base for which one can answer the question: What does it mean to be Human? The purpose of this course is to help students develop an analytical perspective on the concepts of humanness and personhood and what the ramifications for society each concept brings.  It does so through an examination of the topic through different branches of learning in an effort to find a working definition of what it means to be human by looking at where the different disciplines intersect, compliment and complete each other.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Native Ways of Knowing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00015</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Aditya Kumar Dewan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Over the past last 500 years, indigenous peoples of the world have lost much of their traditional knowledge due to invasion and colonization by non-natives. There have been attacks on their language and culture, commercialization of their art, and use of their plant knowledge in the development of medicine without their consent. However, there is still much to be learned from contemporary hunters-gatherers, since this knowledge is still used in their daily lives. This course deals with contemporary native peoples' knowledge of land and nature, resource management, environmental adaptation, herbal medicine, social and economic organization. It will examine the importance of preserving, promoting and protecting indigenous language, culture and knowledge. By examining this other system of knowledge in a multidisciplinary framework, students may better understand their own system of knowledge and its use.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Justice 1</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00016</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anjali Choksi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Journeys</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM -
