4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.18</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.18</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Sex and Death: An Introduction to Psychoanalysis</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00017</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Julian Nemeth</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Few fields of knowledge have been as influential, and controversial, as psychoanalysis. Its founder, Sigmund Freud, pioneered a revolutionary form of therapy, the talking cure, designed to help patients resolve their symptoms and free up their desire. He taught that we never really overcome our childhood. That every story we tell is also a cover story. The unconscious, the I that is another, pulls us along, sometimes catastrophically, without us realizing it. To make sense of this startling situation, psychoanalysis introduces a new way of reading, one which we will apply to works of philosophy, film, and literature. The course also asks us to interpret our own livesparticularly the seemingly marginal realm of dreams, jokes, and slips of the tongue. Sometimes derided as outdated, what remains of psychoanalysis in the 21st century? As we put the field into dialogue with feminism, queer theory, and anti-racismas well as our own so-called selvestentative answers will emerge.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Writing Life: Knowledge and the Art of Nonfiction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00019</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joseph Rosen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course investigates the way that language and writing generate knowledge about the self. We will define knowledge in a particular way: not just as data or information about the world, but as an invitation to occupy certain subject positions. Knowledge, as we will define it, doesnt just tell us about the world: it asks us to be a certain kind of person in the world. We investigate different definitions of ideology, moving from the Marxist concept of false consciousness to the Foucauldian concept of discourse as the production of subjectivity. We will then define critical thinking as an interrogation of how we are told to be subjects.    Focusing on the personal dimension of nonfiction writing, we will look at the role knowledge plays in forming us as subjects. Final essays are a substantial part of this course and students will use what they have learned about knowledge and the personal dimension of nonfiction in order to self-reflectively address their own subject formation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Self: Theories and Construction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00020</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">John Hunting</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the problem of knowledge (epistemology) and its relevance for theories of the self. In thinking about the "self" various related notions are apparent: soul, mind, consciousness, self-consciousness, subjectivity, body-image, self-image, self-concept, psyche and personality. We will ask what these notions mean and how they relate to what having or being a self involves. For example, is the self (or soul) best described as an immaterial thing that "thinks"? Is our individuality only really guaranteed by our corporeality, suffering or happiness? Is the self better described as a self-reflexive process, the origin of which is rooted in experience? Is the self a construction, mere habit or illusion? Is the self a radical freedom or a "no-thing" as Sartre proclaimed? Is the self a unified and singular thing, or is it an essentially divided, layered and conflicted process? Is the self a culturally learned "manner of being" we are asked to perform?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Knowledge of the Human Mind and Critical Thinking about AI</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00021</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carl Saucier-Bouffard</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is based on the premise that knowledge of ones mind is the starting point and one of the main components of critical thinking. We will explore the modes of functioning of the human mind, and will critically examine the processes by which knowledge is thought to be acquired. These processes will be illustrated mainly through the case study of AI technologies. For instance, the modes of functioning of the human mind will be compared with the ways data sets are analyzed and categorized by artificial intelligence (AI) systems. To succeed in this course, students should be able to provide a sound answer to the following questions: Why do an increasing number of scholars claim that humans are predictably irrational? Given the recent developments in AI, is it legitimate to assume that humans are not currently the most rational beings?  How can we train our minds to be more rational? How can we avoid fallacious reasoning? What is a logically valid and sound argument?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Judging Monarchs</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00022</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Timothy Slonosky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Was Englands Henry VIII a good king? How about the Roman Emperor Vespasian? To answer these seemingly simple questions, we must ask several more: What qualities does a good ruler possess? What actions must he or she perform? Who gets to decide which qualities and actions are good?  What information do we have about the ruler in question? Who gives us that information, and how trustworthy are they? What kind of argument and point of view is our source putting forth? Finally, how do we craft our answer so that other people will care about our response? To answer all these questions, we must combine our innate human ability to reason with the research skills necessary to uncover and evaluate historical facts.  This course will seek to answer the question of What makes a good monarch? by examining concepts of historical knowledge, determining what we can truly know about the past and how we can use that knowledge to form contemporary judgments.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Reading the Past</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00023</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Wood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The aim of this course is to foster critical thinking about a specific field of knowledge: archaeology, the study of past material culture. The methods by which the discipline collects data, assesses evidence and builds arguments will be examined. The course will demonstrate how archaeology can be used to reconstruct ancient beliefs, answer larger questions about past societies, test the veracity of written accounts and challenge traditional reconstructions based on literary sources. It will also show how archaeological evidence can be used to construct and test theories meant to explain past trends, namely why societies collapse. Relevant case studies will be drawn from a variety of times and places, such as Rome, the ancient Near East, pre-Columbian America, the world of the Vikings and early Islamic Jordan. A section on pseudo-archaeology will allow for the critical examination of mistakes in reasoned argumentation, while studying popular conceptions about the past.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Problems of Philosophy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00024</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michelle Braiden</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a general introduction to fundamentals of philosophical thought and specifically looks at the way in which theories of knowledge relate to political theory.  Questions to be asked include:  What is justice?  What role do moral values play in politics?  What is human nature?  What are the origins and the end of the state?  Can a war be just?  What are the limits of governmental power?  How much liberty should citizens enjoy?  Who should rule?  What is the best form of government?  What do we mean when we talk about freedom, equality, power, authority, legitimacy, sovereignty, natural law and human rights?  How can we know the answer to these questions?  What counts as a good argument?  The basic aim of the course is to improve students critical thinking skills and their ability to analyze, develop and construct philosophical arguments.  An additional aim is to introduce students to the history of ideas and their development in Western thought.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Philosophical Dilemmas</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00025</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Shi Chen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This knowledge course is an introduction to philosophical dilemmas. We will study lasting issues in philosophy, investigate interesting philosophical arguments, and explore creative ways of doing philosophy. By taking this course, students will develop and apply the essential skills of critical thinking.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Problems of Philosophy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00026</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michelle Braiden</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a general introduction to fundamentals of philosophical thought and specifically looks at the way in which theories of knowledge relate to political theory.  Questions to be asked include:  What is justice?  What role do moral values play in politics?  What is human nature?  What are the origins and the end of the state?  Can a war be just?  What are the limits of governmental power?  How much liberty should citizens enjoy?  Who should rule?  What is the best form of government?  What do we mean when we talk about freedom, equality, power, authority, legitimacy, sovereignty, natural law and human rights?  How can we know the answer to these questions?  What counts as a good argument?  The basic aim of the course is to improve students critical thinking skills and their ability to analyze, develop and construct philosophical arguments.  An additional aim is to introduce students to the history of ideas and their development in Western thought.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.05</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Critical Thinking: Feminist Ways of Knowing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00027</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Susan-Judith Hoffmann</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">To think critically means to think for ourselves rather than let others such as parents, governments or religious institutions think for us. Critical thinking is the practice of identifying poor arguments and constructing strong arguments. We will apply critical thinking by reading some philosophical works and examine how traditional conceptions of knowledge and truth exclude women. We will also explore feminist contributions to knowledge and truth. The definition of a feminist in this context is someone who argues that equality in intellectual endeavors means examining and including, where relevant, womens perspectives and research. The goal of the course is for you to apply your critical thinking skills and your understanding of feminist thinking to knowledge itself, and to write an argumentative essay on a topic proposed by the instructor, or one you have developed on topics such as indigenous issues, racism, gender, domestic violence or educational curricula, to name just a few.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Thinking Critically about the Present and the Past</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00028</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Ring</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Hijacked Brain</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00029</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gray Miles</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">If there is one kernel of knowledge that has united neuroscientists and philosophers, ancient thinkers and modern ones, it is the tacit assumption that humans are bad. It's a notion that drives newspaper headlines and guides the laws that shape our lives. From Plato to Augustine, Machiavelli to Hobbes, Freud to Pinker, the roots of this belief have sunk deep into Western thought. Human beings, we're taught, are by nature selfish and governed primarily by self-interest. But what if it isn't true? It is possible that believing in human generosity and collaboration isn't merely optimistic---it's realistic. Lets find out how this might be true. This knowledge course will critically appraise our traditions, challenging some elements and affirming others.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Self: Theories and Constructions</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00030</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">John Hunting</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the problem of knowledge (epistemology) and its relevance for theories of the self. In thinking about the "self" various related notions are apparent: soul, mind, consciousness, self-consciousness, subjectivity, body-image, self-image, self-concept, psyche and personality. We will ask what these notions mean and how they relate to what having or being a self involves. For example, is the self (or soul) best described as an immaterial thing that "thinks"? Is our individuality only really guaranteed by our corporeality, suffering or happiness? Is the self better described as a self-reflexive process, the origin of which is rooted in experience? Is the self a construction, mere habit or illusion? Is the self a radical freedom or a "no-thing" as Sartre proclaimed? Is the self a unified and singular thing, or is it an essentially divided, layered and conflicted process? Is the self a culturally learned "manner of being" we are asked to perform?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Writing Life: Knowledge and the Art of Nonfiction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00031</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joseph Rosen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course investigates the way that language and writing generate knowledge about the self. We will define knowledge in a particular way: not just as data or information about the world, but as an invitation to occupy certain subject positions. Knowledge, as we will define it, doesnt just tell us about the world: it asks us to be a certain kind of person in the world. We investigate different definitions of ideology, moving from the Marxist concept of false consciousness to the Foucauldian concept of discourse as the production of subjectivity. We will then define critical thinking as an interrogation of how we are told to be subjects.    Focusing on the personal dimension of nonfiction writing, we will look at the role knowledge plays in forming us as subjects. Final essays are a substantial part of this course and students will use what they have learned about knowledge and the personal dimension of nonfiction in order to self-reflectively address their own subject formation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Hijacked Brain</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00032</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gray Miles</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">If there is one kernel of knowledge that has united neuroscientists and philosophers, ancient thinkers and modern ones, it is the tacit assumption that humans are bad. It's a notion that drives newspaper headlines and guides the laws that shape our lives. From Plato to Augustine, Machiavelli to Hobbes, Freud to Pinker, the roots of this belief have sunk deep into Western thought. Human beings, we're taught, are by nature selfish and governed primarily by self-interest. But what if it isn't true? It is possible that believing in human generosity and collaboration isn't merely optimistic---it's realistic. Lets find out how this might be true. This knowledge course will critically appraise our traditions, challenging some elements and affirming others.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Evolution</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00033</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rui De Sousa</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will look at how the theory of evolution has revolutionized our understanding of our place in the universe. Charles Darwin's The Origin of Species undermined many of the premises of Western thought about the elevated status of human beings in the cosmos. We will look at how the dominant views on the origins of human life prior to the modern era were undermined by developments in the Scientific Revolution and during the Enlightenment. We will then examine the notions of variation and natural selection in The Origin of Species and how they seek to explain the development of all life forms. We will also study Darwin's contributions to our understanding of human evolution in his other famous work The Descent of Man and look at the intellectual debate which its publication inspired. The course will conclude with an overview of what we know today about the origins of life on Earth, the particular phases of human evolution and recent developments in the science of genetics.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Critical Thinking and Communication</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00034</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Abid Bahar</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course students will learn about knowledge related to communication. They will critically examine what constitutes competent communication, how these norms develop and become accepted, and how we can know what these norms are. They will also discover whether the norms of effective communications are the same everywhere.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Personal is Political: An Introduction to Autotheory</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00035</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mikaela Bobiy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This book is not a memoir. () It is a body-essay. Fiction, actually. If things must be pushed to the extreme, this is a somato-political fiction, a theory of the self, or self-theory. Just like these lines pulled from the autotheory text Testo Junkie, autotheory is a mutant, combining elements of memoir, critical theory and autobiography. The Personal is Political: An Introduction to Autotheory serves as an introduction to the genre, beginning with its roots in second-wave feminism and visual art, before crossing other disciplines. Throughout the course, students will be introduced to autotheory as a form of knowledge, combining elements of philosophy, psychoanalysis, and autobiography in order to construct, or deconstruct, the subject. In addition to reading works of autotheory, students will be encouraged to engage in their own autobiographical (autotheoretical) writing and other creative projects.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Personal is Political: An Introduction to Autotheory</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00036</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mikaela Bobiy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This book is not a memoir. () It is a body-essay. Fiction, actually. If things must be pushed to the extreme, this is a somato-political fiction, a theory of the self, or self-theory. Just like these lines pulled from the autotheory text Testo Junkie, autotheory is a mutant, combining elements of memoir, critical theory and autobiography. The Personal is Political: An Introduction to Autotheory serves as an introduction to the genre, beginning with its roots in second-wave feminism and visual art, before crossing other disciplines. Throughout the course, students will be introduced to autotheory as a form of knowledge, combining elements of philosophy, psychoanalysis, and autobiography in order to construct, or deconstruct, the subject. In addition to reading works of autotheory, students will be encouraged to engage in their own autobiographical (autotheoretical) writing and other creative projects.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Moral Knowledge</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00037</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Robert Stephens</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is about moral knowledge and will centre on the question, how can we come to know right from wrong? This is what philosophers refer to as a meta-ethical question, as opposed to the sorts of questions asked in normative or applied ethics  which is to say that it will look into the ontological and epistemological status of moral values. Some initial questions that will return throughout the course are the following:  What is the good?  How can we know the good?  Are moral values real in some sense?  Do moral value claims have any truth value?  Are values learned, or innate?  Do we possess the free will to live in accordance to values?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Liberal Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Critical Thinking</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00038</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Robert Stephens</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The class will investigate the nature of knowledge; how knowledge is identified and acquired; the difficulties that arise in trying to acquire it and strategies for overcoming them. Students will learn the basics tools of critical thinking, such as rhetoric, logic and argument construction in order to identify, analyse, evaluate, and produce arguments. They will apply these skills to the careful reading of arguments in everyday contexts.  Students will also learn basic concepts of epistemology and metaphysics. Students who successfully complete the course will be able to identify the fallacies (if any) in everyday arguments.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Native Ways of Knowing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00039</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Aditya Kumar Dewan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Over the past last 500 years, indigenous peoples of the world have lost much of their traditional knowledge due to invasion and colonization by non-natives. There have been attacks on their language and culture, commercialization of their art, and use of their plant knowledge in the development of medicine without their consent. However, there is still much to be learned from contemporary hunters-gatherers, since this knowledge is still used in their daily lives. This course deals with contemporary native peoples' knowledge of land and nature, resource management, environmental adaptation, herbal medicine, social and economic organization. It will examine the importance of preserving, promoting and protecting indigenous language, culture and knowledge. By examining this other system of knowledge in a multidisciplinary framework, students may better understand their own system of knowledge and its use.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Thinking Critically about the Present and the Past</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00040</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Ring</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Darwin's Tea Party</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00041</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gabriel Tordjman</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Biological knowledge, or knowledge of the living world, has been essential to human survival since the dawn of humanity and has transformed nature, society, and our ideas about who and what we are. Darwin's theory of evolution is one key example of just how powerful biological knowledge has been and continues to be, though it is just one chapter in this story. Today, biological science and technology are on the verge of triggering even more radical transformations of our environment, society, and perhaps of human nature itself. This course examines the growth and impact, use and misuse of biological knowledge, from the earliest periods to the rise of Darwin's evolutionary theory, right up to the present.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Philosophical Dilemmas</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00042</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Shi Chen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This knowledge course is an introduction to philosophical dilemmas. We will study lasting issues in philosophy, investigate interesting philosophical arguments, and explore creative ways of doing philosophy. By taking this course, students will develop and apply the essential skills of critical thinking.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Philosophical Dilemmas</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00043</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Shi Chen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This knowledge course is an introduction to philosophical dilemmas. We will study lasting issues in philosophy, investigate interesting philosophical arguments, and explore creative ways of doing philosophy. By taking this course, students will develop and apply the essential skills of critical thinking.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Problems of Philosophy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00044</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michelle Braiden</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a general introduction to fundamentals of philosophical thought and specifically looks at the way in which theories of knowledge relate to political theory.  Questions to be asked include:  What is justice?  What role do moral values play in politics?  What is human nature?  What are the origins and the end of the state?  Can a war be just?  What are the limits of governmental power?  How much liberty should citizens enjoy?  Who should rule?  What is the best form of government?  What do we mean when we talk about freedom, equality, power, authority, legitimacy, sovereignty, natural law and human rights?  How can we know the answer to these questions?  What counts as a good argument?  The basic aim of the course is to improve students critical thinking skills and their ability to analyze, develop and construct philosophical arguments.  An additional aim is to introduce students to the history of ideas and their development in Western thought.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Greek Mythology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00045</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anne Thorpe</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Studying the past is never a straightforward task and the difficulties are compounded when examining cultures like ancient Greece, from which surviving evidence is limited and produced for the most part by a narrow subset of that society. What knowledge of ancient Greece is possible then? In this course, well examine some of the material thats survived, exploring the relative usefulness of these sources in shedding light on ancient Greek culture. In particular, well consider what insights ancient Greek myth might offer us, especially when it claims to present historical events, such as the origins of the universe, the creation of men, women and the gods, and the Trojan War. These stories are fictional and often preposterous, and yet one of the central functions of myth is to reinforce and explore key cultural values. Thus, we can use these myths to glean truths about the ancient Greek value system, and through close analysis even discern which long-held beliefs were in dispute.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Judging Monarchs</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00046</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Timothy Slonosky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Was Englands Henry VIII a good king? How about the Roman Emperor Vespasian? To answer these seemingly simple questions, we must ask several more: What qualities does a good ruler possess? What actions must he or she perform? Who gets to decide which qualities and actions are good?  What information do we have about the ruler in question? Who gives us that information, and how trustworthy are they? What kind of argument and point of view is our source putting forth? Finally, how do we craft our answer so that other people will care about our response? To answer all these questions, we must combine our innate human ability to reason with the research skills necessary to uncover and evaluate historical facts.  This course will seek to answer the question of What makes a good monarch? by examining concepts of historical knowledge, determining what we can truly know about the past and how we can use that knowledge to form contemporary judgments.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.07</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">What Does It Mean To Be Human?</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00047</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Eric Van Der Wee</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">With science steadily progressing in areas such as eugenics; the increasing attention surrounding bioethical issues; and the struggle for religion and philosophy to describe the human condition in this current landscape, a definition of being human is a matter of renewed importance. This course will consider the question of what it means to be human from distinct disciplines, in an effort to build up a knowledge base for which one can answer the question: What does it mean to be Human? The purpose of this course is to help students develop an analytical perspective on the concepts of humanness and personhood and what the ramifications for society each concept brings.  It does so through an examination of the topic through different branches of learning in an effort to find a working definition of what it means to be human by looking at where the different disciplines intersect, compliment and complete each other.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Art: Interpreting the Past and the Present</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00048</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Leanne D'Antoni</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Art is used to define the boundaries of knowledge. By examining specific works of art, students will learn to identify how art conveys knowledge about a society within specific periods. We will be discussing art as it has been used to define and generate beliefs, philosophies, and knowledge of the natural and spiritual world. We will study and explore the many ways art has been used to interpret and convey knowledge, beginning with a mostly chronological discussion of art from prehistory to Medieval Europe (along with a discussion of contemporary indigenous art). We will also evaluate how art of the past has been interpreted in order to serve the needs of the present day and the powerful, and, by so doing, we will use critical thinking skills to evaluate these interpretations.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">6B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Reading the Past</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00049</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Wood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The aim of this course is to foster critical thinking about a specific field of knowledge: archaeology, the study of past material culture. The methods by which the discipline collects data, assesses evidence and builds arguments will be examined. The course will demonstrate how archaeology can be used to reconstruct ancient beliefs, answer larger questions about past societies, test the veracity of written accounts and challenge traditional reconstructions based on literary sources. It will also show how archaeological evidence can be used to construct and test theories meant to explain past trends, namely why societies collapse. Relevant case studies will be drawn from a variety of times and places, such as Rome, the ancient Near East, pre-Columbian America, the world of the Vikings and early Islamic Jordan. A section on pseudo-archaeology will allow for the critical examination of mistakes in reasoned argumentation, while studying popular conceptions about the past.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.09</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">What Does It Mean To Be Human?</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00050</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Eric Van Der Wee</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">With science steadily progressing in areas such as eugenics; the increasing attention surrounding bioethical issues; and the struggle for religion and philosophy to describe the human condition in this current landscape, a definition of being human is a matter of renewed importance. This course will consider the question of what it means to be human from distinct disciplines, in an effort to build up a knowledge base for which one can answer the question: What does it mean to be Human? The purpose of this course is to help students develop an analytical perspective on the concepts of humanness and personhood and what the ramifications for society each concept brings.  It does so through an examination of the topic through different branches of learning in an effort to find a working definition of what it means to be human by looking at where the different disciplines intersect, compliment and complete each other.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Knowledge Beyond Good and Evil</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00051</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gregory Polakoff</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In the 1880s, Nietzsche declared "God is dead," and that humanity has the freedom to envision its future without looking to a higher power. Nietzsche helped to inspire existentialism, modernism, and other movements that encourage people to break with tradition and envision knowledge that is "beyond good and evil." The course surveys writers such as Nietzsche, Hesse, Camus, Sartre, Fanon, de Beauvoir, and concepts including the "absurd hero," "the overman," and "the death of God." We will also explore the portrayal of these ideas in film and the social sciences, and how they relate to contemporary issues, such as science, technology, social change, gender, and artificial intelligence.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.06</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Knowledge Beyond Good and Evil</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00052</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gregory Polakoff</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In the 1880s, Nietzsche declared "God is dead," and that humanity has the freedom to envision its future without looking to a higher power. Nietzsche helped to inspire existentialism, modernism, and other movements that encourage people to break with tradition and envision knowledge that is "beyond good and evil." The course surveys writers such as Nietzsche, Hesse, Camus, Sartre, Fanon, de Beauvoir, and concepts including the "absurd hero," "the overman," and "the death of God." We will also explore the portrayal of these ideas in film and the social sciences, and how they relate to contemporary issues, such as science, technology, social change, gender, and artificial intelligence.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Knowledge Beyond Good and Evil</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00053</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gregory Polakoff</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In the 1880s, Nietzsche declared "God is dead," and that humanity has the freedom to envision its future without looking to a higher power. Nietzsche helped to inspire existentialism, modernism, and other movements that encourage people to break with tradition and envision knowledge that is "beyond good and evil." The course surveys writers such as Nietzsche, Hesse, Camus, Sartre, Fanon, de Beauvoir, and concepts including the "absurd hero," "the overman," and "the death of God." We will also explore the portrayal of these ideas in film and the social sciences, and how they relate to contemporary issues, such as science, technology, social change, gender, and artificial intelligence.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Examined Life</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00054</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Derrick Farnham</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">For Socrates The unexamined life is not worth living (Apology, 38a). In this Knowledge course, students will apply a logical analytical process to how knowledge is organized and used (345-101 competency). We will attempt to examine our own lives by studying his. The course will consider arguments, how to evaluate and produce them. The students logical skills will be honed, allowing a better understanding of the world and an enhanced ability to communicate and succeed. This will be done by gaining an appreciation of the reasoning abilities of Socrates. We will begin with a look at the world that Socrates was born into, Athens, the Greek myths he grew up with and the war with Sparta. We will then read some of the works of Plato, in which Socrates is the main player, and consider the debate over what we can know and what is worthwhile. The perspective taken will be the thoroughness of understanding and argumentation in establishing and refuting positions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Thinking Critically about the Present and the Past</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00055</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Ring</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Examined Life</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00056</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Derrick Farnham</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">For Socrates The unexamined life is not worth living (Apology, 38a). In this Knowledge course, students will apply a logical analytical process to how knowledge is organized and used (345-101 competency). We will attempt to examine our own lives by studying his. The course will consider arguments, how to evaluate and produce them. The students logical skills will be honed, allowing a better understanding of the world and an enhanced ability to communicate and succeed. This will be done by gaining an appreciation of the reasoning abilities of Socrates. We will begin with a look at the world that Socrates was born into, Athens, the Greek myths he grew up with and the war with Sparta. We will then read some of the works of Plato, in which Socrates is the main player, and consider the debate over what we can know and what is worthwhile. The perspective taken will be the thoroughness of understanding and argumentation in establishing and refuting positions.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.04</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Knowledge of the Human Mind and Critical Thinking about AI</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00057</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carl Saucier-Bouffard</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is based on the premise that knowledge of ones mind is the starting point and one of the main components of critical thinking. We will explore the modes of functioning of the human mind, and will critically examine the processes by which knowledge is thought to be acquired. These processes will be illustrated mainly through the case study of AI technologies. For instance, the modes of functioning of the human mind will be compared with the ways data sets are analyzed and categorized by artificial intelligence (AI) systems. To succeed in this course, students should be able to provide a sound answer to the following questions: Why do an increasing number of scholars claim that humans are predictably irrational? Given the recent developments in AI, is it legitimate to assume that humans are not currently the most rational beings?  How can we train our minds to be more rational? How can we avoid fallacious reasoning? What is a logically valid and sound argument?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Critical Thinking: Feminist Ways of Knowing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00058</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Susan-Judith Hoffmann</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">To think critically means to think for ourselves rather than let others such as parents, governments or religious institutions think for us. Critical thinking is the practice of identifying poor arguments and constructing strong arguments. We will apply critical thinking by reading some philosophical works and examine how traditional conceptions of knowledge and truth exclude women. We will also explore feminist contributions to knowledge and truth. The definition of a feminist in this context is someone who argues that equality in intellectual endeavors means examining and including, where relevant, womens perspectives and research. The goal of the course is for you to apply your critical thinking skills and your understanding of feminist thinking to knowledge itself, and to write an argumentative essay on a topic proposed by the instructor, or one you have developed on topics such as indigenous issues, racism, gender, domestic violence or educational curricula, to name just a few.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line.
