Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Sex and Death: An Introduction to Psychoanalysis</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00059</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Julian Nemeth</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Few fields of knowledge have been as influential, and controversial, as psychoanalysis. Its founder, Sigmund Freud, pioneered a revolutionary form of therapy, the talking cure, designed to help patients resolve their symptoms and free up their desire. He taught that we never really overcome our childhood. That every story we tell is also a cover story. The unconscious, the I that is another, pulls us along, sometimes catastrophically, without us realizing it. To make sense of this startling situation, psychoanalysis introduces a new way of reading, one which we will apply to works of philosophy, film, and literature. The course also asks us to interpret our own livesparticularly the seemingly marginal realm of dreams, jokes, and slips of the tongue. Sometimes derided as outdated, what remains of psychoanalysis in the 21st century? As we put the field into dialogue with feminism, queer theory, and anti-racismas well as our own so-called selvestentative answers will emerge.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.39</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Writing Life: Knowledge and the Art of Nonfiction</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00060</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joseph Rosen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course investigates the way that language and writing generate knowledge about the self. We will define knowledge in a particular way: not just as data or information about the world, but as an invitation to occupy certain subject positions. Knowledge, as we will define it, doesnt just tell us about the world: it asks us to be a certain kind of person in the world. We investigate different definitions of ideology, moving from the Marxist concept of false consciousness to the Foucauldian concept of discourse as the production of subjectivity. We will then define critical thinking as an interrogation of how we are told to be subjects.    Focusing on the personal dimension of nonfiction writing, we will look at the role knowledge plays in forming us as subjects. Final essays are a substantial part of this course and students will use what they have learned about knowledge and the personal dimension of nonfiction in order to self-reflectively address their own subject formation.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Men, Women and Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00061</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gloria Lalonde</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The objectives of this course are to examine the field of gender roles and relations in a wide variety of cultures and to examine the development of this area of knowledge. Particular attention will be paid to the questions asked in this field, the methods used to collect data, the assumptions of researchers in the field, the structure of their arguments, and how the various approaches to the study of gender roles and relations can be organized, compared, and evaluated. Content includes the relationship between biology and culture, primate research, the cultural construction of masculinity and femininity, variations in the sexual division of labour and economic organization, and cultural factors which influence the degree of gender equality in a society.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Judging Monarchs</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00062</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Timothy Slonosky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Was Englands Henry VIII a good king? How about the Roman Emperor Vespasian? To answer these seemingly simple questions, we must ask several more: What qualities does a good ruler possess? What actions must he or she perform? Who gets to decide which qualities and actions are good?  What information do we have about the ruler in question? Who gives us that information, and how trustworthy are they? What kind of argument and point of view is our source putting forth? Finally, how do we craft our answer so that other people will care about our response? To answer all these questions, we must combine our innate human ability to reason with the research skills necessary to uncover and evaluate historical facts.  This course will seek to answer the question of What makes a good monarch? by examining concepts of historical knowledge, determining what we can truly know about the past and how we can use that knowledge to form contemporary judgments.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Knowledge of the Human Mind and Critical Thinking about AI</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00063</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carl Saucier-Bouffard</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is based on the premise that knowledge of ones mind is the starting point and one of the main components of critical thinking. We will explore the modes of functioning of the human mind, and will critically examine the processes by which knowledge is thought to be acquired. These processes will be illustrated mainly through the case study of AI technologies. For instance, the modes of functioning of the human mind will be compared with the ways data sets are analyzed and categorized by artificial intelligence (AI) systems. To succeed in this course, students should be able to provide a sound answer to the following questions: Why do an increasing number of scholars claim that humans are predictably irrational? Given the recent developments in AI, is it legitimate to assume that humans are not currently the most rational beings?  How can we train our minds to be more rational? How can we avoid fallacious reasoning? What is a logically valid and sound argument?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.8</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Monsters, Madness, and Mourning: A Critical Introduction to Horror Cinema</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>18001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Jay Shea, Julian Nemeth</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Horror cinema terrifies. So why DO we take pleasure in horror? How do these genre films work? What kind of cultural work does horror do, as it summons and exercises societal demonsfrom economic injustice, to white supremacy, to patriarchy? As we pursue forbidden knowledge, well hunt down the monsterdiscovering, perhaps, that it was us all along! Dangerous difference and mirror image, monsters confront us with our deepest fears and forbidden desiressometimes leaving us unclear which is which. Along our journey into taboo territory, well test the genres limits (are psychological thrillers horror?). Well discuss the range of emotions horror films evoke and the human experiences they speak toincluding loss, mourning, and trauma. With the guidance of philosophy, literature, and our own experience, well navigate the nightmares and make sense of films including Night of the Living Dead (1968), Mulholland Drive (2001), and The Atlantics (2019). Join usif you dare!</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Reflections</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Story of Us: The Oral Tradition and Digital Culture</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>18002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Gray Miles, Rebecca Million</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Reflections</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">345-102-MQ</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">World Views</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">29 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Money</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Noah Brender</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Money makes the world go round. Every time you take cash out at an ATM, use a credit card, or buy something at the cafeteria, you are taking part in a global web of economic relations. When things go wrong in this global system, as they did in the 2008 financial crisis, all our lives are affected. And yet, few of us understand how the economy works. In this course, we will learn about the economic world we live in by studying the origins of the capitalist world view. Our textbook will be Adam Smiths landmark 1776 work, The Wealth of Nations.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Nietzsche and Dostoevsky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maia Johnson-Stepenberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the interplay of two immensely influential world views as developed by two literary giants: Friedrich Nietzsche (1844-1900) and Fyodor Dostoevsky (1821-1881). Although they never met, Nietzsche and Dostoevsky wrestled with the same issues surrounding God and morality. However, while Nietzsche announced the "death of God" as something positive enabling the liberation of man, Dostoevsky pointed to the same decline as something that must be surmounted and replaced with a still stronger faith in God. Students will thus learn to compare and contrast the world views of both Nietzsche and Dostoevsky (that is, life against God versus life with God), as both literature and philosophy.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.08</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Understanding Culture Through Artworks and Artifacts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Beverly Sing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This multidisciplinary course focuses on the examination of artworks and artifacts from different historical periods and places. Defining and examining components of a world view will be the common threads that run through the exploration of social perspectives from the Middle Ages through the present. Selected works will be discussed in the context of the cultural systems from which they came. Diverse examples chosen from the visual arts, literature, and music, as well as everyday objects will be used to determine how people defined themselves as individuals, groups or whole societies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Understanding Culture Through Artworks and Artifacts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Beverly Sing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This multidisciplinary course focuses on the examination of artworks and artifacts from different historical periods and places. Defining and examining components of a world view will be the common threads that run through the exploration of social perspectives from the Middle Ages through the present. Selected works will be discussed in the context of the cultural systems from which they came. Diverse examples chosen from the visual arts, literature, and music, as well as everyday objects will be used to determine how people defined themselves as individuals, groups or whole societies.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">A Conservative World View?</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mark Butorac</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">For almost three centuries liberalism, and its various iterations, has held sway over the West. Emphasizing the primacy of reason over tradition, the autonomy of the individual over notions of the common good, it is the world view by which West has operated, or fought against. Today, for good or ill, these ideas are receding. Yet, our metaphysical beliefs, ethics, legal infrastructure and forms of government still carry the philosophical imprints of these ideas, even if its founders have been defenestrated, its intellectual roots deracinated. This course will examine major thinkers who stand in contrast to classical liberalism, such as Burke, Coleridge, Newman, Disraeli, Babbit, Santanyana and others. Readings will be discussed in the context of movies and television series that reflect or rebut these views. In the past, the course has viewed Downton Abbey, Lord of the Rings, Narnia and others.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00006</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alexandra Law</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the relationship between world views and conceptions of justice. Students will study what justice means to different people depending on their understanding of the world. Students will examine the resulting definitions of justice and their relationship to legal systems.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Enlightened Consciousness</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00007</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Daniel Goldsmith</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">What does it mean to be enlightened? How have different religious traditions described this ultimate human potential? In this course, we will examine the world view of the perennial philosophy, which according to Ken Wilber, is the world view embraced by the vast majority of the worlds greatest spiritual teachers, philosophers, thinkers, and even scientists. This world view includes the following features: 1) the consciousness we normally identify with - our ordinary, waking self/ ego - is an illusion, 2) there is a way to correct this misperception, and 3) uncovering your true nature goes by many names, depending on your cultural background (waking up, liberation, enlightenment, union with God, etc). We will also explore the various methods and techniques that have been prescribed for those seeking their true nature. To this end, there will be a strong emphasis on practicing different forms of meditation in and out of class (calm-abiding, analytical, etc.).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Perspectives on Love</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00008</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Martine Gosselin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00009</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mendel Kramer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The World Views course introduces students to the idea of using conceptual frameworks for understanding, from culturally and historically diverse standpoints, how the world is structured, functions and develops. Students are encouraged to increase their awareness and understanding of different views of humanity and its place in the world.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Enlightened Consciousness</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00010</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Daniel Goldsmith</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">What does it mean to be enlightened? How have different religious traditions described this ultimate human potential? In this course, we will examine the world view of the perennial philosophy, which according to Ken Wilber, is the world view embraced by the vast majority of the worlds greatest spiritual teachers, philosophers, thinkers, and even scientists. This world view includes the following features: 1) the consciousness we normally identify with - our ordinary, waking self/ ego - is an illusion, 2) there is a way to correct this misperception, and 3) uncovering your true nature goes by many names, depending on your cultural background (waking up, liberation, enlightenment, union with God, etc). We will also explore the various methods and techniques that have been prescribed for those seeking their true nature. To this end, there will be a strong emphasis on practicing different forms of meditation in and out of class (calm-abiding, analytical, etc.).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00011</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alexandra Law</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the relationship between world views and conceptions of justice. Students will study what justice means to different people depending on their understanding of the world. Students will examine the resulting definitions of justice and their relationship to legal systems.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Worldviews in 1968</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00012</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Eliza Wood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In 1968 nations across the world erupted in fits of youthful rage and democratic populism on a scale that has not been seen before or since. On the streets of Paris, Chicago, Prague, New York, Beijing, Berlin, Warsaw, Mexico City, Rio de Janeiro, and London, the youth commanded attention. They rebelled for several reasons  some protested American racism, some the division of their nation, and most rejected the American War in Vietnam, the established authority, and the conservative status quo. These movements were captured by television crews who were newly able to simultaneously broadcast the unrest into living rooms. Disruption, upheaval, and violence were widespread as protesters and revolutionaries clashed with the police, the army, or invading foreign powers. In this course we will be examining, comparing, and contrasting the worldviews of those who protested and those who held power; and we will consider the degree to which our own worldviews have changed since 1968.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Medieval Civilizations</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00013</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rui De Sousa</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, we study medieval civilization across ten centuries with a special focus on the evolving Medieval world view, social and cultural institutions, and political and philosophical ideas. Among the more important themes studied will be: the decline of classical antiquity in the late Roman Empire and the contribution of classical culture to the Medieval world view; the Germanic tribal cultures and their contribution to the world view of the Middle Ages; the contributions of Islam and Byzantium; the transmission of classical learning and literature; the emergence of a new Western European society and world view during the Carolingian period; the rise of urban centers and universities in the Late Middle Ages; and the decline of medieval civilization in the 14th century. We will also place special emphasis on those areas of the medieval world view that have had a lasting impact on Western society and culture.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Liberal Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Worldviews of the Ancients</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00014</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rui De Sousa</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course we will look at the world views of the ancient Maya, Greeks and Egyptians and study in detail their respective beliefs about the cosmos and man's place in it.  Students will first be introduced to the history of our knowledge of these past civilizations and how over time our vision of them has changed in fundamental ways.  We will then discuss some of the modern methodology for the study of ancient societies and the challenges that we face in trying to understand cultures different from our own. We will also study what we know today about the history, culture and intellectual achievements of the Maya, Greeks and Egyptians.  Finally, we will examine in detail the key themes and ideas that characterize the myths, religion and literature that make up the world views of each civilization.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">A Conservative World View?</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00015</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mark Butorac</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">For almost three centuries liberalism, and its various iterations, has held sway over the West. Emphasizing the primacy of reason over tradition, the autonomy of the individual over notions of the common good, it is the world view by which West has operated, or fought against. Today, for good or ill, these ideas are receding. Yet, our metaphysical beliefs, ethics, legal infrastructure and forms of government still carry the philosophical imprints of these ideas, even if its founders have been defenestrated, its intellectual roots deracinated. This course will examine major thinkers who stand in contrast to classical liberalism, such as Burke, Coleridge, Newman, Disraeli, Babbit, Santanyana and others. Readings will be discussed in the context of movies and television series that reflect or rebut these views. In the past, the course has viewed Downton Abbey, Lord of the Rings, Narnia and others.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Worldview on Diseases</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00016</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mariam Sambe</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Enlightenment and Romanticism</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00017</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jean Colno</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">All of us have been profoundly shaped by two conflicting world views: the Enlightenment world view, which emphasizes objectivity, science, and reason, and the Romantic world view, which challenges Enlightenment assumptions by emphasizing subjectivity and strong feelings. This course explores key figures of the Enlightenment such as Locke, along with key figures of Romanticism such as Rousseau, Blake, Coleridge, and Kleist. It also examines famous works of visual art that are linked with these two intellectual movements, and one ancient play (Euripidess The Bacchae) that anticipates many of the themes emphasized by the Romantics.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Nietzsche and Dostoevsky</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00018</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maia Johnson-Stepenberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the interplay of two immensely influential world views as developed by two literary giants: Friedrich Nietzsche (1844-1900) and Fyodor Dostoevsky (1821-1881). Although they never met, Nietzsche and Dostoevsky wrestled with the same issues surrounding God and morality. However, while Nietzsche announced the "death of God" as something positive enabling the liberation of man, Dostoevsky pointed to the same decline as something that must be surmounted and replaced with a still stronger faith in God. Students will thus learn to compare and contrast the world views of both Nietzsche and Dostoevsky (that is, life against God versus life with God), as both literature and philosophy.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Perspectives on Love</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00019</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Martine Gosselin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Enlightenment and Romanticism</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00020</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jean Colno</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">All of us have been profoundly shaped by two conflicting world views: the Enlightenment world view, which emphasizes objectivity, science, and reason, and the Romantic world view, which challenges Enlightenment assumptions by emphasizing subjectivity and strong feelings. This course explores key figures of the Enlightenment such as Locke, along with key figures of Romanticism such as Rousseau, Blake, Coleridge, and Kleist. It also examines famous works of visual art that are linked with these two intellectual movements, and one ancient play (Euripidess The Bacchae) that anticipates many of the themes emphasized by the Romantics.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">An Introduction to Ideologies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00021</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sean Elliott</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Political and social life is filled with people who describe themselves with some kind of label. Some people call themselves feminist, separatist, ecologist, or conservative. Often these terms become insults.  What do these labels mean? Ideologies are sets of world views that understand social, economic and political life in a particular way, and seek to solve problems based on that said understanding. This course will examine how these world views developed historically. Have these ideologies changed or adapted over time? Who supports these ideas and why?  We will then ask deeper questions about ideology. To what extent do culture or religion influence ideas about politics? Is there a relationship between economic interests and political ideas? Do ideas matter? Is there a real diversity of values and world-views in our society, or is there rather a dominant ideology that stifles healthy debate on a wide range of issues?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">An Introduction to Ideologies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00022</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sean Elliott</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Political and social life is filled with people who describe themselves with some kind of label. Some people call themselves feminist, separatist, ecologist, or conservative. Often these terms become insults.  What do these labels mean? Ideologies are sets of world views that understand social, economic and political life in a particular way, and seek to solve problems based on that said understanding. This course will examine how these world views developed historically. Have these ideologies changed or adapted over time? Who supports these ideas and why?  We will then ask deeper questions about ideology. To what extent do culture or religion influence ideas about politics? Is there a relationship between economic interests and political ideas? Do ideas matter? Is there a real diversity of values and world-views in our society, or is there rather a dominant ideology that stifles healthy debate on a wide range of issues?</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Violence and Nonviolence</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00023</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Patricia Romano</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Beliefs about violence are important components of our world views, but, both as individuals and societies, we examine them far too rarely. In this course, we will question some of the common assumptions and justifications that support violence and war, while examining the ways in which these ideas are reinforced by powerful societal institutions. Then we will examine the perspective of an alternative world view that rejects violence on both ethical and practical grounds.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Folklore and Fairytale</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00024</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jennifer Koopman</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines how fairy tales reflect world views.  Students will investigate how these traditional narratives organize the world into coherent patterns, as they grapple with vital human matters such as sex, death, loss, abandonment, betrayal, and maturation. We will read traditional European tales from the seventeenth, eighteenth, and nineteenth centuries, with the goal of identifying the world views these narratives reflect.  We will also consider how modern versions critique and overturn older views, beliefs, and attitudes. Students will be invited to consider the implications of fairy tale, as its influence extends into a variety of domains, such as advertising, cinema, psychology, digital technology, and romantic relationships.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Perspectives on Love</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00025</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Martine Gosselin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Worldview on Diseases</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00026</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mariam Sambe</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Folklore and Fairytale</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00027</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jennifer Koopman</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines how fairy tales reflect world views.  Students will investigate how these traditional narratives organize the world into coherent patterns, as they grapple with vital human matters such as sex, death, loss, abandonment, betrayal, and maturation. We will read traditional European tales from the seventeenth, eighteenth, and nineteenth centuries, with the goal of identifying the world views these narratives reflect.  We will also consider how modern versions critique and overturn older views, beliefs, and attitudes. Students will be invited to consider the implications of fairy tale, as its influence extends into a variety of domains, such as advertising, cinema, psychology, digital technology, and romantic relationships.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Folklore and Fairytale</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00028</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jennifer Koopman</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines how fairy tales reflect world views.  Students will investigate how these traditional narratives organize the world into coherent patterns, as they grapple with vital human matters such as sex, death, loss, abandonment, betrayal, and maturation. We will read traditional European tales from the seventeenth, eighteenth, and nineteenth centuries, with the goal of identifying the world views these narratives reflect.  We will also consider how modern versions critique and overturn older views, beliefs, and attitudes. Students will be invited to consider the implications of fairy tale, as its influence extends into a variety of domains, such as advertising, cinema, psychology, digital technology, and romantic relationships.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Worldview on Diseases</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00031</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mariam Sambe</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">345-BXH-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Applied Ethics in Humanities</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">21 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Allen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course aims to explore three interrelated questions: (i) What is ethics? (ii) What ethical theories are available to us for distinguishing good from bad, and right from wrong? (iii) How can ethical theories help us to examine and resolve debated ethical issues in our society and everyday moral dilemmas in our own lives? We will begin by considering the nature of ethics itself, defining the language and basic concepts of ethics as they apply to our everyday lives and the society we live in. We will then explore four major ethical theories in the history of ethics: (i) divine command ethics; (ii) virtue ethics; (iii) deontological ethics; and (iv) utilitarianism. In the final part of the course, we will apply these ethical theories to reflections on current ethical issues such as: abortion, euthanasia, the acceptable limits of scientific research, animal rights, feminism, moral relativism, and environmental issues.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Allen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course aims to explore three interrelated questions: (i) What is ethics? (ii) What ethical theories are available to us for distinguishing good from bad, and right from wrong? (iii) How can ethical theories help us to examine and resolve debated ethical issues in our society and everyday moral dilemmas in our own lives? We will begin by considering the nature of ethics itself, defining the language and basic concepts of ethics as they apply to our everyday lives and the society we live in. We will then explore four major ethical theories in the history of ethics: (i) divine command ethics; (ii) virtue ethics; (iii) deontological ethics; and (iv) utilitarianism. In the final part of the course, we will apply these ethical theories to reflections on current ethical issues such as: abortion, euthanasia, the acceptable limits of scientific research, animal rights, feminism, moral relativism, and environmental issues.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Ethical Issues in Medicine and Health</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mendel Kramer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The objective of this course is to enable students to think, speak and write intelligently about ethical questions that arise in connection with health care. The course examines a number of ethical systems and considers how they might be applied to medicine and health. Among the issues considered are the autonomy of patients, the relationship between doctor and patient, informed consent, euthanasia, abortion and the distribution of health care.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Of interest to students in Nursing.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Desire</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Noah Brender</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Are some preferences better than others, or is there simply no accounting for taste? Should we be held responsible for our desires, or only for our actions? Is a good person someone who enjoys doing the right thing, or someone who does the right thing even though it hurts? Are our desires out of our control, or can we cultivate better desires over time? In this course, we will investigate these ethical questions by studying the contrasting answers provided by two great moral thinkers: Aristotle and Immanel Kant.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">How Can THAT Be Legal?</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alexandra Law</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course encourages students to explore the connection between law and ethics as expressed in legal theories. Students will study legal theory and legal reasoning as a way to analyze ethical issues from within a field of professional knowledge. The goal is to understand legal reasoning as one among many possible ways to ask questions and argue about moral issues.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Desire</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00006</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Noah Brender</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Are some preferences better than others, or is there simply no accounting for taste? Should we be held responsible for our desires, or only for our actions? Is a good person someone who enjoys doing the right thing, or someone who does the right thing even though it hurts? Are our desires out of our control, or can we cultivate better desires over time? In this course, we will investigate these ethical questions by studying the contrasting answers provided by two great moral thinkers: Aristotle and Immanel Kant.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">From Cruelty to Forgiveness</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00007</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Patricia Romano</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course addresses two extremes of human behavior by examining our responses, both individual and collective, to human brutality  our desire for vengeance and punishment, our search for acknowledgment and justice, and the possibility for remorse, forgiveness and reconciliation.  Students will be asked to consider their ethical responsibilities towards both victims and perpetrators, to righting old wrongs, and to reflect on how a concern with human suffering is relevant to their own field of study.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.25</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Applied Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00008</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mark Butorac</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The Applied Ethics course is designed to provide students with the basic ideas and skills of moral reasoning so that they can identify and analyze various issues, including program related ones, from an ethical perspective.
