Students become acquainted with a number of ethical theories and learn how to analyze and evaluate ethical arguments.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Ethical Issues</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00009</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jean Colno</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to some of the most influential ethical theories and concepts. It relates these general theories and concepts to specific ethical issues and debates, and it familiarizes students with key controversies in the history of ethics. By the end of the term, students will be able to identify and compare some of the central beliefs and concepts in the history of ethics. They will be able to relate these beliefs and concepts to many current debates surrounding moral issues. They will also be able to analyze various influential arguments and texts in the history of ethics. Students who complete this course successfully will also improve their reading, writing, speaking, and critical thinking skills.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Sorcerer's Feast</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00010</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sean Elliott</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Globalization is considered by some to be the defining social process of our time. The goal of this course is to look at the phenomenon of globalization and the ethical issues at stake in the process. Is this process as pervasive as some claim? If it is, what benefits or drawbacks can we distinguish in this seemingly imminent progression of events? Once we do this, we can examine topics associated with  globalization, such as the changing relationship between individual and the state, the market and public policy decisions, issues pertaining to terrorism, political protest and dissent, culture and international development. Philosophical issues to be thought about critically are historicism, modernity, human development and democracy, among others.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Ethical Issues in Medicine and Health</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00011</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mendel Kramer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The objective of this course is to enable students to think, speak and write intelligently about ethical questions that arise in connection with health care. It relates these general theories and concepts to specific ethical issues and debates, and it familiarizes students with key controversies in the history of ethics. By the end of the term, students will be able to identify and compare some of the central beliefs and concepts in the history of ethics. They will be able to relate these beliefs and concepts to many current debates surrounding moral issues. They will also be able to analyze various influential arguments and texts in the history of ethics. Students who complete this course successfully will also improve their reading, writing, speaking, and critical thinking skills.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.26</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.26</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Ethics of Resistance</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00013</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Eliza Wood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the ethical issues associated with resisting authority. Is it permissible to attempt to overthrow a violent regime? Is it ethical to choose violent means to affect change in a society or must one always use non-violent means? We will discuss and debate these, and many other questions in this course. We will learn about the different ethical theories and apply them to historical and modern examples of resistance in an attempt to decide if authority must always be obeyed or if resistance might be the more ethical choice.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Ethics of Resistance</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00014</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Eliza Wood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the ethical issues associated with resisting authority. Is it permissible to attempt to overthrow a violent regime? Is it ethical to choose violent means to affect change in a society or must one always use non-violent means? We will discuss and debate these, and many other questions in this course. We will learn about the different ethical theories and apply them to historical and modern examples of resistance in an attempt to decide if authority must always be obeyed or if resistance might be the more ethical choice.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Moral Choices in Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00015</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maia Johnson-Stepenberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Ethics course examines the Christian revolution in understanding the world and modern man's place in it. That revolution may be said to have begun with Dante Alighieri and his monumental poem The Divine Comedy (1321). This one encyclopedic text, which represents the finest flowering of the medieval age in Europe, was conceived by Dante as "the new epic of Christendom," a journey through Hell and Purgatory and Paradise that was designed to bring readers from a state of misery to one of happiness. By acquainting themselves with substantial selections from "history's greatest poem," students will acquire a direct understanding of Dante's medieval view of ethics, as well as some still older moral foundations as defined by Aristotle. Students will also be exposed to some contemporary commentaries on Dante's continued relevance to modern life.  Students will thus learn to appreciate the medieval world of ideas and values in relation to their own knowledge and experience of modernity.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Moral Choices in Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00016</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maia Johnson-Stepenberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Ethics course examines the Christian revolution in understanding the world and modern man's place in it. That revolution may be said to have begun with Dante Alighieri and his monumental poem The Divine Comedy (1321). This one encyclopedic text, which represents the finest flowering of the medieval age in Europe, was conceived by Dante as "the new epic of Christendom," a journey through Hell and Purgatory and Paradise that was designed to bring readers from a state of misery to one of happiness. By acquainting themselves with substantial selections from "history's greatest poem," students will acquire a direct understanding of Dante's medieval view of ethics, as well as some still older moral foundations as defined by Aristotle. Students will also be exposed to some contemporary commentaries on Dante's continued relevance to modern life.  Students will thus learn to appreciate the medieval world of ideas and values in relation to their own knowledge and experience of modernity.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction To Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00017</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jennifer Koopman</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course aims to explore three interrelated questions: (i) What is ethics? (ii) What ethical theories are available to us for distinguishing good from bad, and right from wrong? (iii) How can ethical theories help us to examine and resolve debated ethical issues in our society and everyday moral dilemmas in our own lives? We consider the nature of ethics itself, explore several major ethical theories in the history of ethics, and apply these ethical theories to reflections on current ethical issues such as: euthanasia, animal rights, and environmental issues. The specific topics covered in the last part of the class depend on the interests of the students taking the class in relation to their programs of study and future career choices.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">How Can THAT be Legal?</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00018</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alexandra Law</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course encourages students to explore the connection between law and ethics as expressed in legal theories. Students will study legal theory and legal reasoning as a way to analyze ethical issues from within a field of professional knowledge. The goal is to understand legal reasoning as one among many possible ways to ask questions and argue about moral issues.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Applied Ethics</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00019</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mark Butorac</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The Applied Ethics course is designed to provide students with the basic ideas and skills of moral reasoning so that they can identify and analyze various issues, including program related ones, from an ethical perspective. Students become acquainted with a number of ethical theories and learn how to analyze and evaluate ethical arguments.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Classical Approaches to Contemporary Issues</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00020</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Martine Gosselin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Ethical Issues in Medicine and Health</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00022</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mendel Kramer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The objective of this course is to enable students to think, speak and write intelligently about ethical questions that arise in connection with health care. The course examines a number of ethical systems and considers how they might be applied to medicine and health. Among the issues considered are the autonomy of patients, the relationship between doctor and patient, informed consent, euthanasia, abortion and the distribution of health care.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Illustration</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-101-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Drawing Fundamentals</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Neal Armstrong</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The focus of this course will be to marry theoretical understanding with practical experience to help students visualize and draw with confidence. Students will work from the live model (nude and clothed) to sketch and draw the figure in various contexts, as well as working from memory and visual references. They will demonstrate introductory level skills in order to progress successfully to the next term.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.25</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Neal Armstrong</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The focus of this course will be to marry theoretical understanding with practical experience to help students visualize and draw with confidence. They will demonstrate introductory level skills in order to progress successfully to the next term.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.25</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-141-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Illustrative Drawing 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Xin Ran Liu</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is an introduction to anatomical drawing for both human and animal subjects. Particular attention will be given to skeletal and muscular structures and how they shape surface appearance. Students will examine the mechanics of movement and structural aspects of drawing the figure, while developing associated drawing skills that include gesture drawing, precise linear construction, shading and composition. Hands, feet, and heads/faces will be explored in depth. By using both traditional and digital methods, students will recognize how various drawing techniques can serve for future applications in animation and medical illustration, as well as other segments of the illustration field.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:30 PM - 4:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Xin Ran Liu</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is an introduction to anatomical drawing for both human and animal subjects. Particular attention will be given to skeletal and muscular structures and how they shape surface appearance. Students will examine the mechanics of movement and structural aspects of drawing the figure, while developing associated drawing skills that include gesture drawing, precise linear construction, shading and composition. Hands, feet, and heads/faces will be explored in depth. By using both traditional and digital methods, students will recognize how various drawing techniques can serve for future applications in animation and medical illustration, as well as other segments of the illustration field.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">9:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-151-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Design Concepts for Illustration 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Pauline Fresco</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is an introduction to visual communication design, using both traditional and digital techniques. Students with learn the principles and elements of design, such as composition, balance, value, colour, pictographs, icons and typography. They will follow the standard process from research and concept to execution and presentation. An overview of the technical requirements for print and screen will be addressed.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.17</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Stphanie Aubin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is an introduction to visual communication design, using both traditional and digital techniques. Students will produce orthographic and isometric projections based on correct proportions and format, appropriate choice of viewing angles and positions, appropriate choice and execution of projections, observing proportions, scales and rules of composition, using traditional or digital illustration techniques.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mark Sy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is an introduction to technical illustration. Students will have to reproduce images as well as create their own compositions. Students will use various media and techniques, both traditional and digital, to produce illustrations with a range of tonal values.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.17</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Stphanie Aubin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course aims to apply basic principles of visual language through black and white exercises and projects. Students will use various media and techniques, both traditional and digital, to produce illustrations with a range of tonal values.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.17</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-343-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Illustrative Drawing 3</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Meinert Hansen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course continues the exploration of figure construction and animal anatomy. The students will develop a human and an animal character to be included in a preproduction for a film, game, and other motion-based media presentation, leading to a rendered keyframe - an illustrated colour story panel. Students will develop ideas through research, sketching, colour studies and digital renders. Composition of storyboard framing, lines of action, continuity of design and visual dynamism will be explored. The students will rely on visual cinematic storytelling principles throughout the project, emphasizing attention to detail in refinement of anatomy, perspective and pictorial composition.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.17</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Meinert Hansen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course continues the exploration of figure construction and animal anatomy. The students will develop a human and an animal character to be included in a preproduction for a film, game, and other motion-based media presentation, leading to a rendered keyframe - an illustrated colour story panel. Students will develop ideas through research, sketching, colour studies and digital renders. Composition of storyboard framing, lines of action, continuity of design and visual dynamism will be explored. The students will rely on visual cinematic storytelling principles throughout the project, emphasizing attention to detail in refinement of anatomy, perspective and pictorial composition.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.17</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">574-353-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Design Concepts for Illustration 3</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mark Sy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will incorporate illustration and typography in page design. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-140-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Materials & Furnishings I</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jill Hogan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is an introduction to basic material categories commonly used in interior environments, and their common industry sources and resource persons. Students are introduced to basic materials properties, characteristics and sustainability; their construction, manufacturing and installation techniques; their availability and costs; their aesthetics; and their selection criteria and applications in residential and commercial projects, including environmentally responsible choices.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jill Hogan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is an introduction to basic material categories commonly used in interior environments, and their common industry sources and resource persons. They will learn to develop creative and functional spatial solutions to design problems. This is an introductory design studio course, foundational to Interior Design II to VI, where students are introduced to the profession and related ethical issues and responsibilities.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.21</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Adolphe Tinling, Scott Millar</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The objective of this studio course is to have students identify and use the creative process to develop their design abilities with an emphasis on creative and critical thinking. This is an introductory design studio course, foundational to Interior Design II to VI, where students are introduced to the profession and related ethical issues and responsibilities.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.21</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-142-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Visual Language of Design</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anne-Marie Legault</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to drawing as a tool for documenting observed environments, ideation, and communication. Graphic standards specific to interior design and architecture will be analyzed and applied to 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional drawings at a foundational level. A variety of media will be explored to produce drawings and students will learn how to assemble sets of visual information to communicate in the language of design.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.21</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anne-Marie Legault</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to drawing as a tool for documenting observed environments, ideation, and communication. Parameters for commercial design will be developed, formalized, and integrated into increasingly complex spaces including an introduction to building code, health, safety, welfare, and sustainability. Students will explore the process of conceptualizing, developing, and validating ideas into viable design solutions both individually and as part of a team. Materials, fixtures, furnishings, and equipment (FF&E) will be specified to meet the needs of commercial spaces. Students will learn to prepare documents that effectively explain and communicate the comprehensive aspects of a design solution.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">James McCallan</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Building upon the skills and knowledge attained in Terms 1 and 2, this studio course will introduce students to the process of designing spaces for small scale mercantile and hospitality commercial use, addressing both client and end-user needs. Parameters for commercial design will be developed, formalized, and integrated into increasingly complex spaces including an introduction to building code, health, safety, welfare, and sustainability. Students will explore the process of conceptualizing, developing, and validating ideas into viable design solutions both individually and as part of a team. Materials, fixtures, furnishings, and equipment (FF&E) will be specified to meet the needs of commercial spaces. Construction drawing methodology will emphasize basic construction detailing, which will be expanded upon in subsequent Construction Documentation courses. Skills developed will form a basic understanding of the connection between design and construction. The translation of design objectives into built environments will be demonstrated through the exploration of construction requirements in a residential project, conforming to the National Building Code (NBC).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Philip Fontaine</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course uses the basic drawing skills and drawing conventions covered in Visual Language, Visual Communication I and CAD I courses, to prepare construction drawings and specifications, while developing a basic understanding of construction techniques, drawing conventions and information organization. Construction drawing methodology will emphasize basic construction detailing, which will be expanded upon in subsequent Construction Documentation courses. Skills developed will form a basic understanding of the connection between design and construction. The translation of design objectives into built environments will be demonstrated through the exploration of construction requirements in a residential project, conforming to the National Building Code (NBC).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.21</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-344-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Visual Communication II</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">James McCallan, Sandra Signe Schmitke</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Building upon knowledge acquired in Visual Communication I, drawing and modelling skills will continue to be refined and applied. Presentation techniques, both digital and traditional, will be explored and applied to more complex presentation documents. Students will learn how to adapt and apply their visual and written communication skills to address a variety of audiences. Course content will be aligned with the Interior Design III studio.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">James McCallan, Sandra Signe Schmitke</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Building upon knowledge acquired in Visual Communication I, drawing and modelling skills will continue to be refined and applied. Presentation techniques, both digital and traditional, will be explored and applied to more complex presentation documents. Students will learn how to adapt and apply their visual and written communication skills to address a variety of audiences. Course content will be aligned with the Interior Design III studio.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:30 PM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-345-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">CAD II</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Philip Fontaine</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course builds and expands upon CAD 1 to explore the application of CAD software at an intermediate/higher level. Students will continue to learn methodologies to efficiently draft designs and to produce more complex interior design documentation. An emphasis will be on the organization of complex objects, plans, elevations, sections, and details. Students will learn to integrate CAD conventions associated with interior designers/other professionals and to verify the quality, and accuracy of their work. Students will learn to output drawings through a variety of media (both traditional printing and digital) for their intended purpose.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Mark Lance Lipson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course builds and expands upon CAD 1 to explore the application of CAD software at an intermediate/higher level. Students will continue to learn methodologies to efficiently draft designs and to produce more complex interior design documentation. An emphasis will be on the organization of complex objects, plans, elevations, sections, and details. Students will learn to integrate CAD conventions associated with interior designers/other professionals and to verify the quality, and accuracy of their work. Students will learn to output drawings through a variety of media (both traditional printing and digital) for their intended purpose.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-346-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Colour & Lighting II</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Adolphe Tinling</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a scaffolded continuation of Colour and Lighting I (residential). Course objectives provide students with a more in-depth understanding of both colour and lighting as important design elements applied to commercial and public spaces.  Students will develop lighting concepts with both natural and artificial light sources. Students will apply creative processes, technical knowledge, and assemble hands-on lighting models and prototypes. This course will put emphasis on user psychological perceptions, user needs and complement spatial qualities. Students will be introduced to commercial lighting systems, daylighting components, equipment, sustainable lighting concepts, and relevant terminology. With the acquired knowledge, students will be able to apply communication conventions, specifications and create various lighting proposal documentations for a variety of built environments (related to Studios, IDIII-Retail/Restaurant, and subsequent IDIV, IDV, and IDVI).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">570-347-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Design & the Built Environment</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kurt Holfeld</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Continuing from foundational studies in Art and the Built Environment, this course will focus more specifically on architecture and the applied arts, with an emphasis on interiors. Ideas from Europe will also be observed in local examples. Meaning, significance and evolution of historic design strategies will be used as a basis for understanding contemporary contexts.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kurt Holfeld</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Continuing from foundational studies in Art and the Built Environment, this course will focus more specifically on architecture and the applied arts, with an emphasis on interiors. Accessibility, adaptable design and ergonometric principles will be introduced.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.38</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Italian</h2><div class="new dc_accordion open disciplineText  "><h2 class="dc_accordion-title highlighta"><a class="" style="" href="#important-information">Important Information</a></h2><div class="dc_accordion-body " style=""><p>Please note the prerequisites for each course. Students in doubt of their level must contact the department chairperson at local 4633 or e-mail hkaranika@dawsoncollege.qc.ca before registration.</p></div></div><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">608-111-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Italian 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">5 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nicola Martino</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of Italian, formal or informal. The course will develop four basic language skills: speaking, writing, listening comprehension, and reading comprehension. It will focus on basic grammatical structures and vocabulary, controlled and spontaneous expression, oral/written assignments, and an introduction to culture. Language learning will be enhanced through the use of various audiovisual media, as well as additional learning activities in the language lab.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">All Arts, Literature and Communication Profiles</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nicola Martino</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of Italian, formal or informal. The course will develop four basic language skills: speaking, writing, listening comprehension, and reading comprehension. It will focus on basic grammatical structures and vocabulary, controlled and spontaneous expression, oral/written assignments, and an introduction to culture. Language learning will be enhanced through the use of various audiovisual media, as well as additional learning activities in the language lab.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">All Arts, Literature and Communication Profiles</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Santina Montagano</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of Italian, formal or informal. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">608-121-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Italian Mother Tongue 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Italian Mother Tongue 1 (FOR ITALIAN SPEAKERS)</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Giorgia Sottanelli</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This elementary level course is designed for students who have a passive knowledge of the Italian language or (an) Italian dialect(s), and who wish to acquire a more formal knowledge of Italian. The course will develop four basic language skills: speaking, writing, listening comprehension, and reading comprehension. It will focus on basic grammatical structures and vocabulary, controlled and spontaneous expression, oral/written assignments, and an introduction to culture. Language learning will be enhanced through the use of various audiovisual media, as well as additional learning activities in the language lab.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">All Arts, Literature and Communication Profiles</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">608-211-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Italian 2</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Santina Montagano</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is a continuation of Italian 1. The students will learn the basic principles of quality standards applied in analytical chemistry laboratories, and will be able to follow Good Laboratory Practices (GLP). Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS) training is provided to the students, which will allow them to continue working in the chemistry laboratories. The students will learn to interpret and write Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6A.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">210-112-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Basic Laboratory Techniques</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Isabelle Dionne</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course focuses on the preparation and standardization of solutions for use in analytical procedures. Students will acquire basic laboratory skills on the proper use of balances and pipettes, and be able to perform volumetric titration, dilution, and solution transfer. The course will emphasize the use of calculations and statistical tools associated with treating experimental data. These skills will be applied to the analyses of environmental and industrial samples.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">6A.20</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:00 AM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6A.20</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Isabelle Dionne</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course focuses on the preparation and standardization of solutions for use in analytical procedures. They will perform spectrometric analyses using the following techniques: atomic, UV-vis and IR spectrometry, and fluorometry. The theoretical background will be provided for each technique. The students will be able to identify the different parts and components of spectrometers, and learn their functions. The students will also learn to operate the instruments using quality control methods, and to be able to interpret the analysis results.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">6A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Silja Makinen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, the students will learn the uses and applications of various spectrophotometers. They will perform spectrometric analyses using the following techniques: atomic, UV-vis and IR spectrometry, and fluorometry. The theoretical background will be provided for each technique. The students will be able to identify the different parts and components of spectrometers, and learn their functions.
