4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Hospital</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Religion</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">370-102-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to World Religions</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">5 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ivan Freud</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the major elements of religion. It maps religious diversity by surveying the places and spaces that at least two major religious traditions regard as sacred. It investigates prominent aspects of both personal spirituality and the relationship between religion and society by analyzing selected ritual practices, symbolic representations (in art and decoration), texts, beliefs and social structures. This course will also introduce students to some major theorists of religion and some methods for analyzing selected religious phenomena.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ivan Freud</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the major elements of religion. It maps religious diversity by surveying the places and spaces that at least two major religious traditions regard as sacred. It investigates prominent aspects of both personal spirituality and the relationship between religion and society by analyzing selected ritual practices, symbolic representations (in art and decoration), texts, beliefs and social structures. This course will also introduce students to some major theorists of religion and some methods for analyzing selected religious phenomena.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.21</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Natalie Kepka</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the major elements of religion. It maps religious diversity by surveying the places and spaces that at least two major religious traditions regard as sacred. It investigates prominent aspects of both personal spirituality and the relationship between religion and society by analyzing selected ritual practices, symbolic representations (in art and decoration), texts, beliefs and social structures. This course will also introduce students to some major theorists of religion and some methods for analyzing selected religious phenomena.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Natalie Kepka</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the major elements of religion. It maps religious diversity by surveying the places and spaces that at least two major religious traditions regard as sacred. It investigates prominent aspects of both personal spirituality and the relationship between religion and society by analyzing selected ritual practices, symbolic representations (in art and decoration), texts, beliefs and social structures. This course will also introduce students to some major theorists of religion and some methods for analyzing selected religious phenomena.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Temple</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00005</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Johanne Rabbat</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The Introduction to World Religions examines the various beliefs, features, practices, developments and artforms of the world's major religions, such as Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Hinduism and Buddhism. We will examine the basic building blocks of religion with a special focus on temples. The temple is where law is made, rituals held, politics practiced, monuments built, the mind and the body meet. Through ancient and modern worlds, Classics and Religion convene to explore this structure in the classroom and the field. Throughout the semester, this course will thus meet with the Introduction to Classics course which will also focus on the temple. Come explore with us! We will take students to two special, three hour, fieldtrips, allowing us to end the course a week early: Wednesday, October 5th 2022: Museum Visit 6-9pm   Saturday, October 29th 2022: Temple Visit 1-4pm</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">COMPRESSED: August 18 - November 24, 2022<br>Plus two field trips - travel time not included: October 5, 2022 18:00-21:00, and October 29, 2022 13:00-16:00 MTL_AREA</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Wednesday, September 7, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Aug 18, 2022</td><td data-label="End Date">Nov 24, 2022</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Aug 18, 2022</td><td data-label="End Date">Nov 24, 2022</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Oct 05, 2022</td><td data-label="End Date">Oct 05, 2022</td><td data-label="Time">6:00 PM - 9:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Montreal Area</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Saturday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Oct 29, 2022</td><td data-label="End Date">Oct 29, 2022</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Montreal Area</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">370-121-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Sacred Writings</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Laurence Nixon</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Tanakh, the Bible and the Qur'an are the central documents and inspirations of the religious and ethical traditions of Judaism, Christianity and Islam, respectively. This course introduces students to these sacred writings and aims to provide the foundation for an understanding of the many aspects of their importance. Students will become acquainted with these texts, their history, translation and scholarship, examining many of their historical, philosophical and moral themes and tracing some of their major influences in literature and culture.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Liberal Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">370-219-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Topics in Religion</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Sex and Gender</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sonia Zylberberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the relationships between religion, sexuality, and gender.  We will compare attitudes towards sexuality and gender within different religions and analyze the mutual relationship between sexuality and gender in each religion. We will also look at how these attitudes form the basis for social and cultural gender roles that become entrenched in societies and are very resistant to change.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">370-917-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Cults and Culture</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sonia Zylberberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The course explores the origins, beliefs, rituals and social organizations of some of the new religious movements that contribute to the religious landscape of North America. Sociological, historical and psychological approaches will be employed in the study.  Among other subjects, the course will discuss theories of conversion, the brainwashing/deprogramming controversy, charismatic authority and the ritual processes within these sects. The contentious status of Scientology, the Wiccan and the Raelian traditions will be analyzed, as will their relationships to their host societies. This course represents a scientific and academic study of New Religious Movements and as such maintains a safe and structured environment for students.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">370-BWS-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Religion Studies</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">5 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to World Religions</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ivan Freud</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the major elements of religion, and how it contributes to an understanding of contemporary issues. It maps religious diversity by surveying the places and spaces that at least two major religious traditions regard as sacred. It investigates prominent aspects of both personal spirituality and the relationship between religion and society by analyzing selected ritual practices, symbolic representations (in art and decoration), texts, beliefs and social structures. This course will also introduce students to some major theorists of religion and some methods for analyzing selected religious phenomena.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.13</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Introduction to World Religions</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ivan Freud</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the major elements of religion, and how it contributes to an understanding of contemporary issues. We will examine the basic building blocks of religion with a special focus on temples. The temple is where law is made, rituals held, politics practiced, monuments built, the mind and the body meet. Through ancient and modern worlds, Classics and Religion convene to explore this structure in the classroom and the field. Throughout the semester, this course will thus meet with the Introduction to Classics course which will also focus on the temple. Come explore with us! We will take students to two special, three-hour field trips, allowing us to end the course a week early: Wednesday, October 5, 2022: Museum Visit 6-9 pm   Saturday, October 29, 2022: Temple Visit 1-4 pm.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">COMPRESSED: August 18 - November 24, 2022<br>Plus two field trips - travel time not included: October 5, 2022 18:00-21:00, and October 29, 2022 13:00-16:00   MTL AREA</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Wednesday, September 7, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Aug 18, 2022</td><td data-label="End Date">Nov 24, 2022</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Aug 18, 2022</td><td data-label="End Date">Nov 24, 2022</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Oct 05, 2022</td><td data-label="End Date">Oct 05, 2022</td><td data-label="Time">6:00 PM - 9:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Montreal Area</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Saturday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Oct 29, 2022</td><td data-label="End Date">Oct 29, 2022</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Montreal Area</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">370-BXS-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Social science: applications in religion studies</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Eastern Paths to Enlightenment - Buddha, Yoga, and the Dao</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Ivan Freud</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course we will analyze the paths to enlightenment, or self-transformation, of some of the following Asian religions: Hinduism, Jainism, Sikhism, Buddhism, Daoism and Confucianism. After an initial survey of the beliefs and rituals of the religions chosen, the focus will be on: (1) religious, or mystical, experiences; and (2) the stages of personal transformation into a sage, saint, or enlightened being.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">7A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Research Methodology & Integrated Seminar</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">300-121-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Research Methods: Research in Liberal Arts Disciplines</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Beverly Sing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the use of research methods, especially those used by historians. It aims to instill a sense of how expository prose should be written, a familiarity with the uses of the modern library and a grasp of the requirements of scholarly integrity. Students use selected texts as guides in the preparation and writing of a model research paper on a topic assigned in one of the concurrent courses in the first term. The emphasis on research links this Methods course to the English, Philosophy and Classics courses given in the same term.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Liberal Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">300-300-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Research Methods</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">14 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Richard Soare</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the first of the three (3) methodology courses and is normally taken in the student's second term of the program. The goal of the course is to apply the scientific approach to the various social science disciplines. Students identify a research problem and follow the steps to select a research method appropriate to the problem, produce a data collection tool, collect, analyze and interpret the data. The culmination of the process is a research report that presents the research steps in the context of a brief literature review of the topic.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.17</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Richard Soare</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the first of the three (3) methodology courses and is normally taken in the student's second term of the program. The goal of the course is to apply the scientific approach to the various social science disciplines. Students identify a research problem and follow the steps to select a research method appropriate to the problem, produce a data collection tool, collect, analyze and interpret the data. The culmination of the process is a research report that presents the research steps in the context of a brief literature review of the topic.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carolina Pineda</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the first of the three (3) methodology courses and is normally taken in the student's second term of the program. The goal of the course is to apply the scientific approach to the various social science disciplines. Students identify a research problem and follow the steps to select a research method appropriate to the problem, produce a data collection tool, collect, analyze and interpret the data. The culmination of the process is a research report that presents the research steps in the context of a brief literature review of the topic.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00004</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Carolina Pineda</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is the first of the three (3) methodology courses and is normally taken in the student's second term of the program. You will read, summarize and analyze academic sources on two different aspects of your passion and have a taste of multidisciplinary study in social sciences.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Commerce<br>This section is compatible and available for International Business Studies.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.24</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Economics and/or Politics as Catalysts of Social Transition</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michel Mayer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Social Transition means the time when societies evolve from one manner of being to another. Examples would be the transition that took place during the change from communism to capitalism in Eastern Europe in the early 90s or the Arab Spring of late 2010. We need to look at what happened before, during and after the Transition. How did things change during this time, how (why) did economic or political factors play a role? Ex: did economic hardship encourage people to bring about this change or did political instability drive people into the streets. You may focus on any time period in any region of the globe and look at any aspect of society. You must pick a major Social Transition that occurred and affected society or a large fragment of society. Your only limitation should in fact be your areas of interests. Also, you must use 2 of the following 7 Social Science disciplines: economics, sociology, psychology, history, political science, geography and anthropology.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Commerce</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2F.24</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">300-308-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Integrative Seminar</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">14 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00021</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Katarzyna Wolfson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students in the Social Science Program take this course in their final term after having passed Research Methods (300-300-DW) and Quantitative Methods (360-300-DW). The Integrative Seminar provides the student with an opportunity to consider how the various social sciences can work together to contribute to understanding social phenomena. Using at least three (3) social science disciplines, students will explore a topic related to the seminar theme in a series of distinct stages, ultimately producing a long essay on this exploration. This integrative project will address some of the linkages and differences among social sciences and show how their combined use makes for a deeper understanding of the selected topic.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00022</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Verity Whalen</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students in the Social Science Program take this course in their final term after having passed Research Methods (300-300-DW) and Quantitative Methods (360-300-DW). The Integrative Seminar provides the student with an opportunity to consider how the various social sciences can work together to contribute to understanding social phenomena. Using at least three (3) social science disciplines, students will explore a topic related to the seminar theme in a series of distinct stages, ultimately producing a long essay on this exploration. This integrative project will address some of the linkages and differences among social sciences and show how their combined use makes for a deeper understanding of the selected topic.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Contemporary Threats to Liberal Democracy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00023</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Donal Gill, Michel Fournier-Simard</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course seeks to investigate the stability of governing institutions across liberal democracies in the 21st century. Contemporary challenges facing liberal democracies around the world today will be analyzed through a multidisciplinary social scientific perspective. The course will engage social science disciplines such as political science, sociology, history, psychology, economics etc. to assist in the writing of a research paper that investigates a core issue related to democratic values, governance and consolidation. Students will write a research paper on liberal democracy and democratic consolidation/deconsolidation before pursuing independent research on a related topic of their choosing.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">International Business Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Contemporary Threats to Liberal Democracy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00024</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Donal Gill, Michel Fournier-Simard</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course seeks to investigate the stability of governing institutions across liberal democracies in the 21st century. Contemporary challenges facing liberal democracies around the world today will be analyzed through a multidisciplinary social scientific perspective. The course will engage social science disciplines such as political science, sociology, history, psychology, economics etc. to assist in the writing of a research paper that investigates a core issue related to democratic values, governance and consolidation. Students will write a research paper on liberal democracy and democratic consolidation/deconsolidation before pursuing independent research on a related topic of their choosing.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">International Business Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Deviance</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00025</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Beer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Deviance refers to any behaviour that violates cultural norms. All societies and historical eras define deviance differently, but every society is invested in identifying individuals or groups considered deviant, and these groups become justifiable targets of social control, be it through treatment, punishment, or stigmatization. In this course, students will choose a phenomenon, behaviour, or group that has been considered deviant in some context. Drawing on three Social Science disciplines, students will explore when, how, and why this form of deviance has been constructed as such. Students will situate their chosen phenomenon in social, historical, or geographic context, and examine the political, religious, economic, or cultural changes that have shaped social views and responses to it.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Deviance</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00026</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Beer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Deviance refers to any behaviour that violates cultural norms. All societies and historical eras define deviance differently, but every society is invested in identifying individuals or groups considered deviant, and these groups become justifiable targets of social control, be it through treatment, punishment, or stigmatization. In this course, students will choose a phenomenon, behaviour, or group that has been considered deviant in some context. Drawing on three Social Science disciplines, students will explore when, how, and why this form of deviance has been constructed as such. Students will situate their chosen phenomenon in social, historical, or geographic context, and examine the political, religious, economic, or cultural changes that have shaped social views and responses to it.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Psychology</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Global Issues and Social Movements</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00027</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Diane Shea</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The Integrative Seminar is a multidisciplinary course in which students integrate three different Social Science disciplines in their final project. The theme of this section is Global Issues and Social Movements.  Globalization has created a very integrated global community linked through the internet, the economy and international organizations.  Events in any one country now have global repercussions. In Bangladesh and other developing countries, sweatshop workers make the clothes that we buy in Canada. Wars in Africa and the Middle East have created a crisis for those seeking refuge. The environmental movement, #MeToo, Black Lives Matter, Indigenous Resurgence and other movements for human rights and social justice reverberate on a global scale.  Students will be asked to develop a research paper analyzing a global issue or social movement of interest to the student. Potential topics will be discussed in class.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.9</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">City Limits</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00028</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Julie Johnson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Many people around the world live in an urban environment. Since ancient times, cities have formed, grown, and even collapsed; in this way, they are dynamic physical spaces. But cities are much more than this. Urban spaces are also political, psychological, and socio-economic environments. They can be sites of liberation, celebration, and cultural vitality, as well as places of oppression, division, and resistance. Thought about in this way, the city can be fruitful ground for interdisciplinary research and inquiry. What are the limits of urban space? How do people live within these spaces, and perhaps even transgress their boundaries? In this course, students will explore some of these limits, from ways of imagining the city to ways of being in the city. Students will examine the issue through multiple social science disciplines.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">City Limits</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00029</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Julie Johnson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Many people around the world live in an urban environment. Urban spaces are also political, psychological, and socio-economic environments. They can be sites of liberation, celebration, and cultural vitality, as well as places of oppression, division, and resistance. 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Youth and Neighborhood</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00031</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nancy Rebelo</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Neighbourhood is where home, school, services, and even friendships converge. As such, our most basic experiences and identities are often linked to the neighbourhood in which we grow up. In this course, students will explore how experiences of neighbourhood impact child development through three different social science disciplines. Students may choose to investigate themes such as social housing, food access, community support (health, social, recreational), urban vs. suburban, causes and consequences of neighbourhood-based social inequalities, etc. They may also choose a particular neighbourhood, in Montreal or elsewhere, to investigate its strengths and weaknesses related to child development. Students interested in pursuing careers in social services, education, or urban studies will have a chance to take a deeper look at these key issues related to how to create neighbourhoods that promote health, safety, inclusion, and happiness for children and families.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Indigenous Canada</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00032</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Duckett</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students choose their own topic under the category of Canadas First Nations, Inuit, and Metis. The course begins with an overview of a number of possible topics, from the earliest, pre-contact period to the present day. Students will choose topics that interest them and that they find are important for people to understand more fully. For their social science disciplines to be used, students may choose whichever three they want as long as they can explain their relevance to their chosen topic and can find sufficient material when doing their preliminary research report.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Indigenous Canada</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00033</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Michael Duckett</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students choose their own topic under the category of Canadas First Nations, Inuit, and Metis. Students will choose topics that interest them and that they find are important for people to understand more fully. For their social science disciplines to be used, students may choose whichever three they want as long as they can explain their relevance to their chosen topic and can find sufficient material when doing their preliminary research report.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5B.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00035</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Calogero Miceli</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students in the Social Science Program take this course in their final term after having passed Research Methods (300-300-DW) and Quantitative Methods (360-300-DW). The Integrative Seminar provides the student with an opportunity to consider how the various social sciences can work together to contribute to understanding social phenomena. Using at least three (3) social science disciplines, students will explore a topic related to the seminar theme in a series of distinct stages, ultimately producing a long essay on this exploration. This integrative project will address some of the linkages and differences among social sciences and show how their combined use makes for a deeper understanding of the selected topic.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.19</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Social Service</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">360-951-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Professional Integration 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Heidi Gumbley, Patricia Murphy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Diagnostic Imaging</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Heidi Gumbley, Patricia Murphy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Diagnostic Imaging</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.12</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.11</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 2:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3A.6</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">388-112-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Social Service Practice</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alyssa Kuzmarov</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces the student to the practice of social service work. It aims to identify and examine various components of practice such as what the social service worker does, where they practice and the areas of knowledge they must develop.  The means through which social service workers achieve the goal of empowering those who use services are analyzed. An important part of the course examines the place of values in social service, including professional values and their relationship to personal or societal values. Learning activities include many participatory and experiential activities. Some activities of the course prepare the student for their first fieldwork experience in second semester.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marie-Eve Dufour</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces the student to the practice of social service work. It aims to identify and examine various components of practice such as what the social service worker does, where they practice and the areas of knowledge they must develop.  The means through which social service workers achieve the goal of empowering those who use services are analyzed. An important part of the course examines the place of values in social service, including professional values and their relationship to personal or societal values. Learning activities include many participatory and experiential activities. Some activities of the course prepare the student for their first fieldwork experience in second semester.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2B</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Patricia Murphy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces the student to the practice of social service work. Students will learn how to assess clients' needs, both met and unmet, and identify types of resources that would assist those seeking help to develop their potential by meeting their specific needs. Through the use of case scenarios, students will practice needs assessment and various methods for finding resources that respond to particular problem situations. There will also be opportunity to visit community agencies to learn about services available in our community.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Shimmon Hutchinson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students are introduced to the social service field, in particular to the needs of the populations served by social service workers and the social organizations and public agencies that respond to these needs. The course is structured to provide students with the opportunity to engage with peers and teachers, to develop relationships and to integrate quickly into the social service program. Students will gain knowledge and skills to become effective communicators within the helping relationships they will form as future social service workers. The elements of interpersonal communication, the impact of culture on communication, as well as techniques such as attending, paraphrasing and empathizing will be addressed. Expressing oneself assertively to meet one's own needs while being other-oriented and respecting the needs and rights of others will be practiced. An important part of the course is to develop more aware of oneself as a communicator, and students will learn to assess their own communication style and the impact of this style on others.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Wednesday, August 10, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Aug 08, 2022</td><td data-label="End Date">Aug 08, 2022</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Start Date">Aug 15, 2022</td><td data-label="End Date">Aug 15, 2022</td><td data-label="Time">1:30 PM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Intensive</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">388-115-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Addressing Social Problems I</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Shimmon Hutchinson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course addresses prevalent social problems in Canada, such as poverty and social inequality, racism, colonization, xenophobia, and gender inequality. Students will learn to analyze the causes and manifestations of social problems using different theoretical perspectives. They will begin to understand the impact of these social problems on people's lives from a strengths-based and empathic perspective. The knowledge gained in this course forms a foundation on which to build the student's understanding of the connections between individual experience and social location, and the larger society, as well as the meaning this has for their future practice as social service workers. Through their research on a specific social problem, students will develop college level academic skills (library research, evaluation of reliable sources, critical thinking, APA standards).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Yaffa Elling</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course addresses prevalent social problems in Canada, such as poverty and social inequality, racism, colonization, xenophobia, and gender inequality. Students will learn to analyze the causes and manifestations of social problems using different theoretical perspectives. They will begin to understand the impact of these social problems on people's lives from a strengths-based and empathic perspective. The knowledge gained in this course forms a foundation on which to build the student's understanding of the connections between individual experience and social location, and the larger society, as well as the meaning this has for their future practice as social service workers. Through their research on a specific social problem, students will develop college level academic skills (library research, evaluation of reliable sources, critical thinking, APA standards).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4E.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00003</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marti Miller</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course addresses prevalent social problems in Canada, such as poverty and social inequality, racism, colonization, xenophobia, and gender inequality. Students will learn to analyze the causes and manifestations of social problems using different theoretical perspectives. They will begin to understand the impact of these social problems on people's lives from a strengths-based and empathic perspective. The knowledge gained in this course forms a foundation on which to build the student's understanding of the connections between individual experience and social location, and the larger society, as well as the meaning this has for their future practice as social service workers. Through their research on a specific social problem, students will develop college level academic skills (library research, evaluation of reliable sources, critical thinking, APA standards).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">388-116-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Social Welfare and Legislation</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Shimmon Hutchinson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course focuses on social welfare, policies, and social laws. Their connection to social problems and their impact on people's lives will be examined as well as responses through various types of intervention with a focus on the role of social work. Students will gain a working knowledge of current social security programs and selected laws in Quebec and Canada in order to prepare them for fieldwork.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Shimmon Hutchinson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course focuses on social welfare, policies, and social laws. The course continues the process of personal and professional self-awareness in relation to the student's own family. Students will learn the major theories of family functioning with a view to gaining greater insight into the complex issues faced by families in Canada today. Students will learn how to assess a family from a family systems perspective, with an emphasis on the strengths based approach. An examination of personal attitudes, beliefs, and values will help students develop an appreciation and understanding of diverse family forms and experiences.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.45</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Cindy Mitchell</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces the student to the importance family dynamics, family history and social location, both for our clients and ourselves as professionals.
