The first is the weekly fieldwork placement which offers a full day of social service experience in a selected agency that will continue into the next semester's fieldwork course. Students are supervised in their field setting by an on-site supervisor.  A wide variety of settings are available for fieldwork training. The second component is the weekly two-hour fieldwork seminar where students have an opportunity to meet in groups with their field liaison teacher for mutual support and guided learning regarding their experiences in the fieldwork setting. The third component is the weekly two-hour professional writing workshop. Here students will learn the most important elements of professional written communication in social service work. Students will learn how to write case notes, reports, letters, and how to manage the paperwork of the profession.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Stage</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Patricia Murphy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This dynamic course consists of three distinct and related components. Students will demonstrate this ability by developing a comprehensive groupwork proposal and plan. The course draws on learning gained in 1st year, particularly the course Introduction to Intervention. Students will develop skills in conducting interviews with individuals. These include beginning skills needed for intake interviews and assessment, as well as for making referrals, contracting and the development of a service plan. Skills to support people in problem solving efforts, in effecting change, as well as intervening with people in their environments will be developed. Lastly, ending interview skills will also be addressed.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2B</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rachel Deutsch</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The focus in this 2nd year course is on building psychosocial intervention skills with individuals. Gender development, sexual diversity and orientation issues are examined as they impact the practice of social service work. Students will gain an understanding of the processes of illness from early childhood to later life cycles. Included in the course are theoretical concepts of loss, death and dying and their relationship to social service work. The process of aging and its impact on the elderly and their family is explored in relation to theoretical concepts and issues, programs and services, individual experiences, coping mechanisms, with a focus on social service practice within various settings.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.45</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Health, Illness, and Aging</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Patricia Murphy</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Health, Illness & Aging is the subtitle for this course in which students study concepts of mental and physical health through various stages of life. Gender development, sexual diversity and orientation issues are examined as they impact the practice of social service work. Students will gain an understanding of the processes of illness from early childhood to later life cycles. Included in the course are theoretical concepts of loss, death and dying and their relationship to social service work. The process of aging and its impact on the elderly and their family is explored in relation to theoretical concepts and issues, programs and services, individual experiences, coping mechanisms, with a focus on social service practice within various settings.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.23</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">388-504-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Practice Models</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marti Miller</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students study selected models and approaches to social service practice and apply these to real and simulated case situations.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Marti Miller</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students study selected models and approaches to social service practice and apply these to real and simulated case situations.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">388-512-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Crisis Intervention</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Leah Woolner</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">How does one cope when life becomes overwhelming?  How can you help a person who feels like they have no hope?  How do you deal with someone who is suicidal?  Who has lost a loved one?  Who is experiencing a turning point in their struggle with dependence on drugs or gambling?  These are some of the challenging situations a social service worker may encounter that are explored in this course through the theory and practice of crisis intervention.  The course provides a step by step intervention process to help workers feel confident even in the most difficult cases.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Spinner</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">How does one cope when life becomes overwhelming?  How can you help a person who feels like they have no hope?  How do you deal with someone who is suicidal?  Who has lost a loved one?  Who is experiencing a turning point in their struggle with dependence on drugs or gambling?  These are some of the challenging situations a social service worker may encounter that are explored in this course through the theory and practice of crisis intervention.  The course provides a step by step intervention process to help workers feel confident even in the most difficult cases.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2B</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">388-513-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Intervention with Mandated Clienteles</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Yaffa Elling</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will examine the knowledge and skills required to respond to the needs of clients who are legally mandated to receive help from social service workers.  Students will be introduced to basic legal principles, acquire knowledge of court procedures, and the advocacy and intervention skills necessary to support clients whose problems relate to laws or legal issues. Students will gain detailed knowledge of laws that relate to social service clients such as the Quebec Youth Protection Act, the Youth Criminal Justice Act,  the Quebec Mental Health Act, the Public Curator's Act, and the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.  Students will also learn and practice the psychosocial assessment and intervention skills required to work with clients whose lives are affected by these laws.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.02</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Yaffa Elling</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will examine the knowledge and skills required to respond to the needs of clients who are legally mandated to receive help from social service workers.  Students will be introduced to basic legal principles, acquire knowledge of court procedures, and the advocacy and intervention skills necessary to support clients whose problems relate to laws or legal issues. Students will gain detailed knowledge of laws that relate to social service clients such as the Quebec Youth Protection Act, the Youth Criminal Justice Act,  the Quebec Mental Health Act, the Public Curator's Act, and the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.  Students will also learn and practice the psychosocial assessment and intervention skills required to work with clients whose lives are affected by these laws.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:30 PM - 3:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2B</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">388-534-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Fieldwork 4</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rachel Deutsch</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, the student will engage in an internship at a field placement for 2  days per week, as well as participate in a weekly 2 hour field seminar at the college. This field practice course aims to offer students the opportunity to proceed to a more advanced level of social service practice using a generalist approach. The student will also have the opportunity to consolidate and build on the knowledge, professional values and skills acquired over the first two years of the program.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Stage</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.10</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Stage</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">9:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">Stage</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Felicia D'Orve</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, the student will engage in an internship at a field placement for 2  days per week, as well as participate in a weekly 2 hour field seminar at the college. text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">388-BWS-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Social Science 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Power of Non-Violent Communication</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Alyssa Kuzmarov</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will help you to build non-violent communication skills at both personal and community levels. From a social (service) work perspective, the issue of non-violence and how we can promote a society based on valuing dignity and respect of individuals and groups will be explored. Looking at how individuals and groups can meet their needs using alternatives to violence will be a focus. Students will then be introduced to, and practice, non-violent communication skills including assertiveness, listening, conflict-resolution and emotional management. The course will then ask students to explore how the issue of non-violence is being addressed at the community level. Students will familiarize themselves with community initiatives both within Dawson College and Montreal as well as other parts of the country and the world.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">388-BXS-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Social Science: Ensemble 2</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">The Role of Alcohol in Society</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Spinner</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will help you to develop an understanding of the role that alcohol plays in our society. You will learn about alcohol and addiction from a social work perspective as it affects individuals, families, communities, and our society as a whole. This course will provide you with a theoretical foundation in the field of addiction. It will also explore current social science research and practice within the field.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3H.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table --><h2>Sociology</h2><div class="course-list-table"><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-101-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Individual and Society</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">13 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Elliot Kerr</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the basic ideas and perspectives of sociological investigation and interpretation. It focuses on the ways individuals are shaped by and respond to culture and social organization. Students are introduced to the major areas of sociological research, including representative studies and their findings about Canada, Quebec and other societies, in order to provide a systematic understanding of the contemporary social world.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2P.14</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Laura Shea</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to the basic ideas and perspectives of sociological investigation and interpretation. We will also examine larger social structures such as the State and Capitalism as social problems. Although we will discuss these issues within a broad Canadian context, we will focus on these social problems in relation to Indigenous-Settler relations in Canada.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.11</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-212-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">The Family</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teachers</label><div class="col-md-10">Carlos Velasquez Buritica, Isher-Paul Sahni</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Marriage and the family are institutions found in every society and an important part of almost everyone's life. This course focuses on a variety of issues related to marriage and the family, including dating, courtship and mate  selection, child rearing, parenting, marital stability and marital break-up. It also examines the family as it appears in different cultures around the world, with the main focus on the modern urban family.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-216-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Education</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Elliot Kerr</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Whether student, teacher, parent, or taxpayer, we are all affected by our education system and many of us have strong opinions about that system. This course provides a broad examination of education and the education  system from a variety of perspectives: as a set of activities; as an institutional form; as a set of ideologies, values, and beliefs; and as a setting within which people such as students and teachers come to terms with one another and  learn to understand themselves and others.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Elliot Kerr</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Whether student, teacher, parent, or taxpayer, we are all affected by our education system and many of us have strong opinions about that system. This course provides a broad examination of education and the education  system from a variety of perspectives: as a set of activities; as an institutional form; as a set of ideologies, values, and beliefs; and as a setting within which people such as students and teachers come to terms with one another and  learn to understand themselves and others.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Child Studies</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-219-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Sociology of Law</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jennifer Sigouin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the law as a social phenomenon. Particular areas of focus are on the evolution of modern legal systems, the emergence of the modern legal profession, current controversies with respect to such matters  as civil rights or the regulation of sexuality, and the implications of post-industrialization and globalization on legal systems and issues such as human rights and citizenship.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.26</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4P.26</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Jennifer Sigouin</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course examines the law as a social phenomenon. Particular areas of focus are on the evolution of modern legal systems, the emergence of the modern legal profession, current controversies with respect to such matters  as civil rights or the regulation of sexuality, and the implications of post-industrialization and globalization on legal systems and issues such as human rights and citizenship.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Law, Society and Justice</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5A.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-311-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Social Deviance</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Donald Shawn Berry</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Social deviance refers to criminal and non-criminal behaviours that evoke negative reactions ranging from mild disapproval to widespread condemnation.  This course examines a variety of deviant behaviours, their causes and the responses of various agents of social control, including the police and courts.  The major sociological perspectives on deviance serve as a focus for discussion, and particular attention is paid to deviance in contemporary Canadian society.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-314-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Sexuality and Society</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Beer</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores sexual attitudes, behaviours, and ideologies. The course will focus on the social construction of masculine and feminine sexuality in Quebec and Canada. Topics covered in the course include, sexual violence, romantic love and dating, sexual life cycle, homosexuality, sex education, and the data on health and sexuality.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">4:00 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.1</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-401-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Advanced Studies in Sociology</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Sociology of Food and the Environment</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anna-Liisa Aunio</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">No description available at this time</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.7</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-980-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Sociology of Health Care</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Laura Shea</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will introduce nursing students to the sociology of health care and examine the social contexts within which individuals experience and interpret health, illness, and health care. Throughout the course, students will be encouraged to consider the diverse ways in which social categories such as sex, gender, race, ethnicity, and social class affect health, illness, and health care. Students will also explore the relationship between these categories and professional roles within the health care system. Students will examine how culture influences and impacts health and health care for individuals, families and whole societies. As well, students will be encouraged to reflect on and engage in discussion and debate concerning the ways in which the course material may impact nursing practice and the nursing profession.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Nursing</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Laura Shea</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will introduce nursing students to the sociology of health care and examine the social contexts within which individuals experience and interpret health, illness, and health care. Throughout the course, students will be encouraged to consider the diverse ways in which social categories such as sex, gender, race, ethnicity, and social class affect health, illness, and health care. The importance of recreation in today's society and its effects on the individual and community will be examined.  The course will also explore changes in Quebec society and their effects on recreational activities.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">C.R.L.T<br>COMPRESSED: August 18  14:00-16:00; September 13 to November 24, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Wednesday, September 28, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">387-991-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Research Methods for Recreation</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Anna-Liisa Aunio</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The aim of this course is to explore the differences between casual and scientific research. The course will develop four basic language skills: speaking, writing, listening comprehension, and reading comprehension. It will focus on basic grammatical structures and vocabulary, controlled and spontaneous expression, oral/written assignments, and an introduction to culture. The course will develop four basic language skills: speaking, writing, listening comprehension, and reading comprehension. It will focus on basic grammatical structures and vocabulary, controlled and spontaneous expression, oral/written assignments, and an introduction to culture. Language learning will be enhanced through the use of various audiovisual media, as well as additional learning activities in the language lab.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">All Arts, Literature and Communication Profiles</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00009</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria-Elena Grijalva-Barba</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of Spanish, formal or informal. The course will develop four basic language skills: speaking, writing, listening comprehension, and reading comprehension. It will focus on basic grammatical structures and vocabulary, controlled and spontaneous expression, oral/written assignments, and an introduction to culture. Language learning will be enhanced through the use of various audiovisual media, as well as additional learning activities in the language lab.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 10:00 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3D.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Spanish 1</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00012</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Francisco Goire</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed for students who have no prior knowledge of Spanish, formal or informal. Students will draw objects and figures in different configurations to explore a range of pictorial possibilities.  They will learn the fundamental elements of perspective. Perceptual skills of seeing and sighting will be developed through observation. In addition, students will learn the appropriate terminology pertaining to visual organization and its application.  They will explore a range of drawing techniques with a variety of tools on different surfaces. Slide presentations will expose students to historical and current drawing practices and help familiarize them to a variety of methodologies.  Ongoing drawing assignments and visual research will help develop the students individual creative response.  The technical and conceptual knowledge acquired in this course prepares students for further investigation in Drawing 2 (Term 2).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Natalie Olanick</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 1 course introduces students to the basic language of drawing from observation.  Students will draw objects and figures in different configurations to explore a range of pictorial possibilities.  They will learn the fundamental elements of perspective. Perceptual skills of seeing and sighting will be developed through observation. In addition, students will learn the appropriate terminology pertaining to visual organization and its application.  They will explore a range of drawing techniques with a variety of tools on different surfaces. Slide presentations will expose students to historical and current drawing practices and help familiarize them to a variety of methodologies.  Ongoing drawing assignments and visual research will help develop the students individual creative response.  The technical and conceptual knowledge acquired in this course prepares students for further investigation in Drawing 2 (Term 2).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">510-114-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Color and Painting 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Philip Hall</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 1 course introduces students to basic techniques in painting and subtractive colour theory.  Understanding and demonstrating the compositional dynamics of shape, texture, line and the illusion of space in connection with colour structures will form an essential part of the students learning.  During the course students will learn to interpret colour theory in a number of paintings designed to demonstrate how colour functions within the overall dynamic of pictorial composition.  Through figurative and abstract works many of the essential components of composition will be introduced. Knowledge acquired in this course will be applied in Painting 2 (Term 2).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Philip Hall</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 1 course introduces students to basic techniques in painting and subtractive colour theory.  Understanding and demonstrating the compositional dynamics of shape, texture, line and the illusion of space in connection with colour structures will form an essential part of the students learning.  During the course students will learn to interpret colour theory in a number of paintings designed to demonstrate how colour functions within the overall dynamic of pictorial composition.  Through figurative and abstract works many of the essential components of composition will be introduced. Knowledge acquired in this course will be applied in Painting 2 (Term 2).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">510-115-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Sculpture 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Rachel Echenberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 1 course introduces the students to the basic sculpture materials, hand tools, techniques and processes used in three-dimensional work. Clay modeling from observation, basic casting techniques, and elementary fabrication techniques in wood and metal form an integral part of course projects. The course introduces the student to visual vocabulary used in the creation of sculpture. Students will learn appropriate research methodologies and terminology related to the creation of three-dimensional forms. Heath and safety issues and protocol are integrated into the learning process and applied to studio practice in the studios and workshops. Knowledge acquired in this course will be applied in Sculpture 2 (Term 2) and all subsequent sculpture courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nina Dubois</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 1 course introduces the students to the basic sculpture materials, hand tools, techniques and processes used in three-dimensional work. Clay modeling from observation, basic casting techniques, and elementary fabrication techniques in wood and metal form an integral part of course projects. The course introduces the student to visual vocabulary used in the creation of sculpture. Students will learn appropriate research methodologies and terminology related to the creation of three-dimensional forms. Heath and safety issues and protocol are integrated into the learning process and applied to studio practice in the studios and workshops. Knowledge acquired in this course will be applied in Sculpture 2 (Term 2) and all subsequent sculpture courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 3:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">510-116-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">New Media</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Chronopoulos</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 1 course introduces the students to computers and networks as an art making platform.  Students will be introduced to the tradition, methods and ethical parameters of New Media art.  Students will conceive computer-based projects; and explore digital picture and photo editing, and additive colour theory. The course includes an introduction to simple animation and Internet tools and procedures.  Through an improved familiarity with computer hardware and software and adequate skills in the handling of digital tools, students will be prepared for Photography (Term 2) as well as New Media & Video (Term 3).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Chronopoulos</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 1 course introduces the students to computers and networks as an art making platform.  Students will be introduced to the tradition, methods and ethical parameters of New Media art.  Students will conceive computer-based projects; and explore digital picture and photo editing, and additive colour theory. The course includes an introduction to simple animation and Internet tools and procedures.  Through an improved familiarity with computer hardware and software and adequate skills in the handling of digital tools, students will be prepared for Photography (Term 2) as well as New Media & Video (Term 3).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.10</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">510-140-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Drawing from Observation</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kristi Ropeleski</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to introduce and develop perceptual skills and abilities. Students will learn drawing techniques and materials used to explore objects, figures and illusions of space through observation. An awareness and understanding of observed form will be developed through a rigorous exploration of proportion, line and shading. Drawing assignments are intended to increase the students' level of perception and to record aspects of their environment.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Interior Design</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kristi Ropeleski</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to introduce and develop perceptual skills and abilities. Topics include: horizon line and 1, 2, 3 point perspective, perspective grids for interiors and exteriors, eye level, figure placement, shadow projection and building complex forms.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">3D Animation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Harlan Johnson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will introduce students to a variety of perspective free hand and tool assisted techniques enabling them to choose appropriate methods for sketching on location; thumb-nailing; storyboarding; environment and prop design. The student will explore the relationship between gesture and basic shapes and how they relate to human anatomy. Topics include: spheres forms, box forms, ellipses and cylinders, combining forms, sequential posing, measuring, foreshortening, anatomical landmark tools, skeletal and muscular systems.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">3D Animation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">12:30 PM - 4:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joe Becker</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will introduce students to the animator's approach to figure drawing, by beginning with quick sketches and progressing towards specifics. The student will explore the relationship between gesture and basic shapes and how they relate to human anatomy. Topics include: spheres forms, box forms, ellipses and cylinders, combining forms, sequential posing, measuring, foreshortening, anatomical landmark tools, skeletal and muscular systems.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">3D Animation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:00 AM - 12:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">510-194-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Image and Ideas</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Baumflek</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 1 course focuses on developing an understanding of the relationship between form and content.  Students will be introduced to the fundamental concepts, elements, and principals of 2D organization and will make photographic works that explore compositional structures in relationship to assigned themes.  Works by well-known historic and contemporary photographers will be examined each week during in-class presentations and students will become familiar with the basic terms and vocabulary required to discuss photographic works.  Homework assignments will focus on developing content through compositional structures and through-the-lens framing.  Assignments will be examined each week during in-class critiques.  This course establishes a basis for future visual production in Term 2 courses.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Professional Photography</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.23</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Baumflek</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 1 course focuses on developing an understanding of the relationship between form and content.  Students will be introduced to the fundamental concepts, elements, and principals of 2D organization and will make photographic works that explore compositional structures in relationship to assigned themes.  Works by well-known historic and contemporary photographers will be examined each week during in-class presentations and students will become familiar with the basic terms and vocabulary required to discuss photographic works.  Homework assignments will focus on developing content through compositional structures and through-the-lens framing.  Assignments will be examined each week during in-class critiques.
