Students will engage in the process of developing personal expression through a sustained exploration of themes. They will be introduced to the use of metaphor, symbol and allegory in drawings that explore both size and scale. They will prepare surfaces and supports and experiment with different forms of presentation, such as working in series and installation. Current trends in drawing will be considered in works that explore abstraction and representation. This course prepares students for Drawing 4 (Term 4).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joe Becker</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 3 drawing course uses the technical knowledge gained in previous drawing courses and introduces imaginative new ways to explore drawing as a current medium of expression. Students will engage in the process of developing personal expression through a sustained exploration of themes. They will be introduced to the use of metaphor, symbol and allegory in drawings that explore both size and scale. They will prepare surfaces and supports and experiment with different forms of presentation, such as working in series and installation. Current trends in drawing will be considered in works that explore abstraction and representation. This course prepares students for Drawing 4 (Term 4).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">510-314-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Painting 3</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Antoinetta Grassi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 3 painting course builds on the technical and conceptual knowledge acquired in the previous painting and colour courses. In this course students will make paintings based on observation, imagination, and abstraction. There will be an emphasis on thematic and personal research, and students will compile reference materials and develop preliminary studies to develop their paintings. There will be a focus on selecting and preparing appropriate supports and surfaces, the use of grounds, and the use of transparent and impasto paint applications. The psychological effects of colour will be considered along with the formal and iconographic elements of painting. Current practices in contemporary painting will be considered to assist the student's personal development with the medium.  The knowledge and skills acquired in this course will help prepare students for Painting 4 and the Integrating Studio Practices course (Term 4).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Antoinetta Grassi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 3 painting course builds on the technical and conceptual knowledge acquired in the previous painting and colour courses. In this course students will make paintings based on observation, imagination, and abstraction. There will be an emphasis on thematic and personal research, and students will compile reference materials and develop preliminary studies to develop their paintings. There will be a focus on selecting and preparing appropriate supports and surfaces, the use of grounds, and the use of transparent and impasto paint applications. The psychological effects of colour will be considered along with the formal and iconographic elements of painting. Current practices in contemporary painting will be considered to assist the student's personal development with the medium.  The knowledge and skills acquired in this course will help prepare students for Painting 4 and the Integrating Studio Practices course (Term 4).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.15</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">510-315-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Sculpture 3</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nina Dubois</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 3 sculpture course builds on the technical knowledge gained in previous sculpture courses. It further develops casting processes begun in Sculpture 1 and introduces fabrication and construction processes in fiber arts. Heath and safety issues and protocol continue to be a concern with the use of new techniques and processes. Research and projects are developed using a conceptual and thematic approach emphasizing individual creativity and current approaches in sculpture. The conceptual and technical knowledge gained here can be applied to Sculpture 4 (Term 4).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nina Dubois</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 3 sculpture course builds on the technical knowledge gained in previous sculpture courses. It further develops casting processes begun in Sculpture 1 and introduces fabrication and construction processes in fiber arts. Heath and safety issues and protocol continue to be a concern with the use of new techniques and processes. Research and projects are developed using a conceptual and thematic approach emphasizing individual creativity and current approaches in sculpture. The conceptual and technical knowledge gained here can be applied to Sculpture 4 (Term 4).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.1</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">510-316-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Printmaking 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Julianna Joos</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 3 course introduces the students to basic printmaking processes and technical knowledge, integrating visual and compositional skills from previous Term 2 Drawing and Painting courses.  Students will create matrices for intaglio, relief and stencil processes. Printing editions for each of these processes will form an integral part of course projects. Students will learn appropriate research methodologies to produce developmental work and sketches adapted to each process. The safe use of tools and equipment and methodological organization of space are integrated into the learning process and applied to studio practice in the printmaking studio. Knowledge acquired in this course will be applied in Printmaking 2 (Term 4).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Julianna Joos</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 3 course introduces the students to basic printmaking processes and technical knowledge, integrating visual and compositional skills from previous Term 2 Drawing and Painting courses. Using video recording technologies and editing software, the student will conceive and create video based artworks and examine different options to structure the work within a contemporary context. This course will prepare the student for Integrating Studio Practices (Term 4).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Baumflek</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 3 studio course explores the use of digital video as a contemporary art medium. Students will develop visual acuity through the analysis and implementation of fundamental elements and principles of 3D design. Ideation and creative thought will be developed by the students into fully realized physical forms. Through hands-on projects, students will gain insight into the properties of various materials with a specific focus on wood. Techniques of layout, construction, assembly and finishing will be explored through creative experimentation. Students will learn to comment on and evaluate their creative projects, applying the compositional principles, vocabulary and concepts taught in the course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Interior Design</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Nina Dubois</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The objective of this course is to broaden students conceptual and technical skills in 3D design and art. 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.25</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Joe Becker</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Basic Drawing lays a foundation for drawing skills and observation by identifying important elements that comprise a drawing or sketch, control compositional elements, apply the principles of linear and aerial perspective, and to use light and shade to create different effects.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Graphic Design</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.25</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">511-113-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Studio Art</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Harlan Johnson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course introduces students to contemporary visual culture through guided research and studio projects involving drawing, acrylic painting, collage, photomontage (including digital platforms).  Students will become fluent in the application of visual language through exploration of two-dimensional compositional strategies.  They will broaden their research skills while becoming familiar with major art trends, artists, current visual practices but also making connections with other fields of study through numerous trips to contemporary galleries and museums.  Project research will be conducted through use of the web, the library and critical readings.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">511-313-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Sculpture and Ideas</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Baumflek</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will explore the sculptural relationship between form and meaning.  Topical written and visual research will set the path for exercises and projects.  Traditional and contemporary sculptural processes such as clay modelling, casting, assemblage and construction will be taught in fully equipped studios including the wood shop.  The projects will help develop analytical and critical skills within the creation of three-dimensional form.  A gallery or museum visit will allow students to be confronted with artwork by professional artists which will enrich their visual vocabulary.  Students will learn to critique works and sharpen their point of view through the application of concepts, compositional principles and vocabulary taught in the course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.5</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">511-314-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Printmaking</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Julianna Joos</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The foundations of the print were laid with the first incised line on a rock wall, in stone, bone, horn or metal. The course will trace printmakings evolution from a reproduction technique to its role as an original medium of contemporary expression.  Students will learn the vocabulary specific to printmaking allowing them to appreciate the qualities of an original print.  Students will explore the intaglio, relief and/or stencil processes through the creation of original prints.  Technical exploration will include the use of carving tools for incising plates, the use of rollers and squeegees for inking, paper preparation, and the setting of presses.  A small edition of original prints will be produced in each technique explored.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.13</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">511-315-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Internet Art and Culture</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Maria Chronopoulos</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores new media art and culture through the use of the Internet as a platform for art making. Assigned readings and lectures will compare artistic and literary works created in the vernacular of Internet with traditional art media.  Through written and practical assignments, art projects and guided critiques, the student will analyze the use of visual language in cultural objects, the nature of the network and the computer interface as well as the application of the digital platform for art.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.10</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">511-414-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Drawing/Painting Studio Projects</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Antoinetta Grassi</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will introduce students to various techniques in painting and drawing.  Students will develop an awareness of the physical properties of painting mediums through a number of exercises exploring the dynamic use of acrylic colours.  Use of painting and drawing materials will be developed through both non-representational and figurative exercises.  Compositions of colour, line and shape will be explored offering students fundamental expressive structures for working.  Students will be encouraged to collect visual source material from sketches and collages to help assemble a bank of images.  This studio environment will foster an open yet critical dialogue and response to art-making allowing for greater exploration in future courses. Students will be shown works by known artists from the past and present to help locate and enrich their studio endeavours.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.25</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">511-498-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Integrating Activity (IA)</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Naomi London</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Under the guidance of a teacher, the students will work on a self-directed major project that will consist primarily of the development, production and evaluation of a creative work.  The project will provide them with opportunities to demonstrate their creativity, and their ability to integrate the knowledge, skills and attitudes they have attained in both specific education and general education courses.  Research, interpretation, innovation and critical thinking skills will also be assessed in this course.  Students will present their works in a group exhibition and produce a catalogue.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 5:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.25</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">511-912-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Drawing Techniques</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">3 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Harlan Johnson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The expressive power of drawing as a visual language is introduced and investigated through the exploitation of various drawing techniques.  Working from observation of live models, objects, the environment, and from imagined forms, the students will acquire skills while sketching and rendering with a number of basic drawing materials.  Through representation and abstraction, they will apply their research and learn compositional strategies to express their ideas visually.  Historical and contemporary trends in drawing approaches will be examined through presentations, and students will have an opportunity to discuss and critique their drawings as explored in studio or independently.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Monday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.25</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Kristi Ropeleski</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">The expressive power of drawing as a visual language is introduced and investigated through the exploitation of various drawing techniques. Through demonstrations, practical exercises and a series of extended projects, the student will explore the computer both as an imaginative research tool and as a viewing platform.  The student will explore cultural diversity through the computer interface, situate computer imagery as a distinct and unique means of expression and will interpret a personal world view through digital art projects.  Through directed critiques and discussions, the student will compare established forms of art with works in digital media and will situate the products of the digital representation in the tradition of cultural objects from here and elsewhere.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, and Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Julianna Joos</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is an introduction to art making with the computer. The student will explore cultural diversity through the computer interface, situate computer imagery as a distinct and unique means of expression and will interpret a personal world view through digital art projects. Painting projects will explore modes of representation and abstraction.  Students will work with acrylic colours to discover the many ways paint can be handled.  Students will learn subtractive colour mixing while investigating genres such as still life, figure, portrait and landscape.  Scale will be considered in paintings of various sizes on different supports.  Students will become aware of different periods and approaches to painting to help focus their own preferences.  In-class critiques will incorporate an understanding of relevant terminology.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.25</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">511-916-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Drawing and Ideas</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">David Philip Hall</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will explore the medium of drawing in two related ways: ongoing exposure to historical and contemporary forms of drawing through planned fieldtrips to museums and galleries, and by developing a personal approach to drawing related to ideas addressed during the fieldtrips as well as to contemporary culture at large.  These may include identity, gender, and politics to name a few.  Through a series of in-class projects and assignments, students will learn introductory forms of composition through the exploration of material, methods and techniques; for example, line quality, shading and hatching as well as the exploration of dry and wet media such as ink, charcoal, and graphite.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 12:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.25</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">511-922-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Graphic Novels and Artists' Books</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Natalie Olanick</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course is designed to familiarize students with the relationships between visual images and text by examining representative collected works of both genres.  The course will explore two related types of text and image art  the artist's book and the graphic novel.  These art forms will be investigated in relationship to their contexts in fine arts and popular culture forms of creative graphic production.  Students will produce several artist's books and graphic novels applying both two- and three-dimensional aspects of the art form. This course will identify and investigate the main characteristics of both genres and allow students to develop their skills in representational and abstract image making, while helping further explore the potential for visual communicative through an on-going exposure to historical and contemporary precedents.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.23</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">511-924-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Photo Art</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Bahar Taheri</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores the use of photography as an integral component in art making.  Students will create mixed media artworks that incorporate photography as both a research tool and as a medium.  Referencing their own digital images, they will explore a range of materials and techniques to address and create assigned art projects.  Through personal expression, students explore notions of time, space, identity, reality, artifice and transformation.  Instruction includes basic composition and an introduction to art techniques such as drawing, painting, collage and mixed-media.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, and Literature</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3B.23</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">511-BXA-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Applications in Fine Arts</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Sculptural Assemblage</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Naomi London</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">In this course, students will produce sculptures through assemblage of materials such as: paper, wood, metal and found objects using glues, transfers, paints and a range of mechanical connections. They will also learn the vocabulary appropriate to assemblage (e.g. iconography, fundamentals of composition, etc.), and to analyze the work of various sculptors.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">1G.8</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Drawing from Observation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Bahar Taheri</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students learn to draw from observation using graphite, conte and charcoal. Particular attention is given to gesture, contour, form, proportion, the use of value patterns and the representation of pictorial space. Drawing from the model will also be included. Students also learn how to critique a work of art using appropriate terminology.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">8:30 AM - 11:30 AM</td><td data-label="Room">2G.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">520-102-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Art History 1</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gwen Baddeley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 1 course focuses on the exploration of style, content and context, in a chronological and thematic survey of visual art from Prehistoric to the 16th century Renaissance.  The student will develop an ability to critically analyse art historical imagery through the utilization of research methodologies, investigating the interface between art, content, style and context. This course establishes a basis for exploring the major trends, theories and methodologies of visual art production to be examined in Art History 2 (Term 2).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">10:00 AM - 1:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4G.2A</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Pohanna Feinberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This Term 1 course focuses on the exploration of style, content and context, in a chronological and thematic survey of visual art from Prehistoric to the 16th century Renaissance.  The student will develop an ability to critically analyse art historical imagery through the utilization of research methodologies, investigating the interface between art, content, style and context. This course establishes a basis for exploring the major trends, theories and methodologies of visual art production to be examined in Art History 2 (Term 2).</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3F.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">520-191-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">History of Visual and Graphic Arts</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gwen Baddeley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will examine major art movements from the past and present, their cultural and historical context and their impact on the present day popular culture of film and video games.  Topics include: media, trends, subjective factors and perception, and icons.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">3D Animation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">3:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gwen Baddeley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will examine major art movements from the past and present, their cultural and historical context and their impact on the present day popular culture of film and video games.  Topics include: media, trends, subjective factors and perception, and icons.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">3D Animation</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Friday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Lab</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">520-222-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Renaissance to Modern Art</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Pohanna Feinberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">From Leonardo to the atomic bomb, the critical centuries from the 16th century to the Modern era witnessed extraordinary changes in the visual arts and globalization.  By an examination of art works, artists, art movements and institutions dealing with themes such as portraiture and power, conquest and revolution, perception and conception, realism and abstraction, expressionism and protest, this course will consider the increasingly complex visual language, ideas and rapid socio-cultural evolution that shaped diverse forms of representation from the 16th century to the Modern era.  Course components will include lectures, analysis, discussion of specific art works, methodologies, social contexts and ideas, media presentations and gallery visits, with an exploration forged with contemporary art practice and ideas, where relevant.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3G.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">520-399-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Illustration - Trends and Movements</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Amanda Beattie</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course will provide students with a solid background in the rich histories of art and design that contribute to current practices in the field of Illustration. The visual expression of past ideas will be connected to current visual culture and trends in illustration and visual art production, and will focus on illustration history that will extend from the magical Golden Age of 19th century book publication to the dynamic and diverse illustrators and illustration landmarks of the 20th and 21st centuries.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Illustration</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4H.15</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">520-913-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Cave to Renaissance Art</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Gwen Baddeley</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">From the first stirrings of the mythic imagination to the sensibilities of the Renaissance, this course examines the dynamic evolution of visual art and architecture of this era.  Topics that connect past art production to current practice are explored targeting artworks from ancient societies and contemporary culture.  Student research includes topics that encompass the pyramids of Egypt, medieval castles, Renaissance palaces, body markings and artistic enterprise within a global context.  An exploration of themes such as shamanism, notions of beauty and the divine, gender, images of authority, religious and political conflict, patronage and the emergence of the artist, facilitate the students awareness of how visual art reflects socio-cultural aspirations and relevance.  Discussion, media presentations, lectures, field trips to museums and galleries, oral presentations and written research will be key components of this course.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Languages, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.3</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">520-916-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Decoding Visual Art</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Pohanna Feinberg</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">While exploring current trends in exhibition making and curatorial practice, students will research and develop a proposal for a dream exhibition based on a concept/theme and a context/location of their choice. Art historical methodologies will be employed to compose interpretations for proposed visual art works (historical and/or contemporary art, craft, street art, photography, architecture, new media art, etc.). Led by student interests, the course will engage with topics such as race, gender, class, mental health, kinship/family, the environment, Indigenous knowledge, humour, identity and more. The final version of the dream exhibition will include a written text combined with media such as images, video, and audio. Exhibition visits, workshops and guest lectures will enrich the theoretical and practical aspects of the final project.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts<br>This section will be offered partially on-line. Students registering for this section are expected to have individual access to the internet.</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:00 PM - 6:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">5D.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">520-921-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Art and Design History</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Emma Doubt</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Art and Design History develops research and analytical skills regarding the history of visual arts and graphic design, taking into account formal, aesthetic and societal links between art, architecture and design.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Graphic Design</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Tuesday</td><td data-label="Time">1:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.5</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">520-922-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Photography: Themes and Evolution</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Emma Doubt</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Photography has come to dominate our contemporary visual world through a meteoric rise as a powerful medium of expression.  This course traces that rise by a thematic survey of the doers and shakers who developed the rich language of photography in its diversified global themes, and technical evolution.  The exploration in this course will encompass but not be limited to studies in portraiture, social and auteur documentary, photojournalistic truth and censorship, landscape and ecology, photography as art, and issues in contemporary photography.  Students will develop a critical, analytical understanding of the issues involved through classroom situations, individual research and production, with museum/gallery visits to include the Mois de la Photo biennales and World Press Photo Shows when applicable.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Arts and Culture, Cinema-Communications, Interactive Media Arts, Literature, and Studio Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">520-972-DW</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Art Aesthetics in Product Design</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">1 section</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Watson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This course explores the formal and aesthetic language of art and human-centered design in context.  In order to refine analytical skills, both written and oral, this course requires students to research art and object design using the structural frameworks introduced in class and contributing disciplines.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Comment</label><div class="col-md-10">Industrial Design</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">12:00 PM - 4:00 PM</td><td data-label="Room">3E.6</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div><div class="course-wrap"><div class="course-number-title clearfix"><div class="info-container row" style="overflow:hidden; text-align:right;"><div class="cnumber btn btn-default col-md-2">520-BWA-03</div> <div class="ctitle col-md-8" style="text-align:left;">Introduction to Art History</div>  <span class="csection btn btn-sm col-md-2" style="display:inline-block;">2 sections</span></div><span class="expand-row"></span></div><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Photography: The Art and Influence</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00001</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Emma Doubt</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">This is a comprehensive survey of photography from its origins in the 19th century to the present day. Its aesthetic evolution and technical innovations are examined, as are its socio-economic, political and philosophical influences. The relationships between photography, painting and other visual arts are also  explored.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Thursday</td><td data-label="Time">11:30 AM - 2:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4A.4</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --><ul class="section-details clearfix"><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section Title</label><div class="col-md-10">Modernism and the VIsual Arts</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Section</label><div class="col-md-10"><strong>00002</strong></div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Teacher</label><div class="col-md-10">Sarah Watson</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Description</label><div class="col-md-10 description">Students will be introduced to Modernism in the visual arts through examination of the socio-political context of the Avant-Garde in the 19th century.  Particular attention will be given to the rise of Surrealism in Europe and North America in the early decades of the 20th century.  Students will evaluate the main characteristics of at least three artistic currents in the late 18th, 19th and 20th centuries.</div></li><!-- description --><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Course<br> Drop Date</label><div class="col-md-10">Monday, September 19, 2022</div></li><li class="row"><label class="col-md-2">Schedule</label><div class="col-md-10 schedule"><table class="schedule-details"><tr><td data-label="Day">Wednesday</td><td data-label="Time">2:30 PM - 5:30 PM</td><td data-label="Room">4F.2</td><td data-label="Type">Class</td></tr></table><!-- .schedule-details --></div></li><!-- schedule --></ul><!-- .section-details --></div></div><!-- .course-list-table -->
